DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Beazley)—by leave—proposed:

That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the moving forthwith of a motion rescinding the resolution of the House of 24 June 1992 which adopted a report from the committee of the whole House agreeing to 25 amendments contained in a schedule of amendments received from the Senate in message No. 491 in respect of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. It needs to be understood that, in relation to the procedures and the relationship of the two chambers of the Australian Parliament, there are several aspects of concern. The first is that the Government has decided on a number of occasions to introduce the guillotine. On the day this particular matter was before this House, totally inadequate time was provided for an adequate consideration of what is a very serious public issue. I think the Government itself has to accept responsibility for the confusion that has arisen.

PARA.TAB: Because of the guillotine, this place is not given a proper opportunity to consider the nuances of legislation and, more and more as a result of the application of the guillotine, it is now the Senate which is deciding significant matters of government policy. It is all very well for the Government to say, `Oh, but we haven't got the numbers there or we haven't got the numbers here, so we will pass things through in a perfunctory fashion'. As I see it, that is not the role and responsibility of the House of Representatives.

The first point I make in relation to this suspension of Standing Orders, which significantly relates to the reason this place did not debate the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill, is that the Government, by using the guillotine the way it is, is denying members of the House of Representatives the proper opportunity to scrutinise legislation. I think it is despicable; I think it is an indictment on the Government, and it reflects very much the whole core of its administration. The reason we have this motion for the suspension of Standing Orders is that the Government believes it is essential to correct an error that resulted from the expeditious passage of amendments in the Senate that were then transferred back to this chamber. The first point is that the Government has to accept full responsibility for the failure of the legislation to be passed as was intended.

The second point I make is that it is quite critical that the certification, which is necessary before matters of this sort go to the Governor-General for signature, accords with the will of the two chambers. I commend the Clerk of the House for the action he took in accepting that the legislation was not what the House considered it to be when it was deliberated upon. I know that official advice was given by Government departments to the Clerk that changes were made to the actual amendment made in the Senate. I know that in the current interpretations provided by the High Court there has been a tendency to look at the whole debate in considering any doubt upon particular wording of legislation. I do not think a House of Parliament can be treated in any casual, perfunctory manner. I think if legislation is before us, even though we may not have the numbers on this side of the House, we should have an opportunity to deliberate upon it.

The point was that we did not as a chamber deliberate on the same matters considered in the Senate. For that reason it would have been diminished in its stature. As my colleague the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) says, the certificate was provided on the basis that it was the intention of the House of Representatives to accept whatever amendments the Senate might have passed to us. That is the key issue. This House does not accept as a matter of casual reference what the Senate passes. We have an authority right on our own behalf.

I think the Clerk of this chamber deserves to be commended for the way in which he acted and the way in which he upheld the status and dignity of not only the chamber but also every member of this place. Mr Speaker, I commend both you and the Clerk for acting formally in accordance with the responsibilities that you exercise on our behalf. There might be some matters on which I disagree with your interpretation of Standing Orders, Mr Speaker, but on this occasion I believe you have actually done the right thing. That deserves to be put on record.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have me doubting whether I did the right thing now.
—Hardly let it be said; after all, I did say that you did it on the advice of the Clerk, and as long as you rely on his advice I have no doubt that you are in good company.

PARA.TAB: The point at issue is that we are now being called on to deliberate on a significant and sensitive proposal which had been put through this chamber on an incorrect basis. I know my colleague the shadow Minister for social security, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who is at the table, is about to talk on the substance of the Bill. I want only to say that as far as I am concerned I do not think it is good enough that matters of this sort are sent to the House and that, because the Senate decides what the legislation will be, we automatically accept them. We do not, and the action the Clerk and Mr Speaker have taken has demonstrated that the House of Representatives has a unique responsibility. I commend the Clerk and you, Mr Speaker, for the actions you have taken.

On the substance of the measure, I have no doubt the honourable member for Bradfield will speak in detail. Like he and every other member of the House, I regard this as being quite remarkable in its timing. This is one of the areas where the Government is adding to the imposition of business, at a time when it has produced a Budget which it says is about jobs. The reality is that this particular measure is denying jobs to people. This particular measure is one of the imposts on the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The right honourable member might get back to the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders rather than that matter.
—I am. We are suspending Standing Orders so that we can deny jobs to people. I see no reason to suspend Standing Orders—
—The right honourable member for New England shall not be semantic about this. We will get back to the matter before the House.
—I am very much on that, Mr Speaker. As you would know, I am concerned about the jobs of people. I think it is an inappropriate reaction that we suspend Standing Orders.
—I will not have you stealing the thunder of your colleague the honourable member for Bradfield.

—I think it would have been far better if the measure itself had been allowed to lapse. Indeed, if that had been the ultimate result of the action taken by the Clerk and yourself, Mr Speaker, your action would have been even more commendable.

—On behalf of the Opposition I endorse the views expressed by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). This is a serious matter. I will be examining in greater detail the substantive issues that have been raised, but we would like to place on record our concern that the whole question of the legislative program of the House can be affected in this way, especially by the action taken in this particular case. We agree that the action taken by you was the only alternative available at the time.

—I want to endorse much of what has been said by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). Mr Speaker, you will be aware that the legislative power of the Commonwealth is vested in the Parliament, and the Parliament consists of the Queen, the Senate and the House of Representatives. It is commonly overlooked that there are three elements to the Parliament, including the Queen. Of course, that is an institution that those on the other side would like to do away with at the current time. But unless a Bill goes through the House of Representatives and through the Senate and has the assent of the Governor-General as the Queen's representative, it does not become law.

PARA.TAB: I would like to commend the Clerk of the House who has taken a very proper constitutional position in relation to this particular incident. For in this particular incident the form of the Bill that was passed by the Senate was not the same as the form of the Bill passed by the House of Representatives. Therefore, it could not be certified for the Governor-General's assent, and could not become law under that provision of the Australian Constitution. If there had been a temptation to overlook that, that would have been an infringement of high constitutional position and an infringement of the law that governs this Parliament and all the actions that we engage in.

I think we owe a debt of gratitude to the Clerk of the House for the stand that was taken. We also owe a debt of gratitude to the Governor-General who, quite properly in the circumstances, was unable to give royal assent to the actual Bill, which remains a Bill. It has never become an Act and has never become law. The purpose of this suspension of Standing Orders is to allow that error to be rectified in the proper way and, if it should be the case after due deliberation by this House and the Senate and assent by the Governor-General, for that matter to become law.

I want to underline that this is the proper way in which to approach this particular problem, to bring it back to this House for rectification. There has been a tendency in the past to continue on with matters which have not been validly enacted and to treat them as though they had been enacted and had become law. It is a matter of great regret that in the absence—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think the honourable member is straying.
—No, I am right on this. In the absence of this suspension of Standing Orders—

—Order! The honourable member is straying a little bit from what this particular suspension is about. I am quite happy to entertain this debate that the honourable member is starting when we get to the substantive motion. I think that is the proper place to do that.
—I am still speaking on the suspension because the point I am making is that the suspension is the proper way of rectification. That is the point I am elaborating at this stage.
—The rescission of the resolution is the proper way of rectifying the matter. All the suspension does is to get us to that stage. The honourable member for Higgins is slightly jumping the gun.

—I am addressing the question of the suspension which will allow the rescission motion to be put in due course. I am addressing the procedure that must be engaged in if the rescission motion is to be put. I am suggesting that this is the proper procedure. I am addressing the procedures that should be observed by the forms of the House.

—In that case the honourable member is jumping the gun a little. The procedure that the honourable member wants to talk about is dealt with by the rescission motion itself. The honourable member can go to why Standing Orders should or should not be suspended, but we will not entertain the substantive debate on the rescission now. I do not know why the honourable member wants to do it now.

—I would like to conclude the point I am making about the suspension. The suspension is the gateway to the rescission motion. I am addressing that particular procedural matter. I am addressing the reason why the suspension is necessary in these circumstances. If need be, I will come back on the substantive motion, but I do not want to address the substantive motion at this stage.
—The substantive motion might be the best place to do it.

—The point I make is that the legislative power of the Commonwealth is vested in the House, the Senate and the Queen. If the legislative power is not exercised in relation to a Bill with all of those three constituent parts, then the Bill does not become an Act and nobody has the right to treat it as an Act. It is necessary to come back, if need be to suspend Standing Orders, and to move a rectification. It would be a fundamental misconception to have treated the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill as anything other than a legislative proposal for the past couple of weeks. Yet we have seen the Tax Office—

—Order! The honourable member is now most certainly straying off the suspension. You are not going to debate the substantive motion now. You can do it in a few moments time. I do not know why you want to waste the time of the House.

—I will do that in a few moments time, and I will conclude on the suspension. When the suspension is opened up and it is then possible to move the motion in order to rectify an error of the House, it will be necessary at that stage for the House to take note of what has actually occurred, how it has actually occurred and why it was wrong as a matter of law that the Bill was treated as anything other than a legislative proposal in the interim and can only be rectified after the House has been satisfied as to both the procedure and the substance in relation to the matter.
—Order! If the honourable member wants to pursue that, he will resume his seat.
—I am finished, Mr Speaker, and could have finished much more quickly.

—The whole debate may not have been necessary if the honourable member for Higgins had a bit more knowledge of the procedures of the House and waited until we got to the substantive motion rather than try to debate the substantive motion on the suspension of Standing Orders.

PARA.TAB: While I am on the matter, I would point to the fact that the honourable member for Higgins, who is the shadow Attorney-General, brought a bit of a red herring into the debate which probably needs to be clarified. In his remarks he said that the Governor-General was owed a debt of gratitude. Of course, as the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) pointed out in his contribution, and it should be known by the honourable member for Higgins, the reason we are at this stage is that I would not send the Bill to the Governor-General. The Governor-General quite properly had nothing to do with this. I most certainly would not have put the Governor-General in a position where he would have had anything to do with this. I would not like the shadow Attorney-General to have misled people on that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek to clarify the point.
—I am more than happy to listen.

—The point I made was that the Clerk quite properly had not certified that the Bill which had been passed by the Senate was in the same form as the Bill which had been passed by the House. In those circumstances the same Bill had not been enacted by two of the constituent parts of the Parliament and could not be given assent by the Governor-General. The point I made was that the Clerk had acted quite properly and indeed that the Governor-General had acted quite properly. I am not suggesting for a moment that you, Mr Speaker, had acted improperly on that. I hope that you did not gain that impression and that you and I are in agreement on that particular proposition.

—The honourable member for Higgins has compounded his error again by bringing the Governor-General into this. Not only did the Governor-General not act on it; the Governor-General was incapable of acting on it because it was not a matter that was before him. I would not like you to give people the wrong impression about this.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the resolution of the House of Representatives of 24 June 1992 adopting a report from the Committee of the Whole House agreeing to 25 amendments contained in a schedule of amendments received from the Senate in message No. 491 in respect of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 be rescinded.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition spokesmen like to give us civic lectures on these matters. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), chose to do so and, in so doing, revealed that, whatever he might know about constitutional and legal processes, he knows very little about the Standing Orders of the House. I suppose the House ought to be grateful that at least one useful purpose has been served by this debate here today: he has been able to be educated by your good self, Mr Speaker, on important elements of those. That will not go amiss.

PARA.TAB: The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) also spoke way outside Standing Orders. The difference between the right honourable member for New England and the honourable member for Higgins is that the right honourable member for New England knew he was doing it. That is because he has been in this place for a very long time. He is an ornament to this place and, when he rises here, none of us dares criticise him. The honourable member for Higgins matters very little to the proceedings of the House, and the sooner he is out of the place the better.

On 24 June 1992, by message No. 491, the Senate returned the Bill to the House of Representatives acquainting the House that the Senate had agreed to the Bill with the amendments indicated by an annexed schedule, in which amendments the Senate requested the concurrence of the House of Representatives. The annexed schedule contained 25 amendments.

On 24 June 1992, the message was reported in the House of Representatives and ordered to be taken into consideration in Committee of the Whole House forthwith. In committee, a motion that the amendments be agreed to was debated and agreed to, and the report from the Committee was adopted by the House. The House of Representatives had therefore agreed to the 25 amendments contained in the annexed schedule received from the Senate.

On 24 June 1992, message No. 581 was sent from the House advising the Senate that the House had agreed to the amendments. On 25 June 1992, the Bill was sent for the printing of copies required for the royal assent, incorporating the 25 amendments. In the Senate, House of Representatives message No. 581 was reported.

On 29 June 1992, the revised Bill was received from the AGPS and checked in anticipation of its forwarding to the Governor-General for royal assent. Shortly before its anticipated transmission, advice was received from both the Australian Taxation Office and the Office of Parliamentary Counsel that they believed four of the amendments contained in the schedule of amendments received from the Senate had not been made by the Senate. Oral inquiries were initiated with officers of the Senate to ascertain the position. On 30 June it was confirmed that four of the amendments were not in fact made by the Senate. As a consequence of this error, the House of Representatives had been asked to agree, and had agreed, to four amendments which had not been made by the Senate.

The Clerk of the House felt that in these circumstances it was not possible for him to provide the required certificate as a prerequisite to the transmission of the Bill by the Speaker to the Governor-General for royal assent, and the Speaker was not prepared to transmit the Bill to the Governor-General. In the case of Bills initiated in the House of Representatives, it is necessary for the Clerk of the House to provide the following certificate on a Bill prior to its being submitted by the Speaker to the Governor-General for royal assent:
I hereby certify that the above is a fair print of the . . . Bill 19 . . . which originated in the House of Representatives and has been finally passed by the Senate and the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill that was passed by the House was not the Bill that had been passed by the Senate, so neither form of the Bill had been passed by both Houses. A report by the Clerk of the Senate stated, inter alia:

I believe that the view that the bill cannot proceed is mistaken. In accordance with the usual procedures, the House of Representatives passed a resolution the effect of which is to agree to the amendments made by the Senate in the bill. That resolution did not have the effect of endorsing the erroneous schedule. It is the documentary record of the proceedings which is incorrect, not the proceedings in either House, the effect and intention of which are perfectly clear. To say that the bill now cannot pass because of the error in the schedule is to say that the erroneous record of proceedings prevails over the proceedings themselves. It is not correct, as the government's advisers seem to have concluded, that the Houses have not agreed to the bill in the same form. It is clear that the Houses have agreed to the same bill; it is the documentary record of that process which is inaccurate. The record should be amended to reflect the proceedings, rather than the proceedings altered to reflect the record.

To amend the record `to reflect the proceedings, rather than the proceedings altered to reflect the record' would have been perfectly in order in respect of the Senate proceedings. If a corrected schedule of amendments was sent to the House of Representatives in substitution for that sent previously before the House acted, it would have reflected what actually did happen in the Senate. However, to suggest that `it is the documentary record of proceedings which is incorrect, not the proceedings in either House, the effect and intention of which are perfectly clear' ignores what occurred in the House of Representatives. The House actually agreed to 25 `amendments', a schedule of which had been circulated in the chamber as amendments made by the Senate. We now know that four of them had not been made by the Senate. It is not possible to ignore the fact that, because of the error in the Senate schedule, the House had agreed to a different version of the Bill and no amendment of the record will alter that fact.

PARA.TAB: There is provision in the Standing Orders of the House for the correction of errors of a verbal, formal, clerical or typographical nature. Standing order 241 provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments of a verbal or formal nature may be made, and clerical or typographical errors may be corrected, in any part of the bill by the Clerk acting with the authority of the Chairman of Committees.

Such errors are regularly corrected. In this case the four amendments included in the Senate schedule in error were amendments of substance which could not be dealt with under this provision. The error may have been a simple, and indeed an understandable, one. Perhaps it was a clerical error. It could have been corrected if detected before the House acted, but the House had acted on the basis of material received and circulated. It endorsed this material, erroneous as the material was. This stage having been reached, it was concluded, rightly it is submitted, that the matter was past the stage where it could be corrected under the provisions of standing order 241.

PARA.TAB: The reason I went into that fairly lengthy explanation is that I think the process in which we have been engaged in terms of the Standing Orders and procedures and relations between the two Houses actually has been quite important, and it is fairly important to put on the record here the views—as indeed the views of various of the Senate Clerks on these matters have been put on the record in the Senate—of the way in which you, Mr Speaker, arrived at your decisions and the Clerks advised you to arrive at those particular decisions, as there are elements of precedent involved here. There is no point, I believe, in getting into blaming anyone for the particular processes that produced this situation. Clearly we in this place do rely, in practical terms in our operations here, on receiving correct advice from the Senate on what have actually been its proceedings. It is all very well to call upon Ministers to read avidly through the plethora of amendments that the Senate passes on to this place and arrive at correct conclusions about them. The fact is that towards the end of a session no government is in a position to ensure that this proceeding takes place absolutely. I think Ministers are entitled to anticipate—because in general this is the case—that the materials that are received from the Senate accurately reflect what was passed by the Senate.

It is not as though we are inexperienced in these matters. Hundreds of Bills in a parliament are amended by the Senate and arrive back here on the basis of perfectly correct advice as to what the Senate's intentions were in dealing with them. In this case this did not occur. Therefore, how it ought to be handled and how it ought to be fixed required a degree of deliberation.

There appeared to be some criticism outside the provision of Standing Orders emerging from the last Opposition speaker on whether or not it is right for people to act as though Bills had been enacted. He would be aware that, in the area of the operations of the Treasury and with taxation legislation in particular, when the Taxation Commissioner finds, for example, a practice of which he disapproves but which requires legislation to be corrected, there is an automatic assumption that any particular activity is backdated to that time, irrespective of whether or not legislation has been passed by the House correcting that particular problem. There is much less of a purist practice in this regard than he would have us believe, at least by the sorts of remarks that he made during the discussion on the motion for the suspension of standing and sessional orders. I think that the Treasury and the Minister have conducted themselves perfectly appropriately in this regard.

I will add one comment of my own with regard to this matter. I am not completely convinced that, having discovered this error, the Senate needed to go through the process of debating this all over again yesterday. In my view, all that was required of the Senate was that, as soon as the error was discovered, it transmit to us a correct version of events. The exercise which took place in the Senate yesterday concerning this matter was a waste of its time. I think it would have more sensibly established the correct way of handling such matters if it had made a simple decision to correct its advice.

In terms of precedent, what occurred in the Senate yesterday was more than a little unfortunate. Basically, the Australian Democrats and the Opposition have adopted a very sensible approach to this matter. They want to see the process corrected. Therefore, the full implications of what the Senate did yesterday are not necessarily revealed to us because of that restraint on the part of the Opposition and the Democrats in their handling of it.

But one could envisage, by way of precedent, an opportunity arising from this for people capable of getting a Senate majority—or even if they do not have a Senate majority—to create quite a deal of mischief in handling a particular piece of legislation. The fact of the matter is that the voting system we have in this country means that no government will ever control the Senate—certainly not control it reliably—for any lengthy period of time. The Senate, with its plethora of parties, Independents and the like, will produce for time everlasting situations when governments and the House will be held hostage to a fairly knock-about attitude to material before it.

Getting a piece of legislation out of the Senate is, from time to time, like extracting blood from a stone. When it finally appears one is very grateful. Then we find that, through absolutely no fault of the House, because an error has been made in the transmission of materials from the Senate, it can go through the whole darn process again. This is disruptive of the legislative process in a totally unnecessary way.

I concede that it was open to the Democrats and the Opposition—because, I think erroneously, this matter was placed back in the hands of the Senate—to play exactly that role in this instance. They chose not to do that, so this is not a criticism directed at them in any way, shape or form. I simply point out that as we are dealing here with a whole series of precedents as to how this material ought to be handled in the future, it is necessary to draw attention to the consequences of one of the precedents that have been set in the way in which this matter has been handled. I only hope that the Presiding Officer in the Senate will give due consideration to whether or not absolutely everything that he did in this instance in requiring this matter to come back before the Senate for consideration was entirely necessary.

I do not have any quarrel at all with the way in which you have handled this matter, Mr Speaker. I think it would also be fair to place it on record that, in the opinion of the Solicitor-General of the Commonwealth, the Senate's consideration of this matter yesterday was not required. I think that would probably also reflect the opinion of the Clerks here—they cannot speak for themselves, but I will say that nevertheless—and also your opinion, Mr Speaker, on this matter. It is a matter of regret that we now have to consider this recission motion. I do not accept that any blame ought to be attributed here.

At the end of a session it does not matter whether we are under guillotine or anything else. The process at the end of a session always requires activity of this nature by the Senate and the House of Representatives. Indeed, this has absolutely nothing to do with the guillotine; it does not matter whether there was any guillotine in place at all. At the end of the year, guillotine or otherwise, there is always pressure to complete legislation by the end of the session.

I can well recollect times in the past when the Government and the Opposition have not legislated at the end of a session under guillotine but have legislated through the ordinary processes. We have arrived at precisely this position, where we have played ping-pong with the Senate in the last couple of days on legislation that came from the Senate. The alternative, of course, is to sit through Christmas or to sit through a period that has been scheduled as a parliamentary break.

I also do not accept that the guillotine produces hasty legislation that would not be corrected in this place. The vast bulk of the corrections to superannuation legislation by the Senate properly reflect political positions that have been arrived at. There is disagreement with Government policy and, because the Government does not have a majority in the Senate, its view is not able to prevail. The views of the Opposition and the Democrats do prevail under those circumstances. But this is not because the Bill has been incompetently drafted. It is because the Bill has been disagreed with by the Opposition in some area of principle and therefore is returned to the House of Representatives. This would occur whether or not the original Bill came through under guillotine.

The point that somehow or other this is a product of the guillotine being applied is a nonsense. It is a product of the fact that at the end of the session there is always a rush of business between the Senate and the House of Representatives to get legislation through and in those circumstances mistakes can be made. There is no process that would avoid this error and this sort of situation developing. People can unctuously moralise about it, but no government has ever avoided the problem of a rush of consideration of legislation between the Senate and the House of Representatives—at least no government at a time when it has not controlled the Senate has been able to avoid this sort of situation.

So I anticipate a certain amount of unctuous moralising from those opposite on this subject. All I say in advance is that I do not cop that unctuous moralising at all. As I do not want to prolong this debate unnecessarily, I will not spend any time rebutting those opposite, but because I do not spend any time rebutting them I do not want them for one minute to think that I concede on that point.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) anticipates that what I am about to say might be unctuous, but it will not be. I do not intend to speak for long, although I think a couple of points need to be made.

PARA.TAB: As the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) correctly pointed out, we are not of the view that the suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders ought to have taken place in any event, but we are in an extraordinary position. Clearly, standing order 241, which allows a correction of a clerical nature, was unable to be availed of in this instance because the procedures had gone too far. We had formally accepted the message and moved to accept the amendments from the Senate. So the Clerk and the Speaker acted correctly, as has subsequently been shown to be so, in refusing to send a message to the Governor-General that the particular piece of legislation had received the royal assent.

The matter has therefore gone back to the Senate, has been corrected and has come back to the House of Representatives. It seeks from us the rescission of our previous motion where we acted upon advice from the Senate in accepting its amendments, so that we rescind and then put back in a piece of legislation that is the mirror image of what has been passed in the Senate. The Bill then, having passed through the constitutional processes, can correctly go to the Governor-General to receive the royal assent.

Procedures that are followed in the Senate are a matter for the Senate. I do not want to enter into the arguments put forward by the Leader of the House that perhaps the Senate ought not to have entered into the debate of yesterday. That is a matter for the Senate. We might question whether or not we agree with those procedures, but the procedures in the Senate are a matter for the Senate.

The other point that the Leader of the House made is that this is not a debate about the guillotine. Certainly, it is not a debate about the guillotine. I have made the point in the past that as we come to the end of a session we invariably end up in the position where more and more legislation is being rushed through. Some of the errors that may have arisen here can be sheeted home to a lot of different reasons, but one of them surely has to be the nature of the rush that we engage ourselves in at the end of the session.

I take the view that it is not sufficient, as I have said in the past, just to blame the Senate for that. It really is a matter of running government business in an ordered fashion and ensuring that Ministers bring to the Parliament in a timely fashion legislation that can be dealt with in the proper method by which we would all hope that this Parliament would proceed. It is not sufficient for the Government to say, `We always have to use the guillotine'. It is in the hands of the Leader of the House and the legislative committee of the Cabinet to order the priorities of the Government in such a fashion that it does not have to rely on excuses, as it does invariably. Increasingly, the excuse is that it is all the Senate's fault because of the Macklin amendment. That is a debate we have had and we will have again, I am sure.

Finally, I come back to the substantive issue that we have to deal with. We will now move into committee; the amendments will be moved by the Government to delete the offending clauses that we accepted on the advice of the Senate; we will be agreeing to the deletion of those amendments which we previously had agreed to; and we will debate the substantive issues on which this legislation hangs—that is, a levy on employers to fund superannuation and the heavy impost of that levy. That is a debate that my colleague at the table, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), will be bringing forward; he will also relate some of the substantive matters raised by the Solicitor-General and our colleague in the Senate, Senator Alston.

We will then come out of committee, having accepted those amendments, and the legislation will mirror what has been passed in the Senate. We will then make a decision about whether we support that piece of legislation and our decision will be based on the substantive decision we made about how we will oppose the superannuation guarantee levy.

With those few remarks, I reiterate that the decision taken by you, Mr Speaker, and also by the Clerk is proved to be and was the correct constitutional position. You are to be commended for what you have done. It was a highly professional operation from this House of Parliament. We hope that will be mirrored in the other place on other occasions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take up the point that was made by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) in relation to the legality of the situation and where we now stand. We had a rather adventurous proposition being put forward by the Leader of the House that all would be well and we should all rest assured in our beds that it was nobody's fault that this had happened, that he had the answer to it and that as of the moment when this rescinding motion is passed, all of the problem could be undone and rectified.

PARA.TAB: The very interesting question is: once the record is rectified and the Bill, according to the record, has been adopted in the same form by each House and can then go to the Governor-General and receive royal assent, what effect will it be deemed to have had during the interregnum; that is, what will the status of this Bill—assuming it becomes an Act—have been between 1 July 1992 and the time when it receives royal assent?

In due course my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) will address the House on advice which has been obtained from the Solicitor-General on that question. No doubt the Leader of the House and the Government will hope that the view will be that by the time the assent is granted to the Bill the first clause of the Bill, which says that it commences on 1 July 1992, will be activated and that the Bill will be considered to have been law during the interregnum. Of course, that is a matter which most definitely can be challenged—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Higgins is now starting to pre-empt debate on the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill, and we are not going to do that. That matter is not before the House yet. He can talk about the rescission motion on the previous Bill. I know that the honourable member wants to get in front of the other speakers, and that the honourable member for Bradfield is not happy about his speech being stolen, but I will not allow the honourable member for Higgins to continue to steal the speech of the honourable member for Bradfield. He will stick to the rescission motion and to the previous Bill. He will not pre-empt debate on the Bill about to come before the House.

—Mr Speaker, of course I always take your rulings seriously and I will stick to the rescission motion introduced by the Leader of the House. The Leader of the House referred to all of these matters in his speech and, in reply, I am entitled to refer to the same matters as he did, including—

—You are not entitled to pre-empt debate on the matter that is going to come before the House in committee if this motion is passed. You can talk to the motion but not to the Bill that is going to come before the House.

—Mr Speaker, I am talking to the motion and to the Solicitor-General's advice which was referred to by the Leader of the House in his speech—a reference that you did not pick up, a reference that you did not rule out of order and a reference in relation to which you did not intervene in any way.
—The honourable member for Higgins can speak to the rescission motion but should not start to pre-empt debate on the other matter.

—I am speaking to the rectification, Mr Speaker. The point I wanted to make is that when the rectification motion goes through—assuming that it goes through—the interesting question then becomes: what has been the situation from 1 July until such time as it goes through? The Leader of the House is putting the view that the guarantee charge will be considered to have been law throughout. The point that I was putting is that that is very much a matter that will be open to legal debate and no doubt will be challenged.

PARA.TAB: There is unquestionably an argument that will be put the other way. The point that arises from this is: even if the rectification motion does have the effect that it will have made the superannuation guarantee charge law as from 1 July 1992, nobody was entitled in the interregnum to assume that. Nobody was entitled, until such time as the rectification motion was put, and nobody is entitled to assume until this rectification motion is passed, that the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill was law from 1 July 1992.

The Leader of the House adverted to that himself. He said that the Commissioner of Taxation was entitled to go out and advertise and treat this as law, assuming that one day it would be picked up. He said that this was considered to be usual procedure. Well, it is not usual procedure to advertise, and expend public moneys on advertising, something as law when it is not law. It cannot become law until such time as it is passed in identical form through the House and the Senate and has received the royal assent.

The reason that the rectification motion has been moved is that it is quite clear that that had not occurred. It is quite clear by reason of the rectification motion itself, even on the most generous assessment of the rectification motion, that once the royal assent is given—the commencement date comes into operation as from 1 July 1992—in the interregnum until today that Bill was not law and it was just untrue to be advertising on television as though it was, to be spending public moneys advertising on television as though it was and to have been informing the public that it was law.

Quite clearly it was not law and, even on the most generous assessment, could only retrospectively become law after today and after royal assent. To go around and pretend that the matter is a bit of a giggle, a bit of a laugh and a usual procedure is not only treating the Parliament with contempt—to say whether the Parliament passes this matter or not is unimportant—it is also treating its own motion with contempt. Its own motion, on the substantive provisions that it has, is an attempt to say that it is important to get it right; it is important to have the records completely in agreement; it is necessary for that to be the case before the royal assent can be given; it is necessary to have the royal assent for a Bill to become law; it is necessary to have a law for the expenditure of public funds; it is necessary that tax commissioners, like anybody else, regard themselves as being under the law; that their advertisements, which advertise to the public what the law is, are fair and accurate and not misleading; and that the expenditure of public funds occurs in relation to informing people what the law is once it has become law. That is, even on the most generous assumptions that this can be given, retrospective validity. If it cannot be, of course, that is wasted money—money that has been expended in the interim.

It would be a very bad day if we said that all of this does not matter, that all of this can be somehow brushed aside, that this is not unusual, that this is an unimportant matter, that this is somehow just a technical hiccup and that we should not let the processes of the Parliament stand in the way of what we, the Executive, have decided to do. It is no light matter whatsoever, and it is no light matter for the Leader of the House. The Leader of the House is the Leader of one House of the Parliament and is somebody who ought to take that matter absolutely seriously. He is somebody who ought to take a serious view of carrying on in society as if things are law when they are not. Even on his own admission, even in his own rectification motion, even in his own speech today it is clear in his mind that, until today at least, this has not been law and nobody should have been given the apprehension that it was. Anybody who has been given the apprehension that it was, by advertising or otherwise, would have been misled.

Public funds were going into advertisements which were telling the public what the situation was, but this motion and the speech of the Leader of the House make it quite clear that it was not law at that particular time. The rectification motion, on its most generous reading, can retrospectively validate that, but it can never change the facts that as at the time this—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments before the chamber relate to the Superannuation Guarantee Administration Bill 1992. The substance of this Bill was opposed by the Opposition when it was debated in the House some months ago, and naturally we will continue to oppose the Bill. However, for administrative reasons, which have been outlined in the House at some length already today, we have little choice but to support the proposals which have been put forward to overcome what is an unfortunate situation.

PARA.TAB: I would, however, like to take this opportunity to outline some of the difficulties we have with the procedural arrangements which have been made or, more precisely, the long term results which could flow from those arrangements and to place our views on record. Firstly, contrary to the point made by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley), the problem was to a large degree caused by the Government's fixation with guillotining legislation during the closing weeks of the autumn session which resulted in this serious administrative error occurring.

As we know, the Senate passed the Bill at 11.18 a.m. on 24 June. It was presented in the House of Representatives at 9.30 p.m., some 10 hours later. The original schedule as prepared in the Senate was said to contain 25 amendments when, in fact, there were only 21. On 25 June, the House agreed in good faith to those 25 amendments contained in the Senate schedule. The error was subsequently discovered by the Tax Office as well as by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel. The four amendments had not been originally passed by the Senate and, consequently, the form of the legislation passed by both Houses was not exactly the same.

We have already discussed the action taken by the Clerk, which we strongly support, and the action taken by the Speaker, which we strongly support, to ensure that the Governor-General was not placed in a position where he would have to pass legislation which was unsatisfactory. I feel that, in the context of the record, there are two pieces of information which should be included in Hansard. I seek leave of the Committee to have incorporated in Hansard the letter to the Speaker by the President, dated 18 August 1992, which is very relevant, and also the opinion given by Gavan Griffith, the Solicitor-General, to the Senate on this matter.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—
Message No.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker,
The Senate acquaints the House of Representatives with a statement made by the President this day, regarding the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992:

I inform the Senate that the schedule of amendments made by the Senate to the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 which was forwarded with the bill to the House of Representatives on 24 June 1992 mistakenly included four amendments which were in fact not agreed to by the Senate. The presence of these amendments in the schedule was not detected when the House of Representatives agreed to the bill as amended by the Senate later on that day, and was not detected until both Houses had risen for the winter long adjournment.

The Clerk of the Senate took the view that, as the intention of the two Houses was clear, the problem could be overcome by the correction of the erroneous documentary record and the bill could proceed to royal assent as amended by the Senate. The Government, on contrary advice, came to the conclusion that the bill could not proceed to royal assent and that it would be necessary for the error to be corrected by some action by the two Houses.

The view initially taken by the Government's advisers was that the Senate would need to correct the error by resolution, either by asking for the bill to be returned to the Senate or by formally advising the House of Representatives of the corrected schedule of amendments. Subsequently, however, the view was expressed that the problem could be overcome by my signing a substitute message forwarding a substitute schedule of amendments to the House, without any further action by the Senate. On the advice of the Clerk, I took the view that it would not be proper for me to do this, and that the Senate should be acquainted with the problem and asked to take remedial action. I took this view particularly because the proposed date of commencement of the bill, 1 July 1992, had then passed, and there is a question as to whether the bill will operate retrospectively if it is now passed or whether further amendment is required to provide that retrospective operation.
Having been acquainted with the problem, it is now for the Senate to take the appropriate action to have the bill reconsidered.
I table the reports which were made to me by the Clerk on the matter.
The Senate transmits to the House of Representatives the following Resolution which was agreed to by the Senate this day in connection with the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992:

That the President's statement and a corrected schedule of amendments to the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 agreed to by the Senate on 24 June 1992 be forwarded to the House of Representatives, and the House be requested to reconsider the bill with the corrected schedule of amendments.
President
The Senate,
Canberra, 18 August 1992
MATTER of SUPERANNUATION
GUARANTEE (ADMINISTRATION) BILL 1992
OPINION

After passage through the House of Representatives the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 ("the Bill") was amended in the Senate. Due to clerical error (in its root sense of meaning error by a clerk) the signed Schedule of Amendments ("Schedule") annexed to Message 491 24 June 1992 from the President of the Senate to the Speaker included some purported amendments which had not been passed in the Senate. The error was not exposed until after the House of Representatives had agreed to all the purported amendments in the Schedule before assent.

The President has not yet sent a message to the Speaker to correct the error of Message 491. 1 am instructed that the Clerk of the Senate has expressed a personal view that whilst the error could have been corrected administratively before 1 July without further reference to either House, rectification now requires resolution by the Senate. This is because the commencement Clause 2 reads "This Act commences on 1 July 1992", a date now passed. The suggestion is that the Bill has therefore become a Bill for retrospective legislation, and effectively a new Bill, if brought into force in the form.
I am asked—

PARA.TAB: (1) Is there any legal impediment to the President now transmitting the correct schedule to the House without reference to the Senate?
(2) May the Bill be passed by the House of Representatives with the same amendments passed by the Senate, and then presented for assent under section 58 of the Constitution?
(3) Would such enactment have effect from 1 July 1992?
(4) Was the Clerk correct in his view that the error could have been corrected administratively before 1 July?

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Chapter 20 of the Senate Standing Orders regulates the passage of Bills through the Senate. Under S.O. 131, a Bill which has originated in the House of Representatives and been passed by the Senate with amendments is returned to the House by message from the President with the amendments set out in a schedule certified by the Clerk. However, S.O. 131 prescribes only a parliamentary procedure. It does not reflect any constitutional requirement to pass a law (cf. procedures under section 57 of the Constitution in respect of the enactment of legislation at a joint sitting). The correction or non-correction of Message 491 by further message from the President will not affect the efficacy of the completed passage of the Bill through the Senate. Constitutionally it is not a necessary pre-condition to the House reconsidering the Bill amended by the Senate that the schedule of amendments passed by the Senate be correctly, or even at all, transmitted with message under S.O. 131 from the President to the Speaker. What is required is that the proposed law be passed in the same terms in each House.

2. Where, as here, a Bill originates in the House and is passed by the Senate, the courts will not ordinarily inquire whether the internal procedures of Parliament have been complied with. The High Court has expressed the view that it is for each House to determine whether a law has been passed by each House according to its procedures, and the assent is taken as indicating that the Bill has been passed by each House: see Victoria v. Commonwealth and Connor (PMA Case) (1975) 1 34 CLR 81, 181 Mason J. At 164, Gibbs J. said the courts are not concerned with enforcement of Standing Orders of the two Houses.

3. Although there must be limits to the extent to which the High Court will foreclose consideration of parliamentary processes in constitutional litigation, it is unnecessary to consider issues of judicial review in resolving this matter of parliamentary process. Obviously, each House must rely upon the other to comply with its procedures, and it cannot be a proper working of the relationship for material normally communicated by one to the other to remain uncorrected after error is detected. Message 491 should have been formally corrected by a further message from the President to the Speaker as soon as the mistake was exposed, and no authority from the Senate was required before or after 1 July. The fact that a law proclaimed in the form passed by the Senate after 1 July will contain a commencement date in incorrect tense is irrelevant.

4. Section 58 of the Constitution allows the Governor-General to assent to a proposed law only after it has been "passed by both Houses of the Parliament". The constitutional requirement is that the substantive text be passed in each House. Here different amendments have been passed. Section 58 has not been complied with. It follows that no present version of the proposed law may be presented for assent. There is no scope for a text to be finalised by administrative action to express the supposed will of the Parliament. As the proposed law has not been passed by both Houses it cannot be presented for assent, either in the form passed in the Senate or with the purported amendments agreed to by the House of Representatives.

5. The mechanism to ensure passing of the Bill in compliance with constitutional requirements is a separate issue from correction of the President's advice to the Speaker. The House of Representatives may now agree to the amendments as they were in fact passed by the Senate. It then should send a new message under its Standing Order 247 explaining that its earlier message under that Standing Order was ineffective insofar as it said that the House had agreed to the amendments that were not in fact made by the Senate and stating that it has now agreed to all the amendments made by the Senate. Then the same proposed law will have been agreed to, and so "passed" by both Houses. In that form, the Bill may be presented for assent under section 58. This can be done even if no correcting message is sent by the President of the Senate to the Speaker. No further consideration by the Senate is required. Nonetheless, as a matter of practice between the Houses, it is appropriate for the President to correct message 491 before the House of Representatives considers and agrees to the correct schedule of amendments.

6. Upon assent, the commencement date is a matter of construction: see Worrall v. Commercial Banking Co of Sydney Ltd (1917) 24 CLR 28. The infelicity in the tense of clause 2 will be explained by legislative history. For the avoidance of doubt, this intention for retrospective operation could be expounded and explained in the Minister's speech when the correct amendments are agreed on the further consideration of the Bill in the House of Representatives. In the peculiar circumstances of the passage of this law, a court should find that the Act does have retrospective operation back to the originally intended prospective date of 1 July 1992. This may, in turn, give rise to some other arguments as to whether the purported retrospective operation of the Act back to 1 July is valid, but those arguments could arise even if Clause 2 was amended directly to provide for retrospective operation.
Accordingly, the questions are answered as follows—
1. No. The mistake in message number 491 should have been corrected as soon as it was detected.
2. Yes.
3. The Act should be held to have effect from 1 July 1992.
4. No.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will briefly take the time of the House to refer to a number of points. Firstly, in the letter to the Speaker by the President, which was not read, he noted:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, on contrary advice, came to the conclusion that the bill could not proceed to royal assent and that it would be necessary for the error to be corrected by some action by the two Houses.

We have now gone through the process of subsequent actions. I think it also worth pointing out that the Government was facing a political dilemma. It faced the very real risk that had the Senate, in which it does not have a parliamentary majority, sought to make additional amendments, or sought to change the content of the legislation, the entire superannuation exercise would have unwound. The Leader of the House has made the point that senators on both sides showed remarkable commonsense in this particular matter; nevertheless, it did demonstrate that there was a political problem of some consequence. The President also said in his letter, and I think this point is quite important:

. . . there is a question as to whether the bill will operate retrospectively if it is now passed or whether further amendment is required to provide that retrospective operation. Having been acquainted with the problem, it is now for the Senate to take the appropriate action to have the bill reconsidered.
In that context the comments made by the Solicitor-General, Dr Gavan Griffith, are particularly pertinent. The opinion asked of him fits into four basic questions. He was asked:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is there any legal impediment to the President now transmitting the correct schedule to the House without reference to the Senate?
(2) May the Bill be passed by the House of Representatives with the same amendments passed by the Senate, and then presented for assent under section 58 of the Constitution?
(3) Would such enactment have effect from 1 July 1992?
(4) Was the Clerk correct in his view that the error could have been corrected administratively before 1 July?

SPEECH.PARA: The only question to which I wish to refer in some detail is: would such enactment have effect from 1 July 1992?

PARA.TAB: On the final page of his opinion, Dr Gavan Griffith referred specifically to the case of Worrall v. Commercial Banking Co. of Sydney Ltd, which was a 1917 case before the High Court. He stated—and this is the important point:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this intention for retrospective operation could be expounded and explained in the Minister's speech when the correct amendments are agreed on the further consideration of the Bill in the House of Representatives. In the peculiar circumstances of the passage of this law, a court should find that the Act does have retrospective operation back to the originally intended prospective date of 1 July 1992.
But he also went on to say:

This may, in turn, give rise to some other arguments as to whether the purported retrospective operation of the Act back to 1 July is valid, but those arguments could arise even if Clause 2 was amended directly to provide for retrospective operation.

So the points we are raising in this context are as follows: firstly, there was no royal assent; secondly, as has already been pointed out, the Tax Office, essentially as it appears of its own volition but possibly at the request of the Government, put out a press release advising employers that, irrespective of the finding of this problem which brought into question the legality of this legislation, they should have no doubt that they have the responsibility to pay their commitments, under a law which did not exist in legal terms, from 1 July.

PARA.TAB: As my colleague Senator Alston pointed out in the debate on this matter yesterday, the matter is important because `a Bill is presumed to have prospective operation only' if, as pointed out by Gavan Griffith, the Minister specifically in his second reading speech has drawn attention to the fact that the Bill has retrospective operation. Naturally that was not done, because at the time of the Minister's second reading speech it was presumed that this matter would be effectively legal. Senator Alston also stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the normal course of events is to clearly and unequivocally prescribe the intention that a Bill has a retrospective effect.

We have now gone through the procedures. We are sorting out this unfortunate mess. But Senator Alston took the opportunity to raise a number of matters in relation to the substantive motion which he put to the Senate. I am not moving a motion in similar terms because there are no procedures by which I can do so. The four points he made yesterday are relevant and should be on the record. Senator Alston's motion in the Senate stated:

(a)condemns the Government for its unnecessary and indecent haste in rushing through the Parliament important legislation, which adversely affects the lives of millions of Australians, without allowing time for full and proper debate;
(b) condemns the Government for its failure to follow the proper processes in seeking to achieve retrospective operation of the legislation;

(c) records its unequivocal opposition to the Government's compulsory superannuation regime which will severely punish ordinary Australian workers by requiring them to forgo wage increases and rising living standards in order to disqualify themselves from the age pension; and

(d) condemns the Government for embarking on a very expensive and highly misleading advertising campaign which pretends that the legislation is already in force, wrongly implies that employers are expected to bear the cost of compulsory superannuation and paints a very false and inflated picture of the amounts which are likely to be available to workers upon retirement.

Those points are important, especially (d). The Government deliberately set out to present a false impression of the benefits of its superannuation proposals and to present a very false impression that what was being asked of employers was appropriate in terms of the legislation which was technically illegal.

PARA.TAB: As I said in my opening remarks, from day one we have in this place and in the Senate strenuously continued to argue that the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill is fundamentally based on a false premise, that it is not in the interests of the Australian people, especially at this time, and that effectively the Government is bringing into place a regime which is estimated to cost—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to make a few remarks and to add to what the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) has said. I do so in the context of the small business community, which I feel constitutes the main business base in my electorate. I do not want this opportunity to pass without again making very clearly the point that the superannuation guarantee levy has been a disaster right from the start. Today's episode, which has gone on for one hour now—much, I imagine, to the Government's embarrassment—to correct its mistakes and inadequacies merely compounds the error. In my view, what we have seen this morning, even by this Government's standards, is monumentally unsatisfactory.

PARA.TAB: Much has been said about that and about the lack of proper consideration of this matter. This, unfortunately, is typical of the way this Government has handled important legislation. The fact that this particular legislation was rammed through this Parliament without adequate consideration means that things are not done properly and, more importantly, that members in this place are not given the opportunity to represent their constituents properly.

As the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) perhaps quite weakly said, the Senate is different; there is a mixture of parties there. But why is it that these things are given proper and detailed consideration in the Senate, when this is the House of the people? This is the place where these matters should be debated properly and fully. If that were to happen, we would not be relying on the Senate to do that work for us.

Much has been said about the importance of retirement incomes. There is no difference in views on both sides of this place. It is important that people are encouraged to provide for their retirement. I think that argument is well made and well understood. But in this case, the end does not justify the means. The point we have made consistently here is: while we agree that people must be encouraged to provide for their retirement, we do not support the compulsion; we do not support the imposition on employers. This end is not justified by this means. The superannuation guarantee levy is a tax on business at a time when business cannot afford it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lost jobs.

—It translates, as the honourable member for Maranoa says, into lost jobs. The irony is that last night we had a Budget which was about creating jobs. We will not debate whether it is going to do that today, Mr Deputy Chairman. But the irony is that this morning we should be dealing with the superannuation guarantee levy, the effect of which will cause tens of thousands of more people to go on to the unemployment queue.

PARA.TAB: Whether it is 10,000, 20,000, 30,000, 40,00 or even 100,000 people, it is crazy for this particular imposition to be placed on businesses at this time. It is like many things which this Government has done, wrongly and incorrectly in our view, and which contrast remarkably well with the approach that we would take to encourage people to provide for their retirement.

Since this became law in a Clayton's sense, I have had in my office many examples of unintended consequences. How many times in the term of this Government have we been faced with so-called unintended consequences, where things that are not properly thought through, not properly planned and not properly executed have led to consequences which are unfortunate? I have had people from small businesses phoning me saying that they do not know what to do with the levy; they cannot find an insurance company that wants to deal with them; their business is too small. There are numerous anomalies. People are phoning and saying, `What do we do?'. The hot line the Government set up has been virtually jammed with inquiries from employers who are simply confused about what the whole thing is all about, and it is easy to understand why they would be confused.

Finally, the role of the ACTU in this matter is, once again, disgraceful. It has dictated the terms of this whole saga. It has only been a matter of the ACTU Secretary or President saying to the Government, `Jump' and the Government's response of course has been, `How high?'. I do not want to take up too much time here because ultimately there is probably no point other than that I feel that I am doing my job as an elected representative in saying this again. The fact is that superannuation guarantee contributions will be fully preserved from 1 July 1993 but other contributions will not be required to be preserved until 1 July 1998. The Government has refused to accept the principle of competition between other financial institutions in this particular area because the ACTU does not want that competition; the ACTU does not want competition from outside with its so-called sponsored funds.

Despite our pleadings with the Government, the system still retains reasonable benefit limits complexities. We have pointed out that compulsory superannuation ultimately means reliance on the lowest common denominator. The Government has failed to address the issue of the preservation age. It acknowledges, and its own Ministers have acknowledged, the need for that preservation age to be increased to 60, and yet it has taken a Clayton's decision and has put it on the never never; it is going to look at it in the year 2025. Meanwhile, the system continues to haemorrhage as people are encouraged to double dip, and the amount of the haemorrhage could be as much as $1.5 billion per year.

I object most strongly to this approach. That is why I have taken this opportunity in committee this morning—I could not let it pass—to speak on behalf of the many small businesses that I represent, and tourist operators, who are small businesses, who cannot afford the compulsory superannuation system. They cannot afford the level of taxes that are being imposed on them. I am proud to represent a party that has policies that will reduce tax for small business. The centrepiece of our approach to this small business policy is to get government off the back of small business and to reduce tax. I take the opportunity again this morning to say that I deplore the approach that has been taken on this matter by the Government. The whole sorry saga that we have seen repeated here this morning has convinced me more than ever that this approach to helping people provide for their retirement is entirely wrong and entirely misguided. I am pleased that the Opposition's policy is to discontinue it when we are elected at the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will continue where I left off in my opening remarks. The point we are trying to get across quite clearly is that we have reached a stage where, to use a rather simplistic notion, one person's superannuation is another person's job. The evidence is quite clear.

PARA.TAB: Before the Senate made certain amendments it was estimated that the cost of superannuation in terms of job loss would be approximately 100,000. It was subsequently revised down—depending on whom one wants to believe—to around 80,000. But the fact of the matter is that at this stage in the job cycle or, more correctly, in the gross unemployment cycle, any action which a government takes which deliberately and directly contributes to greater unemployment must be opposed by any self-respecting Opposition. It is not good enough to talk about a million people unemployed when we all know that that does not take account of the high level of underemployment estimated at another half a million people. It does not take account of the hundreds of thousands of people who have dropped out of the system because they simply believe there is no purpose in applying for work or being registered as unemployed. In other words, the estimate that we have of 11 per cent unemployment is at best optimistic and at worst a gross distortion of the sad reality brought upon this country by this Government.

It is for that reason that we are emphasising in this debate that, in our opinion, employers do not carry with them a legal liability to pay superannuation up until the passage of this Bill through the House and subsequently its signature by the Governor-General. In other words, the current arrangements are illegal. They have been illegal ever since the original passage of the Bill on 25 June. Yet, as I said earlier, that did not hold back the Tax Office from putting out press releases and demanding that people make their payments. If the Government is taken to the courts by the CAI or any other employer body, it may well face the interesting question as to what the basis of that legislation was at that time and whether it was, in fact, retrospective. As I have stated, in quoting from Dr Gavan Griffith, there is certainly some doubt on that point.

Because of that, we are strongly urging the Government to give an assurance in the House today that it will not proceed to seek royal assent until it has obtained a further independent legal opinion, putting a further legal challenge beyond all reasonable doubt. Anything less than that is to leave this Parliament still in limbo, not knowing whether the retrospective elements in the original Bill, or as they could be interpreted in the court, are justifiable.

As I was saying in my earlier remarks, the superannuation issue before the Committee falls into a number of very fundamentally important questions. Firstly, there is the effect of the 80,000 to 100,000 people who will not be employed or whose current positions may well be lost. We should take account of the fact that, in recent months, we have seen a raft of legislation passed through this Parliament which has significantly increased the oncosts of employing labour. I recall that a few years ago we used to say it was 25 per cent; in other words, 100 per cent for wages plus 25 per cent for oncosts. That was an average which was applied across the economy. If we speak to employers today, essentially as a result of the introduction of a range of provisions in legislation, we find that that oncost is no less than 35 per cent and, in some cases, as high as 50 per cent. And we wonder why people are not creating job opportunities for their fellow Australians. It is very simple—they cannot afford to.

Surely, therefore, it is beholden upon this Parliament to make absolutely certain that every piece of legislation we pass has to go through the fundamental question or criterion of answering the issue: does it create new jobs or does it militate against the creation of new jobs? By any test at all, this legislation does nothing to increase employment opportunities for Australians.

There are other issues of relevance too. The proposals contained in this legislation effectively ignore the significant role of part time and casual employees in the Australian economic system. There are about 1 1/2 million people in that category, 75 per cent of whom are women. We have heard the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—the Prime Minister was on AM again this morning—telling us how there has been a significant growth in the proportion of the population available for work and how this growth is much greater now than it was, say, in 1982. The Prime Minister totally ignores the fact that there has been a growth in the number of people available for work because they are living in a social and economic system where no family can survive today on average weekly earnings, or anywhere near approaching that, unless both the husband and the wife are actively involved in the work force. As I said, 75 per cent of women are in part time work or in casual employment. What does this legislation hold out for them for superannuation? What does it give to these people in their so-called financial independence in retirement?

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing

—As my colleague says, nothing; absolutely nothing. But we have a government which is full of compassion and concern! We had a caring Budget last night, so we were told. The sad fact is that those hundreds of thousands of women in the work force expect and receive nothing from this Government in terms of superannuation reform. That is exactly the opposite of what the Opposition's superannuation policy is all about.

PARA.TAB: We have specifically identified the need to have an equitable system irrespective of income and the need to have a system in which all Australians—whether they be in or out of the work force, whether they be permanent or part time or casual employees—have the opportunity to access superannuation and the 25 per cent tax rebate on their contributions; that they have the opportunity to save for their long term retirement and have the opportunity through their savings to create work for other people and wealth for this nation.

Those are the principles which must outline a sensible, decent, equitable superannuation policy. Regrettably, these are the principles which have been ignored for so long by this Government in its headlong desire to give its ACTU mates access to the savings of the Australian people in a most inequitable way. In the last 10 years this has effectively contributed to making the rich much richer than ever before and making the vast majority of the men and women who have worked to build this nation significantly worse off in real income terms than they have ever been before.

This superannuation legislation is fundamentally flawed. It is not fit to be passed by this Parliament. As I said in the House last June, the Opposition will continue to vigorously oppose it in this House.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —One cannot escape from the fact that this reform means a decent retirement for virtually all Australians. If the Opposition wants to run in the next election on threatening to remove this essential protection for decent retirement from the vast bulk of the Australian work force and extending to them a privilege which the Liberal Party was pleased to keep ensconced firmly in the hands of only those who have been in government service or those who are wealthy in business, so be it. That is the policy that those opposite will pursue.

PARA.TAB: One of the useful things as an election approaches—and it does not matter particularly about this election; it applies to any election—is that gradually the Opposition's policies, as opposed to simply the Government's, come into focus. It is terribly important that in this area the Opposition's policy does exactly that—comes into focus. In this area, as in education and employment policies generally, the Opposition's policy offers to the ordinary Australian not only no progress but also regression.

It is terribly difficult to get in place in a country such as Australia something like superannuation, which is absolutely necessary and vital to any decent retirement policy. We had opportunities back in the 1920s and 1930s when various governments put forward national superannuation schemes. Indeed one was put forward by Mr Menzies, I think, and apparently it had the backing of the Opposition at that time. It fell between the cracks after the subsequent general election, despite the fact that it had bipartisan support. Had legislation been passed then, no doubt this is a debate we would not be having now. We would probably have superannuation organised on the most effective basis possible.

Superannuation has grown like Topsy since that time, but it has not grown in a fashion which the ordinary Australian can address unless the ordinary Australian happens to be a public servant.
