—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Support and Minister for Local Government. I ask the Minister: what are the Government's objectives for the local government capital works program announced last night, and on what basis were areas selected for government funds?
—Order! The House will come to order. There is far too much noise.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Simmons The Hon D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Oxley for his question on the local government capital works program that was announced last night in the Treasurer's Budget Speech. This is a very important program that will help to boost employment and economic activity in a lot of those areas in Australia currently facing difficult employment prospects.

PARA.TAB: The program is going to be administered by the Office of Local Government in cooperation with the State and Territory local government associations. As honourable members would be aware, last night's Budget allocated $345m over a two-year period for the program. Interestingly, this program is very cleverly targeted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—Order! The honourable member for McEwen and the honourable member for Maranoa will cease interjecting.
—I warn the honourable member for McEwen.

—The claim has been made, since I suggested that the program has been cleverly targeted, that it is targeted towards government seats. I remind honourable members that the marginal seat of Flinders, for example, which is held by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, is going to attract $5.4m worth of funding. We are also quite happy to accept the funds from Wentworth, the marginal seat of the Leader of the Opposition, that has $2.234m worth of funding. I am quite happy to write to councils in the electorates of any honourable member who interjects that she or he does not want the funds to see what they think of it, because I can tell you, Mr Speaker—
—Order! The honourable member for Corinella will cease interjecting.

—that this program is very strongly welcomed and endorsed by the Australian Local Government Association. Indeed, local government has been calling for this program for a number of months. ANSWER.PARA: National Vision with Local Direction is the central theme in the Budget.

—I can assure the honourable Leader of the National Party that I do take account of the existing Standing Orders and ensure that there is fair play. The Standing Orders have a lot to say about what questions are. They do not have much to say about what answers are. Oppositions of all political calibre complain about the Standing Orders. PARA.TAB: The current Standing Orders—as the honourable member for Higgins is only new here he might not know but his colleague sitting next to him, the honourable member for Mackellar, was a Minister in the former Government and he knows—in the main were designed by the coalition when they were in government. So what may have been good then may not be good now, according to the coalition. But that is not a matter for me to adjudicate on. I have the Standing Orders and I apply them as they are. If the House wishes to change them that is a matter for the House.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The failure of the Budget to provide a plan for Australia's economic recovery.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition raises this matter of public importance today to debate and to analyse the Budget which was brought down by the Government last night. It is a very disappointing Budget and the criticisms of the Budget which we see in this morning's press sum up very well the disappointment that so many people would feel in it. As the public look to the Government to provide some answers to the recession that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) engineered, they would find very little in this Budget that would give them any sense of cheer for the future.

PARA.TAB: I will quote a few of the headlines: the Telegraph-Mirror describes the Budget as `Labor's $1b job gamble'; the Age states, `Dawkins gambles on jobs; a gamble again'; and the theme in the Sydney Morning Herald is `Keating's gamble'. I must say that there is not a bad cartoon next to it which picks up the political direction of this Budget. It has a shot of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) sitting at a table. He is speaking into a microphone saying that this Budget is all about jobs, jobs and jobs. Then there is a second shot of the same Mr Dawkins, at the same table, with the same microphone and he is saying, `Paul's job. This Budget is about Paul's job, it is about John's job, it is about Kim's job'. Unfortunately, that is true.

This Budget is not about real jobs. This Budget is about jobs for members of the Labor Party—the Labor politicians who want to see themselves re-elected at the next election. This Budget shows us that the Labor politicians are prepared to do and say anything to save their own political hides as we go into the next election.

So it is a very disappointing Budget because the Government had an opportunity to use it as a platform for some major changes which would really give people a chance of hope, but it has simply gone for its own political benefit. It is a disappointment that this is the best the Government could do after 10 years with nearly one million people unemployed and the worst recession for 60 years.

This Budget is not, I must say, the Government's first attempt. Over the last 12 months we have had five major economic statements. Every one of them starts with the prospect of jobs, finishes with the prospect of jobs and ends up delivering nothing; nothing but spending money the Government does not have to convince people that it is trying to do something. If one looks at the jobs proposals in this vote-buying Budget, one finds that the extent to which the Government has gone on a spending spree to satisfy the public that it is doing something is quite extraordinary.

When we take out the numbers, we see that the Government is spending $3 billion or $3 1/2 billion to achieve a one per cent reduction in the unemployment rate from 11 per cent to 10 per cent. Many of those so-called jobs are simply hiding people by transferring them from the unemployment queues to some training program. In some cases they might be painting white rocks for a council somewhere out the back of Woop Woop, but there are no real jobs. Any other jobs that are there will be temporary jobs only. The whole thing is an illusion on jobs.

It is interesting that, in the Government's own forecast, it is effectively forced to admit that the impact on jobs over the next 12 months, through to June 1993, is minimal. It misses an opportunity to do something decent for jobs; it spends money simply as a very poor substitute. In respect of the Government's capacity to fund this Budget, we again see a massive blow-out in the Federal Budget deficit. It is $6 billion more than last year's deficit. The Government's spending in the Budget has gone up from about $102 billion to $111 billion.

Over the five-year plan of the One Nation statement, we see a massive gaping hole in the finances of the Commonwealth Government. A figure of about 50 billion is the extent to which the Government will be short of a dollar through to 1995-96. Two of the promises the Government made only six months ago have literally evaporated—they have gone up in smoke. The proposition that the Government could return the Budget to a surplus in 1995-96 is not going to happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the Treasurer?

—I thank the Leader of the Opposition. Where is the Treasurer? The Treasurer ought to be here for this debate. Is he so ashamed of his own Budget that he is not prepared to front up to answer the questions which we raise in this matter of public importance? It is a disgrace that he is not here.
—We get the cover and not the contents.

—We get the cover and not the contents. We have two big promises, made just six months ago, literally evaporating. One was, `We're a bit short of dollars in the recession, but we'll fix things up by 1995-96 and we'll be back to surplus'. That one has gone. The best Government members can say now is, `We'll try to lower the deficit. If we don't get it down to about one per cent in 1995-96, we'll increase taxes'.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, Government members maintain their promises about personal income tax cuts, but they reveal that, if ever they were to provide those personal income tax cuts, they would fund them with a tax increase. It is quite extraordinary. That whole One Nation statement they brought down in February was in response to Fightback—a fully-funded package which gave this country a sense of hope, a direction and a plan for the future. In February, the Government pulled a political response out of the hat. It cooked the books. Even Bob Hawke said in Perth today that obviously it had cooked the books.

It is now obvious that the Government cannot deliver. The tax cuts have gone. What does the Government do? It is forced into admitting that behind a return of a Federal Labor government there would be a massive tax increase. It is not $2 billion to $3 billion, which is the admission that we have extracted from the Treasurer in the last 24 hours, that it is after. The Government is looking for a lot more than that. It has a funding hole of about $50 billion.

I will tell the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly), who is at the table, what the Government is going to do, because it probably has not told her what its plans are. I will tell her now that inside the cover there is a GST, a goods and services tax—a consumption tax. Does the Minister know why?
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We finally welcome the Treasurer.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—I suggest that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition get to the substance of the matter before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will do a deal with you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will get to the substance of the issue—
—Order! The Deputy Leader does not do deals with the Chair. Just get on with it.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, if you require the Treasurer to get to the substance and the details of his tax increases when he stands to speak. That is the nub of this Budget: the Government does not have the money to pay for this. It is putting it all on Bankcard. If it is re-elected, it has a secret tax which is not just the goods and services tax. The Treasurer has had his Treasury officers up night after night working on the details of extending the fringe benefits tax to benevolent institutions, the St Vincent de Paul Society, the Sydney City Mission, religious organisations—
—Public hospitals.

—Public hospitals, right across the board—local government. He was not prepared today in Question Time to give people an assurance that there would not be a tax increase. And it claims to be a party of compassion! Yet the Government is going to slug all those pensioners and self-funded retirees who live off the interest on their savings with a new secret tax that will wipe out half the interest earned and will require them to fill in a tax return form to get it back, thus losing the cash benefit advantage of it.

PARA.TAB: We have a Budget which is artificially reducing jobs, not creating real jobs. We have a deficit that has blown out massively, and a government that is putting it all on the tick, on the plastic. One of the very interesting tables in the Federal Budget, when one goes through the fine detail, is one relating to contributions to real growth. It shows where the Government will be spending a lot more money in the years ahead. Guess where this money will be spent? It will go on the interest bill on the money it is borrowing—an extra $1.1 billion this year, which is an extra 26 per cent, and an extra $1.6 billion the year after, which is an extra 33 per cent. It is a massive explosion in the interest bill of the Commonwealth to meet the massive build-up in debt which the Government is using to fund this Budget.

This Government artificially reduces employment, blows away any semblance of fiscal responsibility it might ever have, and then mounts an attack on us by saying, `Members of the Opposition are ideologues, zealots, right wing, hard people who have no compassion'. I say to the Treasurer, `That is pretty rich coming from those people who made a million people unemployed'. The Treasurer boasted about his economic policy prowess and his capacity to run this economy. Yet we have the worst recession for 60 years. In this last Budget he did not have the decency to at least give people a plan and a fundamental set of reforms that would turn this economy around.

The Treasurer talks about compassion and attacks our proposals which he once advocated. He talks about jobs. If he looks at our Fightback package he will see a plan that will create jobs basically from day one. His Party used to be in favour of the abolition of payroll tax because he said that that would create up to 200,000 new jobs. Why did he not do it? Why did he not have the guts finally to do the right thing?

What about all of the young people? Why is he not prepared, if he really claims to have some compassion, to change the system so that those people, instead of being couch potatoes, sitting at home watching the midday movie, can at least get a job and the experience that goes with that, the dignity that goes with that and the chance to get their feet on the ladder of success in an employment sense?

What about older unemployed people who have been long term unemployed? If the Treasurer was really compassionate, he would have announced last night in his Budget a change to the industrial relations system to allow them to work in the manner outlined in our Austrain scheme. Again, this would give those people the chance of a real job. Instead, what do we get? He is just interested in saving his own bacon.

If we had delivered the Budget last night, it would have been directed to the fundamental problems of Australia. And there it is in its hefty detail—Fightback. We will implement a Fightback Budget upon our early return to government.

This country should have seen—and if we had been in government would have seen—a detailed strategy to address Australia's problems. Yes, we would have abolished payroll tax. Yes, we would have abolished other consumption taxes. We would have abolished the tax on exports. In fact, one of the vulnerabilities in the Government's Budget is the current account deficit forecast. I think $15 billion is a bit on the low side; $17 billion is more likely.

It is always worth looking at that statement in the Budget in which Treasury has had a say, because it always puts the qualification in. It can be found if one looks hard enough. Where was it? The qualification was that there is a downside risk to the Government's forecast, depending on the likely course of the overseas economies, particularly the Japanese. In fact, the Treasurer in his Budget Speech refers to the importance of the Japanese economy to Australia for exports.

If we had delivered a Budget we would have gone much further on assets sales. The headline deficient figure would have been much lower—down to $6 billion or $7 billion. That would have been very beneficial for interest rates. In fact, lowering interest rates across the board would have been part and parcel of lowering costs in the business community. In this Budget there is virtually nothing for the business community, except the prospect of higher taxes—and in fact there are some higher taxes in it.

In this country we need to develop an export strategy; a strategy to promote investment. We need a national savings strategy. We need, and should have had, a strategy to stabilise and reduce foreign debt. We ought to have seen in the Budget last night a policy to establish a new wages system where wage increases are tied to productivity. There ought to have been a major reform of the tax system, and, of course, the detailed development of an anti-inflation strategy.

This Budget is the last Budget from this Government after a decade of mismanagement. It comes at a time when, instead of looking to the national interest and instead of producing a Budget that would hold out some hope of real jobs, this Government has gone on a vote-buying spending spree with money it does not have in order to look after its own political interests. I think the Treasurer will be damned by this. He will be damned for failing to take the opportunity to at last give this country a sense of hope. There is hope for this country; Australia is a good place. We have good potential if we are prepared to make the big decisions. Those big decisions await the return of a coalition government and the implementation of our alternative Budget: the Fightback Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the House for not having been here for the first 10 minutes of the speech by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) but I have a suspicion that I have heard it all before. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is a kind of tax fetishist; he has a total fetish for the tax system. Indeed, it was not until the last three minutes of his speech that he actually got off the subject of tax and onto something else. The trouble with the Opposition is that it believes it can transform and improve Australia simply by dealing with the tax system; that if it switches $40 billion worth of expenditure—nearly half the Commonwealth Budget—somehow things will happen miraculously to make this a better place.

PARA.TAB: In the last minute of his speech, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition finally got around to saying something positive about Australia. In speech after speech we have heard the Deputy Leader and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) simply harp on about all the perceived shortcomings of this nation. In speech after speech we hear Liberal Party and National Party of Australia politicians trying to run this country into the ground. As if this were not bad enough, they go to the point of undermining confidence in the currency by giving gratuitous advice to the money market and the foreign exchange market in a way which is calculated to extend or exaggerate volatility on those markets when it occurs.

This action is entirely unbecoming to two people who purport to want to lead this nation. One does not lead this nation or offer advice to it by running it down; by constantly telling Australian workers how hopeless they are; by constantly telling Australian business how hopeless it is; or by constantly telling interest groups how they have only their own interests at heart, have no concept of a national interest and are not interested in participating in the development of a national interest.

Those opposite are entirely anti-Australian. Whilst they can wave their flags around—as they do constantly—that is just to cover up the fact that they have a basic insecurity and lack of confidence in this place and the people who work in it. They think they can cover up all of this by giving us this smokescreen in the form of a tax change which will in fact be counterproductive in trying to address Australia's problems.

It will be a total distraction right at a time when we are beginning to see the sorts of sensible changes, the helpful changes, which are coming about in the Australian economy. So I am not going to spend my time dwelling on tax issues. I am certainly not going to spend my time responding to the calculated scare tactics of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. However, I will talk on the question which he has put before the House and which he has quite deliberately avoided in that context.

The plan that we have is a plan for today and it is a plan for tomorrow. In relation to today, what we have said is that we will attack the question of unemployment at its roots, in the local communities where the despair is deepest. Those communities are hurting most. For this we have been roundly abused by the Opposition on the basis that this is somehow just a vote-buying exercise. How could it possibly be a vote-buying exercise when we are responding to the anguished cries of people in those communities, some of whose members have been thrown out of work for the first time in their lives? We are trying to respond, not only by providing jobs for them in a sensible way, but also by trying to improve the amenity of the communities in which they live.

Of course, that is only one feature. A wealth of additional programs designed to improve people's opportunities of getting back into work, by providing training opportunities for something like 430,000, are available. That is, nearly half of the unemployed can get access to a training place in the course of this year. Some of those training places involve work as well—work experience and real work. All the Deputy Leader of the Opposition can do is disparage this and say, `Why didn't you take up the Austrain idea?'. The people of Australia ought to understand that Austrain is about legalised slavery.

What the Opposition wants to do is compel the unemployed to take a cut in their wages of 20 or 30 per cent in order to get into some make-work scheme which would be provided in some way or other. They would be denied benefits, which would force them into this position of legalised slavery where they would actually have to take a cut of 20 to 30 per cent below the award rates in order to get work. There is no consideration of how many ordinary workers might be displaced as a result of this exercise, or how many people honestly going about their normal work might not be kicked out in order to make way for these `Aus-slave' victims who are forced upon various employers by this particular scheme.

Again we have the Deputy Leader of the Opposition abusing the unemployed, referring to them as couch potatoes, an expression which he picked up from his Leader. This is very reminiscent of the time when various Ministers for employment in the Fraser Government used to wander around this country referring to dole bludgers. There is no difference between a dole bludger and a couch potato in the Liberal Party's lexicon of abuse of the unemployed. It is just another way of blaming the victims for the problems that exist and for the circumstances in which they find themselves.

To make matters worse, in the dying moments of his speech the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said that what this Budget should really have been about was a deficit of $6 billion or $7 billion below what it was. In other words, not only does he eschew the idea that the Government ought to take action to provide a stimulus to a sluggishly growing economy, in order to spur a bit more life into it, in order to create a few more jobs this year and next, but also he believes we should withdraw billions from the economy and actually slow it down from the position it is now in and, of course, as a consequence take more jobs out of the economy. This is the breathtaking gall of honourable members opposite, that they will stand up here and actually confess to a policy which is about turning the economy back into recession, turning the economy down, and unemployment up. That is their view of what should have been an appropriate Budget for this year.

But of course our Budget was not only about the circumstances of today; it was about what we should do in preparing ourselves for a better tomorrow as well. If we look through the papers which were presented as part of the Budget, we find that there are pages and pages about the Government's plans—continuing plans. We did not have to dust off new tax schemes in order to explain where the country was moving in terms of becoming more internationally oriented and more capable of competing with the rest of the world.

If honourable members look at Budget Paper No. 1, Budget Statement No. 2, part II, the section `Sustaining Growth', they will see that it goes from page 2.34 all the way up to page 2.64, so there are 30 pages of small print discussion about what we need to do in the future in order to get this country into a position where it can have sustainable growth. What this Government is about is growth: growth sufficient to provide jobs for this country—not just now, but in the future as well. We do not baulk from the challenges we confront as we try to create that high level of growth.

We have shrugged off the eighties, with which Opposition members seem to be totally mesmerised. They want to revisit the excesses of the eighties, take their lead from those cowboys who wandered around Australia and elsewhere making money out of nothing and then leaving thousands of shareholders bereft as a result. It is the eighties which provide the inspiration for the Leader of the Opposition and those who follow him. We are looking at the nineties. We want to stand shoulder to shoulder with people like Prescott, Warburton and Johnston, who are doing decent things in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Connell, what about Bondy?

—What do they get from the Leader of the Opposition? Nothing but rounds of abuse. People like Prescott, Warburton, Johnston and Nasser are the targets of the sharp tongue of the Leader of the Opposition; he abuses them for what they say about what they want to do in the future. We are happy to stand with them because they are people of substance, people who are running successful businesses in this country and people who know what it is like to get out there and compete with the world. What would the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), some failed suburban solicitor, know? What would the Leader of the Opposition, who has never had a proper job—he has been an academic and a merchant banker, very good at shuffling money around—know? When has he ever made anything decent for this country? Never. He just abuses those who make the steel, the motor cars, the fibres and the other things in Australia which actually make money for Australia.

PARA.TAB: I am sick and tired of these people who come in here abusing and denigrating decent Australians when all they can say is, `All we need is a new tax and everything will be fixed'. What this paper and the companion paper, Working for the Future, reveal is a sensible and coherent plan for the future. It does not centre on some mad program to rejig $40 billion worth of the Government's revenue. What it does do is deal with the real problems confronting Australia and how we can on the basis of skills, imagination, ideas and innovation bring about the changes which will allow this country to grow faster and produce the kinds of jobs that are based on the ability of this country to compete with the rest of the world.

When do we hear anything of that nature from the Opposition, except in the context of wanting to inspire industrial relations chaos around the country as it congratulates the people of Burnie for bringing on an entirely unnecessary industrial dispute in that part of Tasmania. Robe River is another of the Opposition's champions who again brought on an entirely unnecessary industrial dispute when, of course, Hamersley did exactly the same thing but without the chaos. All the Opposition wants is to see chaos and a bit of blood on the floor in order to demonstrate that something has happened, whereas underneath things are happening.

The Liberal Party in office was content to live with a country whose export earnings amounted to only about 15 per cent of its GDP. It was totally left behind from the huge expansion in world trade which happened postwar. Under us we have seen exports and imports grow to the point where they total about 22 per cent of gross domestic product. Exports are up and imports are up, because we are becoming an international trading nation. There is nothing wrong with having higher imports if they are balanced off with higher exports. What we have done is expose more of this economy to the international sector and we are determined to succeed in the international sector. That is the guts of the plan that we have. But it does not end there.

We go on to talk about the labour market. It is just a joke for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to say that we had nothing to say about the labour market. What we are saying is something quite revolutionary in this country, something which is not going to have workers and managers at each other's throats, which is what those opposite want to see. We have something which is about getting employers and employees working together, finding ways of doing things better, so that workers can have higher rates of pay commensurate with their higher skills and higher productivity.

TALK.START.PARA: —What, like New Zealand?

—Yes, New Zealand! What the Deputy Leader of the Opposition wants is wage cuts. Never forget that at the heart of the Opposition's plans are wage cuts and tax increases and that will be thumped into the political debate day after day after day and those opposite will squirm every time they hear it because they are about wage cuts and tax hikes. That is what their policy is about, because they have not got the sense to realise that Australia can have a high wage rate if we balance that with increased productivity.

PARA.TAB: We cannot get increased productivity by taxing the corn flakes. The way to get increased productivity is by ensuring that Australian working men and women in their places of work contribute to the way in which things can be done better, processes can be improved and productivity upgraded as a consequence. Those are the kinds of things which we are doing to make this country better able to compete in the future, become the kind of successful trading nation that we have been, but extending our success away from mining and agriculture, with which the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) seems to be totally obsessed. He believes there is no future for Australian manufacturing when we believe it has a great future ahead of it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —After that amazing response from the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), I remind him that the one thing he will be remembered for in his Government is the lost decade of opportunity in Australia. We need to analyse what has happened to the Budget. When we look at capital spending we see that we can expect a slump of 2 per cent in the year-on-year figures for 1992-93.

PARA.TAB: In the Budget Speech the Treasurer made only passing reference to business, and no reference whatsoever to small business. The Government has completely missed the point. In this Budget it has thrown money at a problem without fixing the real difficulties, without giving the opportunity to create real jobs.

But perhaps we should go further and look at what industry has said about the Treasurer's speech. A press release from the President of the Chamber of Manufactures in New South Wales said that the Budget had failed manufacturing—the very area that the Treasurer tried to claim the Budget's success in, the manufacturers claimed its failure on. The Chamber went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: To attract investment and create sustainable jobs the Government must immediately:
*restructure the tax mix to reduce costs on exports and jobs;

PARA.TAB: *speed up the pace of labour market reforms;

SPEECH.PARA: *establish a timetable of micro-economic reforms to help compensate for and match the pace of tariff reductions; and
* ensure all sectors of the economy, particularly the non-traded sector, are up to international best practice.
This Government has done nothing. The release further went on to say:
This Federal Budget relies too much on faith, hope and charity, and is a disappointment to Australia's manufacturers.

But it does not stop there. The Taxation Institute of Australia put out a media release headed `Tax system still a shambles, says Taxation Institute of Australia'. The Real Estate Institute of Australia, responding to the package that had something to do with housing, has a great quote. It really says it all. The Government tried to bring forward spending on housing by $75m in the vain hope that the mad scramble and panic might create jobs. I can tell the House what will happen if the Government brings forward spending in that area. The building industry has been plagued for years by peaks in funding; it falls off when the tap is turned off. Of course, you will waste money. I quote from the press release of the Real Estate Institute, which states:
Deputy Prime Minister and Housing Minister Brian Howe is a major part of Australia's housing cost problem.

That is too darned true. It goes on to say that the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) is the problem in regard to housing costs in Australia. But of course it does not stop there. The Government's approach to this has been to create jobs that are not real jobs. I guess that is the really disappointing thing. At a time in Australia when we have one million people unemployed, we have an admission in this Budget that in 12 months time, mid-next year, we can still look forward to unemployment at 10 per cent. In four years time from today we will still have unemployment running at 8 per cent. That is a terrible admission, if we can really believe the Government, after the term of this Government, after nearly a decade.

PARA.TAB: I do not think we have seen the last of unemployment; the Government has admitted that. Let us remember that the last forecast was that unemployment would peak at 10 3/4 per cent. It got to 11.1 per cent. Now the Government is saying, `Trust us. It will drop back to 10 per cent mid-next year and it will flatten off at 8 per cent in four years time'. Well, that is not good enough. It is not good enough to throw money at the problems. Finally, why does the Government not face up to the real problems?

Let us look at where there is some increase in funding in the Budget. This is very interesting. I draw the attention of the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall), who is at the table, to the fact that in the portfolio estimates there is an increase in funding for one particular area and that is the insolvency and trustee area in Australia. For expenditure under the Bankruptcy Act there will be an increase from $15m-odd to $26.5m. But there is more. In fact, there is going to be computerisation. That will involve an extra increase of $2.8m.

Bankruptcies are the only success story of this Government. In fact, this year all-up bankruptcies jumped to 17,500 people—up from 9,100 two years ago. But the figures are hidden. Let us remember that when a proprietary limited company is wound up, it does not go broke; it is an insolvency. Insolvencies this year jumped to 9,579—so under this Government this year all-up bankruptcies and failures add up to 27,166. It is an absolute disgrace. This Government's only claim to success is the growth in bankruptcies. The only extra funds being provided to cope with that growth are being provided to that department to handle those bankruptcies. It is a lost opportunity.

We need to look at the collapse of funding. Let us look at the revenue side of Budget Paper No. 2. It is interesting that the 1990-91 figure for companies was $14.2 billion. The actual figure for l991-92 dropped to $13.4 billion. This year again it dropped to $12.1 billion. But let us not stop there. Let us look at the revenue that comes from small business partnerships and investments. The estimate of the Government for the year 1991-92 was $8.750 billion; that was its estimate. The figure came in at $6.4 billion—well under its estimate. What is it hoping for this year? It is pretty bright; it is hoping for an increase—only a slight increase—of $6.7-odd billion. I have to tell the Minister that on the figures that extra funding for bankruptcies will be well and truly needed.

It is unfortunate that this Government missed the entire point in regard to creating real jobs in this country. Of course, the Government put on a superannuation levy which industry estimates will cost between 60,000 and 100,000 jobs. If payroll tax were knocked off, between 175,000 and 200,000 jobs could be created. The Government is about putting costs on industry in this country.

The Treasurer talked about the need for change in the economy. We are well and truly aware of the need for change in the economy. What we are about on this side of the Parliament is giving our businesses, our industries, our manufacturers, the opportunity to be both domestically and internationally competitive. If we give them a chance, they can do it. We are about taking taxes off industry and off business to give them a chance. The Government is about putting on taxes and charges. In fact, in this Budget it has a darned car parking tax as well. When will the Government get out of this taxing mode and give business the opportunity to compete?

In Fightback we are about taking taxes off. Payroll tax is a tax not only on employing people but also on doing business. The hard pressed manufacturers in Victoria in the industries that have been killed off by this Government would be more competitive if they could wipe payroll tax off the cost of production.

I note that the figure for wholesales sales tax of $9.4 billion was about the only thing that came in fairly close to budget in the Budget. Again, we would give business a chance. We are about wiping $1.7 billion worth of wholesale sales tax off the costs of exports. But, more importantly, we will be taking the taxes off the cost of doing business. The removal of fuel excise of $6.6 billion will also give our industries a chance. If we take the taxes off our industries and our businesses, they can compete.

We are not about knocking workers. The Treasurer said that we do not have faith in Australia. Well, I have to tell honourable members that we have great faith in Australia. We have a faith that our manufacturers and workers can take on the rest of the world and win. We have in this country a well trained and well educated work force. We do not want to finish up having in this country the best educated dole queues in the world. We believe that we can do well. We believe that can be done through a better trade surplus, repaying the foreign debt and giving the workers a go.

Under the Government's policy the average tradesman who wants to work overtime on a Saturday will jump up the tax scale. I will give a quick example: a tradesman on $450 a week now, after tax, earns about $9.88 per hour. If he works overtime on a Saturday, the first two hours are at time and a half and the next at double time. So his gross pay jumps to about $627, his tax doubles and his hourly rate drops to $8.56. So the guys say, `Mate, I am not interested in working'.

Under our package of tax cuts, that tradesman can double his income and pay a tax rate of 30c in the dollar. We will give tax cuts of 30 per cent or $13 billion to reward people who want to put in the effort. This country was built on reward for hard work and effort. We can return to that situation by creating jobs and giving people the incentive and reward for hard work and effort. If they want to save, let us reward them. If they want to work, let us reward them. (Time expired).

TALK.START.PARA: —For the last two years the Liberal Party has been about talking down the economy, in an effort and a hope of seeing the fortunes of Australians in a worse position—for their own political gain. It is about time that some of these prophecies of doom are put to rest and that the Australian people are able to have a look at the genuine situation—as attested to not only by Australian business people but also by international agencies—rather than, as the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) was wont to do, going through a rather droll collage of press releases.

PARA.TAB: In the last year there has been significant growth in the Australian economy. It is significant in terms of not just Australia's recent experience but also international experience. The most recent OECD economic outlook published in June of this year has some forecasts for the 1992 calendar year that some honourable members opposite would do well to consider and understand.

The G7, the traditional group of the seven most powerful economic countries in the world, has been assessed by the OECD as having an economic growth outlook in the year 1992 of 1.8 per cent. The OECD assesses Australia's economic growth in the same period, this calendar year 1992, at 2.6 per cent—a clear margin, a clear sign of faith by the OECD that the Australian economy will grow this year faster than those of the G7, the countries that are seen as the leaders of the economic world, the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Italy, the United Kingdom and Canada.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will it go up 3 per cent?

—The Budget's projections of 3 per cent growth to which the honourable member for Forrest now refers, are reinforced by the 1992 projections of the OECD, which predict for this 1992 calendar year—the honourable member would do well to listen to and understand this—2.6 per cent growth in Australia. That is right on track for a 3 per cent growth in the financial year 1992-93.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at some of the countries that those opposite would have us emulate. The United Kingdom has followed the Thatcherite policies that have been so warmly embraced by those opposite. This year, the United Kingdom is expected to have a growth rate of—wait for it—0.4 per cent. In fact, I understand that in the most recent figures that country has dipped back into recession. That is the result of the Thatcherite policies.

The United States is to have a 2.1 per cent growth level. In fact, at that figure America is anticipated to have the greatest growth amongst those important economic countries. We will achieve 2.6 per cent. The Opposition sits there and says, `Where is the plan for economic growth?'. In spite of the evidence, in spite of the facts, in spite of our experience, it endeavours to talk the economy down. It should be condemned by the electorate for its negative and quite deceitful representation of the Australian economy.

One of the reasons we are performing that well is that for the first time since the Second World War this country has restructured so that we no longer sit back and rely upon digging holes in the ground and selling a bit of wool, wheat, sugar or a few other things. For the first time since the Second World War we have restructured to become a manufacturing exporter of substantial measure.

The comparisons between what the Opposition had when it tried to run this country and the current situation are dramatic. When we look at major exports in the manufactured fields, things we have not just dug out of the ground and put in a ship but things we have made—things like motor vehicles—we find a dramatic change in the past 10 years. The most recent figure published in the Winter 1992 Treasury Economic Round-Up shows that motor vehicle exports in 1991 were worth $414m. Ten years ago when those opposite were in office they were worth $20m. That is a change of over 2,000 per cent. That is an average annual growth every year of 27 per cent in the export of vehicles.

In office machines and computers there is the same situation—growth of 33 per cent on average every year for the past 10 years. That is something those opposite never contemplated, much less achieved. Telecommunication equipment is the same story, showing a 22 per cent average increase every year for the past 10 years. So those exports now are quite substantial. In new areas such as medical, pharmaceutical and scientific products, there is an annual growth rate over the past 10 years of 13 per cent—every single year. They are the facts. They are the facts which those opposite try to hide from the public for their own cheap political interests.

Unemployment was mentioned, and I will make some reference to that as well because no doubt it is the key concern for the nation and for all members in this place. It is no doubt the case that unemployment is far too high, and no member of this House takes any comfort or pride in that. But when we compare the situation in March 1983, when we came to office, with March 1992, there are some interesting results. It is true that unemployment has gone up by about 600,000. It is also true that the number of people who have a job has gone up by about 1.2 million. Well in excess of one million more people are actively employed now than at the time when we came to office.

The truth is that the economy over that period has grown dramatically. It has grown because of this Government's policies. But in spite of that growth the Liberal Party and the Opposition persist with their efforts to denigrate the country and to denigrate the economy.

Some comment has been made about whether the deficit in this Budget is appropriate. The size of the deficit in this Budget is quite modest by Australian standards and by international comparison. We have a projected deficit of 3.3 per cent of our gross domestic product. In dollar terms that is about $13.3 billion. That $13 billion deficit that we will have this year should be seen against the surpluses which this Government returned in the four years 1987-88 through until 1990-91. During that period this Government generated surpluses of $18 billion.

If we look at the surpluses the Opposition generated we get a very different picture. Indeed, the Opposition has never generated a surplus at all—not at all. From the day Bob Menzies got the idea to spawn the Liberal Party, not once did it return a surplus budget. Never—not once in its entire history in government—did it have a surplus budget. The Labor Government is the only government in the last 40 years to return a surplus budget. It is those surpluses, built up through the 1980s when the economy was probably overheating with too much money floating around, which this Government is very responsibly using to finance much-needed employment programs and welfare assistance to those most hurt by the recent recession.

In case we think we are out of kilter with the rest of the world, let us have a look at what the OECD projects for deficit budgets around the world. Let us look at the G7 again, the most powerful economic nations in the world. The average for all of those nations this year as projected by the OECD is a 3.6 per cent deficit budget—which is more than Australia is planning, more than this Government is planning in the current Budget. Again when you look at some of the people those opposite would have us follow, we see that Canada will have a deficit in this calendar year of 3.6 per cent of its gross domestic product; the United Kingdom 4.2 per cent; Italy 10 per cent; and the United States somewhere around 5 per cent. The deficit provided for in this Budget is entirely responsible, well within the means of the nation to meet, and well under that of comparable nations around the world.

The critical question the people of Australia want answered by those opposite when they hop up to criticise this Budget is where will they find the $7 billion which they will not fund this year? Will they take out the $369m for schools or the $345m for local government projects? Or will it be the $188m for urban development and public housing? In both those areas they have already gone on record as saying they will abolish those programs. I could go through the list of other initiatives that are in this Budget if time permitted, but unfortunately it does not.

The clear question those opposite have to confront every time they hop up to talk about the Budget is which $7 billion do they want to cut out? Until they come clean with the answer to the $7 billion question, the people of Australia will not have a bar of them or their policies, and nor should they.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Development of RAAF Base Scherger at Peppan, Cape York Peninsula, Queensland

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report:

SPEECH.PARA: Development of RAAF Base Scherger at Peppan, Cape York Peninsula, Queensland

The Government is committed to a policy of defence self-reliance within a framework of alliances and agreements. Consistent with this policy it is necessary to provide a RAAF airfield on Cape York Peninsula. This proposal will provide facilities at the initial development of the base which is to support Australian Defence Force activities in the north-east of Australia. The base will complete the chain of RAAF airfields across Australia's north and provide a base for the deployment and coverage of the sea-air gap during a contingency.

PARA.TAB: In peacetime the primary purpose for the airfield will be exercises and deployment. During exercise periods about 20 aircraft and 400 RAAF personnel will be deployed at the airfield. It will be able to accommodate up to 1,500 military personnel for combined or joint force exercises. The facilities to be provided at the airfield site will cater for aircraft operations, aircraft parking, navigational aids, fuel and equipment storage, and accommodation. These facilities will be the minimum to support military aircraft operations. The airfield will contain a 3,050 metre runway and associated taxiways.

The estimated total cost of the proposed scope of works, including consultants fees, is $166.5m at December 1991 prices. Completion of initial works will be commensurate with the priorities of the Department of Defence and cash availability; however, current plans envisage completion by 1998-99. I table selected drawings of the proposed development of RAAF Base Scherger at Peppan on the Cape York Peninsula. I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports this motion to refer to the Public Works Committee the proposal to develop an Air Force base at Peppan on the Cape York Peninsula. The coalition is of the view that the development of an air base on the Cape York Peninsula is an important part of any approach to northern defence. In the event of a defence contingency in our north, this air base could play a significant role in providing a point for logistic and maintenance support as well as for tactical air operations.

PARA.TAB: We already have a base at Tindal in the Northern Territory and the so-called bare-base at Derby in Western Australia. The addition of this facility will complete a chain of bases across northern Australia which, as I have said, will facilitate air operations in times of emergency in our north. It a worthwhile defence objective and one which signals Australia's commitment to develop a significant defence presence in that part of our land.

Having indicated our support for referring the project to the Public Works Committee, we would also ask that the Committee give consideration to another issue—the proposal to develop a satellite launch facility on the eastern side of the peninsula, at Temple Bay. I put it to the Committee for its consideration that if the spaceport development goes ahead there will then be, within 80 kilometres of each other, two airfields on the peninsula capable of landing international standard aircraft—by `international standard aircraft', I mean models such as the Boeing 747, the jumbo—and heavily laden military aircraft.

I hope that the Committee looks at this issue and, in particular, examines the thought which has been given already to collocating the airfields. It would be interesting to know why there has been a resistance so far to collocation, as the two airfields will be, as I have already indicated, a short distance apart. When exercises are being contemplated, if they remain separate, that may again pose problems for aircraft controllers and for the use of airspace. Certainly, collocating the sites would simplify the task of maintaining airfield defence, amongst other things. In other words, it is quite apparent that in the event of a contingency both airfields would be commandeered for the use of the military and both would be required to be defended. I suspect also that aircraft movements could be controlled from an airport established to service the proposed satellite launch facility about which I have spoken.

These questions have already been raised by others, including Dr Ross Babbage. It is an important matter and one which I hope the Committee will make inquiries about during its investigations and deliberations. Having said that, and assuming that it gets all the necessary answers, the Opposition is keen to see the establishment of RAAF Base Scherger, but with that qualification that I have outlined.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Hand, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: Effective management of the migration program is essential in ensuring that planned program outcomes are not exceeded.The Act currently provides for two broad program control mechanisms; namely, the power to suspend processing in specified classes and a system of pass marks for the independent and concessional family categories. This pass mark system, which is currently in operation, controls visa issue by allowing for the approval, `pooling' and rejection of applications.

PARA.TAB: The suspension power in section 28 of the Act has not been exercised but it forms a powerful administrative tool in ensuring that program levels are not exceeded. However, it is also a very blunt one. There is no facility to set a numerical limit. It also unnecessarily suspends all processing, even where that processing would not result in the program being exceeded. Resorting to an across the board suspension power would cause very uneven workload patterns at overseas posts and, given the processing delays involved, would lessen the capacity of the program to be increased readily.

This Bill will remedy these problems by supplementing the visa suspension powers. The new provisions permit the imposition of numerical ceilings, or caps, for a class or classes of visas and allow the processing of applications up to the point of grant. The cap would be gazetted by the Minister for a financial program year. Once the cap is reached, no more visas in the capped class or classes will be able to be granted, although other processing would not be impeded.

In order to ensure that the cap is not inadvertently exceeded, the Bill permits the Minister to implement an effective administrative mechanism which allows the orderly grant of visas while the cap is in place. This mechanism will, for instance, allow the Minister to impose ceilings on the number of visas that can be granted at overseas posts.

The Bill will allow the Minister to determine the orderly release of visas to fill places when the cap is lifted. The Minister may target the grant of visas in accordance with the priorities of the migration program.

Consistent with section 28, the new capping provisions will not apply to certain classes of visas in the preferential family category. The Bill also corrects a minor technical error of reference in the Migration Amendment Act (No. 2) of 1991. I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ruddock) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN WINE AND BRANDY CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Crean, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to remove uncertainties about the enforcement of laws concerning truth in labelling of wine. In 1989, the Commonwealth Parliament amended the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980 to implement a wine label integrity program. The wine label integrity program was developed at the request of the wine industry and requires wine manufacturers to keep records to support labelling claims of the vintage, variety and region of origin of wine. These records and the stocks to which they relate must also be made available for audit upon request by the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. The aim of the program is to ensure truth in labelling and so increase consumer confidence in the reliability of wine label claims. The program also aims to ensure that all wine makers compete honestly amongst themselves in the marketing of wine.

PARA.TAB: The first label integrity program inspections occurred in the Clare Valley of South Australia in 1990. No breaches of the record keeping provisions occurred and no instances of fraud were detected. However, practice in using the legislation where over 200 audits have now been conducted has highlighted technical deficiencies which are likely to impair the enforcement of the legislation.

The Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980 requires manufacturers to keep label integrity program records, but there is no requirement that the records be accurate and complete. Further, where the Corporation under section 42 of the Act requests a manufacturer to provide label integrity program records the manufacturer must provide the records, even if they are self-incriminating, but the manufacturer is then protected from prosecution should the records disclose false labelling. Thus, there is some doubt whether a successful prosecution concerning false labelling could be launched under the present provisions of the Act. This Bill aims to rectify these deficiencies.

This Bill does four key things. First, where label integrity program records are required to be kept under the Act, clause 39ZAAA makes it an offence to knowingly or recklessly fail to make and keep such records, or to make and keep false, misleading or incomplete records.

Second, section 42 of the Act, which requires a person to provide information to the Corporation on request and indemnifies the person from prosecution where such information is furnished, is amended. The amendment removes the label integrity program provisions from the ambit of section 42 but otherwise leaves section 42 unchanged.

Third, clause 39ZAA of the Bill provides that where the Corporation requests a person to provide label integrity program records, the person may with reasonable excuse refuse the request. The Bill provides that it is a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse to provide label integrity program records where they are self-incriminating. The aim of these amendments is to enable the Corporation to instigate a prosecution where label integrity program records, provided at the Corporation's request, disclose false labelling of wine, while retaining the right of a person to refuse to provide such records where they are self-incriminating. Where a person chooses, with reasonable excuse, not to provide the records, the Corporation may still exercise its inspection powers to obtain label integrity program records and will be able to use those records to initiate a prosecution. Thus the original intention of the legislation will be achieved.

Clause 39ZAC of the Bill enables the Corporation to retain label integrity program records for 60 days or, if a prosecution for a label offence is initiated within 60 days, until proceedings and appeals are concluded. A person will be able to inspect or copy the records provided to the Corporation.

The fourth change in the Bill honours a commitment made by the Government in 1989 to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The first of the two amendments involved will enable a person to copy evidence seized by a label integrity program inspector. The second reduces the period of validity of an offence warrant from one month to a maximum of seven days. The Senate Committee had argued that a person ought to be entitled to copy records which were seized by an inspector and that the period of validity of an offence warrant of one month was too long and could unfairly infringe a person's privacy. The Government had agreed to consider the Committee's recommendations in the light of experience in administering the Act and to implement any necessary changes when it was next amended.

The Bill will not have any financial impact.The changes proposed in this Bill are aimed at safeguarding the integrity of our wine industry and have the industry's wholehearted support. The success of our wine industry is reflected in its motto of purity, integrity, quality and economy. This Bill furthers this objective.

Australian wine makers have a 97 per cent share of the domestic market for wine. Exports of Australian wine have soared from $20.5m in 1985-86 to $234m in 1991-92. The industry is aiming for $1 billion of exports per year by the year 2000. Continued export expansion is the key to future growth and prosperity of our wine industry and truth in labelling is the key to consumer confidence in our wines here and abroad.

Our wine label integrity program legislation has drawn praise at home and abroad for underpinning the integrity of our wines and for providing the platform for fair trading in wine. The label integrity program is seen as a tough and effective deterrent to fraud. The amendments proposed in this Bill will ensure the legislation can be enforced in the courts and will safeguard our hard won international reputation for high quality, value for money, true to label wines. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Chaney) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL ROAD TRANSPORT COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Robert Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is to amend the National Road Transport Commission Act 1991 to give effect to the light vehicles agreement formulated at the Heads of Government meeting on 11 May 1992. The agreement involves a regime for vehicles weighing 4.5 tonnes or less, their drivers, other road users and related matters. This will expand the powers and functions of the National Road Transport Commission, NRTC, to include regulation of all motorised vehicles and not just those vehicles weighing more than 4.5 tonnes. In addition, the Commission shall exercise responsibility for policy development for light vehicles, excluding the determination of charges.

PARA.TAB: When the National Road Transport Commission was formally established at the beginning of this year, it was hailed as a major step towards achieving fundamental and lasting reforms of road transport—reforms which would benefit all Australians as a result of a more efficient road transport industry sector. In the short time the Commission has been operating, it has achieved significant progress towards the development of uniform charges and technical standards for heavy vehicles.

The Commission has earned a reputation for its independence and fairness through extensive formal and informal consultations with industry and governments. The first recommendations of the NRTC in relation to heavy vehicle charges have been considered and approved by the ministerial council. The charging determinations have received support from a convincing majority of States. The charges have also received overwhelming support from the road transport industry, the Business Council of Australia and the Transport Workers Union.

The addition of light vehicles to the terms of reference of the National Road Transport Commission is another significant step towards creating a single national road transport regulatory environment. Australians are one of the most mobile people on earth. The ability to move freely anywhere in the country is something we consider a fundamental right. Nevertheless, one of the most basic ways through which we enjoy our right of mobility on the ground is governed by a myriad of different regulations. Even to the basics of traffic rules.

In many places on State borders, such as in Albury-Wodonga, Tweed Heads-Gold Coast, and in the Canberra-Queanbeyan region, near neighbours and colleagues who have the same type of car, are subject to different registration requirements, different inspection requirements and differing on-road requirements.

The management and development of the regulations covering light vehicles has meant duplication of work amongst the States. The National Road Transport Commission will play a significant role in facilitating and ensuring continued cooperation among the States and Territories to reach a solution to these problems. It will create the basis for a nationally consistent legislative framework which will streamline administrative processes in government bureaucracies across the country.

Our roads constitute a major asset to this country, but it is also an asset which requires constant maintenance and upgrading. An important function of the Commission will be to assist in the development of indicators which can provide better ways of assessing how we, as a nation, are coping with this task. The Commission will collect and publish information on important issues affecting road transport. Information will be assembled and published on the comparative assessment of the performance of road authorities and road systems. This will assist all levels of government by providing a better, more balanced view on the delivery of road funding programs.

In addition, the Commission will monitor the use of alternative fuels and publish information on road safety. The Commission will not pursue uniformity purely for uniformity's sake. In a number of specified areas, it must demonstrate that significant net benefits would arise before developing proposals.

I now turn to the individual amendments which are set out in the Bill. The principal amendment in the Bill will provide for the inclusion of the light vehicles agreement in a schedule to the National Road Transport Commission Act. The proposed amendments will expand the terms of reference of the National Road Transport Commission to include a range of issues relating to light vehicles. The Commission will also assemble and publish information on road funding, the taxes and road related charges applying to light vehicles, the performance of our road systems, the effectiveness of road authorities, and on road safety.

The other amendments proposed within the Bill cover those areas which make specific reference to issues covered by either the heads of government agreement on heavy vehicles or the light vehicles agreement. These amendments do not affect the manner in which the Commission and the ministerial council operate, but are limited to clarifying which agreement is referred to. The Commission is funded through contributions by the Commonwealth and the States based on shares approved by the ministerial council. The Commonwealth contribution is 35 per cent. In 1992-93 this amounts to $1.1m. The financial impact on the Commonwealth of the expansion of the terms of reference of the Commission will be minimal.

Successful and lasting reforms which facilitate a better, more efficient road transport environment has been a priority for this Government. The expansion of the terms of reference of the Commission to include light vehicles is certain to bring benefits to all Australians.I expect all governments to continue to honour the commitment by heads of government to implement a uniform national road transport registration system. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hawker) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION STANDARDS REGULATIONS APPLICATION BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Beddall, for Mr Baldwin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes to ensure the validity of amendments to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations to reflect the superannuation guarantee arrangements. On the basis of legal advice, the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 was not presented to the Governor-General on 30 June 1992. That advice indicated that it would not be appropriate to seek royal assent owing to the fact that the SG Bill was not passed in identical form by both Houses of Parliament.

PARA.TAB: Legal advice on 30 June was that the amendments to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations could proceed and come into effect from 1 July 1992 even though the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill had not been enacted. That advice was on the basis that 1 July 1992 would be the commencement date for the SG Bill, when it was enacted, and that it would follow that the commencement date of the amendments to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations would be 1 July 1992.

Subsequent legal advice raised doubt about the validity of this approach. In consequence, the Government decided to introduce the present Bill to place beyond doubt the validity of the amendments to the regulations from 1 July 1992. This decision was taken to provide certainty for employers, fund trustees, employees and the superannuation industry generally, that the superannuation guarantee arrangements are in place as announced. I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today the House debated some neighbouring legislation which was directed at overcoming the potential legal problems relating to the incorrect passage of legislation through this House and the Senate. We welcome the opportunity to debate the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations Application Bill 1992 principally because even at this late hour it gives the Opposition another opportunity to place on the record for all to see and hear why we believe at this stage that it is not in Australia's interests to be introducing a universal, compulsory system of superannuation.

PARA.TAB: The overwhelming majority of the workers who will lose their jobs because of this legislation will be young people with low skills and part time casual workers who are mainly women. This effect will be compounded when the system brings into the net a further 850,000 non-managerial, non-award private sector wage and salary earners most of whom are not currently covered by superannuation, are employed in small business and are on very modest incomes. Also, a further 50,000 to 100,000 public sector employees are currently lacking effective coverage because of poor vesting.

There are also another 650,000 employees who have no award superannuation coverage because their employers cannot afford to comply with the award due to the outstanding superannuation liabilities which are currently estimated to be around $700m. Under this legislation those outstanding amounts will have to be paid over the next 12 months. I put it to the House: has this Government seriously considered what the impact of having to find a further $700m will be on small and medium business in particular?

The Government is well aware that when this matter was announced originally the Confederation of Australian Industry made it absolutely clear that, on the basis of the surveys it had conducted, there would be a loss of between 60,000 and 100,000 employees. On average that represented 2.9 per cent of the work force in each company which had subscribed to that survey. Nothing has changed and, if anything, the circumstances faced by many of these companies have got worse.

It simply amazes the Opposition why it is that, at a time of such high unemployment, we have a Government which seems determined to set upon a course of action the purpose of which is to increase significantly the on-costs of employing labour in Australia. This is precisely why in our Fightback package, among the seven taxes which we would abolish with the direct and deliberate intention of increasing employment opportunities and reducing the current tendency of putting people out of work, we establish the need to abolish the payroll tax, which would save Australian business $5.9 billion a year.

We will also abolish the lump sum superannuation tax currently before the House, although we have made it clear that the level which we inherit will be the base level which will apply across the economy. The training guarantee levy will also be abolished. That, again, is a cost to employers. There are other changes in the Fightback package which will undoubtedly make it cheaper and more versatile for employers to look to the future in a more productive and optimistic manner. It is an extraordinary situation that at this time we see in the superannuation levy, the SGL, yet another effort to increase costs. In fact, it has been estimated that the total costs of labour will probably increase by between 9 and 10 per cent.

The employers of most of those 1.5 million workers to whom I have already referred will be required to go from nought per cent to 3 per cent, 4 per cent or 5 per cent or more in just one year if this legislation is implemented. We hear rumours. Statements are made sotto voce by various Ministers that if unemployment continues to rise, perhaps the timing of the introduction of the SGL can be changed once again. This is just a very dubious and false way of saying to those who are affected most, `Yes, we were wrong, but we don't have the courage to admit it'. That, sadly, in so many areas is the legacy of this Labor Government.

The cost, as I have identified, will be around $2 billion a year. That is on top of the 4.5 per cent wages claim currently being pursued by the ACTU and other costs such as the training guarantee levy and payroll tax. That is why it is not difficult to demonstrate that over recent times the cost of employing labour has increased by approximately 10 per cent, at a time when employers are looking for excuses to divest themselves of labour on the grounds that the level of productivity of their work force under current economic circumstances cannot justify the oncosts and the supplementary costs of employing them.

In a sense, the time at which the SGL comes in at 4 or 5 per cent for larger firms is irrelevant in terms of a total final outcome. The jump in employer contributions will be enormous for many firms, especially for those small businesses which have not been contributing as perhaps by law they should have been. They have failed to do so because they have not had the money. It is as simple as that. The alternative for a small employer faced with those circumstances is to say, `What do I do? I break the law or I call in my employees and say, ``Sorry, fellows, you're out. We're closing the doors"'. That has happened in thousands of industries and thousands of small businesses across this country over the last two years or so. In the middle of the worst recession in the last 60 years of Australia's economic history, we find this Government determined to proceed with this legislation which is utterly false and wrong at this time.

The Treasury evidence which was given to the Senate Committee was quite stark. We were told that if employers bear the full cost burden, up to 45,000 jobs will be lost over the next two years and up to 100,000 over the next five years. Senator Cook has already conceded that non-compliance is costing some $700m a year, according to his own Department. The reason has been given: employers cannot afford to pay. Yet now they are being told by law, `You will fork up or else'.

Award superannuation now nominally covers some 85 per cent of wage and salary earners, yet the compliance levels are much less, at around 65 per cent. It does not apply to the self-employed—some 20 per cent of total employment in the private sector and 15 per cent of the total economy. As a result of the SGL, approximately 1.5 million employees will be brought into the net for the first time. These will include almost 1,000,000 non-managerial, non-award private sector wage and salary earners, as well as some public sector employees, and a further 500,000 employees of non-complying employers.

The approximate projected new flows to the first full year of operation will be more than $2 billion, equivalent to 80,000 jobs at an average income of $25,000 each. This money has to be found by those employers, regardless of their economic circumstance. There is no provision in the proposals before the House that the economic difficulties facing those companies are in any sense to be seen as mitigating circumstances.

It is very sad that the Australian work force and Australian employers today are being expected to carry the cost of a pre-election accord deal made by the then Hawke-Keating Government before the last election to cement the support of the ACTU. We find it absolutely extraordinary that the ACTU, which sets itself up as the guardian of the future of the working class people of Australia, should have done so little since the last election, despite the devastating reduction in economic activity in this country and the massively high levels of unemployment that have followed. On this point, nothing has been done by the ACTU to encourage the Government to go to employers and say, `We want to reduce wherever we can the oncosts of employing labour'. That demonstrates the fundamental difference between Fightback and the Government's policy. We have put together a policy which is unashamedly directed at improving employment, at creating jobs and at taking $20 billion off the costs of business in Australia.

Our opponents carry on with this program which is adding about 10 per cent to every additional job taken at this time. Adding 10 per cent in additional costs clearly must mean that people at the margin will lose the right to work. We hear so much from the Government, as we did in the Budget last night, about how full employment is once again one of the objectives of its policies. I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Price), who is at the table: how can Government members seriously talk about full employment when through their legislative program they are going in exactly the opposite direction? We were told last night in the Budget that the Government will create 800,000 jobs within the next four years. In Fightback we said we would create two million jobs by the end of the decade.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a minimum.

—As an absolute minimum, as my colleague says.
