Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Sullivan)—Order! I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Grain Legumes Levy Amendment Bill concurrently with the Oilseeds Levy Amendment Bill. As there is no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LLOYD
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The two Bills we are debating tonight, the Grain Legumes Levy Amendment Bill and the Oilseeds Levy Amendment Bill, change the basis of research levies on grain legumes and oilseeds from a specific rate per tonne to a farm gate ad valorem rate. The Grains Council, on behalf of grain growers, has recommended that this is a more equitable form of contribution because it is proportional to the net return and takes into account, obviously, the varying prices of or returns for different types of grain.

PARA.TAB: We have before us two separate Bills, but since 1990-91 there has actually been one corporation to cover the whole grains, oilseeds and legumes area—the Grains Research and Development Corporation. I commend the Grains Council for its work in consolidating this research, Don Blesing, who is the Chairman of the Corporation, and its members.

In considering the first report of the Grains Research and Development Corporation, there has been some comment about the level of reserves of $30m. It has been questioned whether there is a need or whether it is appropriate to have such a level of reserves when, after all, it is growers' money that is being levied—and levied in difficult times—and when it is not actually being utilised. The answer has been that this is the first year of the combined Corporation and, therefore, there is a need to sort things out. Secondly, there is considerable variability in income from year to year and therefore there is a need for reserves to provide stability. The example was given that in the year in question it was projected that the levies would raise $14.5m but, because of the climatic situation, the actual amount raised was only $8.5m. Adequate reserves will mean more stability in the research programs, and we are looking at about 1,000 different research programs under this Corporation.

Also, there are no Government matching dollar for dollar payments for administration under the rural research arrangements. The payments of the dollar for dollar do not happen until after the money is actually expended by the Corporation—that is, the growers' money is spent first. Once again, there is a need to have some sort of reserve. However, once again I query whether it is really in the best interests of growers to have that level of reserve for any length of time.

No-one in the industry—and certainly no-one in the Opposition—queries the value of rural research.Now, more than ever, it is essential, and the grain industry is a good example. There is the need to target particular markets with varieties that are suited to, or have special requirements or abilities to meet, those markets' requirements. The days of just using breeding to increase production are gone and, therefore, there is this need for particular types of research.

We have just had a public debate on the level of rural research. It was indicated that the Government was going to change the longstanding dollar for dollar rural research arrangements up to the level of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production for that particular industry, to a 60:40 arrangement, that is, 60 per cent growers and 40 per cent Government. That would have had quite a disastrous impact on the whole rural research arrangements. It would have damaged the stability that was there, which would have created uncertainty for those in the research community. It would have been most unfair in relation to that sector of agriculture and, for that matter, all sectors of agriculture, which are going through the lowest income year ever.

The rural sector also provides more of its own money for research in good years and bad than is the case, to my knowledge, in any other sector of the community.Many years ago I was shadow Minister for health and had a meeting with those in the medical profession who were wanting more money for medical research. I suggested to them that one way to increase medical research was to have the same sort of scheme as farmers, that is, dollar for dollar. They did not like that at all, yet their income was far higher, and consistently far higher, than farmers. They said, `Why should we contribute to research which, in a way, reduces our jobs?'. That, of course, is no different to rural research. Much of the research means there is an ability for individual farmers to produce more and there is the same impact.

I do make the point that we often overlook that there are bad years and good years. Last year was the worst year on record for farmers' net incomes in this country, yet in that year they continued to provide those same research dollars. I am pleased that commonsense has prevailed in the Government and that that longstanding and bipartisan arrangement will continue. It is essential that it does.

In relation to the value of research, I want to refer to a recent document entitled Rural Research: The Pay-off. It contains returns from research undertaken by the CSIRO Institute of Plant Production and Processing. It is a co-operative study by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics. It was released in May 1992. There were 10 case studies of the return on the research dollar in the plant production area.

This document notes that obviously there are certain qualifications in the sense that some research projects will always be more successful than others. Some will return more than others and, of course, there are times when the research may be very good but will not be taken up commercially as much as it should—and sometimes there are reasons for that as well.

Running quickly through these 10 case studies, I believe they indicate the breadth of some of the types of research that is going on in the area we are talking about and the benefit to the nation as well as to the individual farmer. The first was the control of take-all in South Australian wheat. To the year 2000 the benefit-cost ratio is 92.2:1, with an internal rate of return of 179 per cent and a value of benefit to the industry of $813m. The second was pest control in cotton, with a benefit-cost ratio of 3.4:1, an internal rate of return of 16.2 per cent and a $61m net value.

The third was disease resistant lucerne in Queensland, with a benefit-cost ratio of 3.7:1, an internal rate of return of 13 1/2 per cent and a present value of benefit of $39.7m. The fourth was nematode tolerant grapevine rootstock, with a benefit-cost ratio of 25.5:1, an internal rate of return of 28.3 per cent and a present value of benefit of $169m. The fifth was breeding of new cotton varieties, with a benefit-cost ratio was 18.4:1, an internal rate of return of 27.8 per cent and a present value of benefit of $289m. We have here two cases of research into cotton. Cotton is now one of our major agricultural export industries, and research has played a very important part in making our cotton industry one of the most efficient and competitive in the world.

The sixth case study was the introduction of chickpeas in Queensland, with a benefit-cost ratio of 9.4:1 and a value of $132m. The seventh was phalaris breeding in New South Wales, with a benefit-cost ratio of 7.2:1, an internal rate of return of 20 per cent and a present value of benefit of $358m. The eighth was the introduction of stylo pastures in Queensland, with a benefit-cost ratio of 4.7:1, an internal rate of return of 16.3 per cent and a value of benefit of $112m. The ninth—and the last example I will give because the other was a non-agricultural example—was the mechanical pruning of grapevines, with a benefit-cost ratio of 84:1, an internal rate of return of 87 per cent and a present value of benefit of $224m.

Those are some examples. People can say, `Well, they're better than average examples', but it does not matter if they are because they indicate very clearly the tremendous pay-off to this country for its rural research effort. I commend the Bills and express the support of the coalition parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Grain Legumes Levy Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 provides for the basis on which grain legume research levies are paid to be changed from a specific rate per tonne to an ad valorem rate. The amendments are being made, as the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Lloyd) has said, in response to a request by the Grains Council of Australia, the representative organisation under the Grain Legumes Levy Act 1985.

PARA.TAB: The Bill will allow for research levies on leviable grain legumes to be paid on an ad valorem basis rather than at a specific rate per tonne, which is the current arrangement. The levies will continue to attract matching Commonwealth contributions, as provided for under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989. The research funds are administered by the Grains Research and Development Corporation.

Currently, levies are imposed under the Act on specified grain legumes at flat rates, as recommended by the GCA. These can be increased by regulation up to a maximum rate also specified in the Act. The levy rate for almost all grain legumes is currently $1.25 per tonne. Peanuts are levied at $2 per tonne and navy beans at $5 per tonne.

Maximum and operative rates of levy are specified in the Bill with provision for the operative rate to be changed by regulation on the recommendation of the GCA. The maximum rate may only be changed by Parliament amending the Act. Initially, the operative levy rate for all grain legumes will be one per cent of the net farm gate value of the grain legume, with provision for this to be increased to a maximum of 3 per cent. The GCA's request for the introduction of an ad valorem levy for grain legumes reflects its policy of relating the amount of levy payable for all grains more directly to the return received by the producer.

The Bill provides for the method of ascertaining the value of grain legumes for levy purposes to be prescribed in the regulations. It is envisaged that the method will parallel that for wheat, that is, sale price net of handling, storage and transport costs. Regulations under the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 provide for the collection of the levies.

The Oilseeds Levy Amendment Bill 1992 provides for the basis on which oilseed research levies are paid to be changed from a specific rate per tonne also to an ad valorem rate. The amendments are being made in response to the Grains Council of Australia which, as I said in regard to the previous Bill, is the representative organisation—in this case it is so under the Oilseeds Levy Act 1985.

This Bill will allow too for research levies on leviable oilseeds to be paid on an ad valorem basis rather than a specific rate per tonne, which is the current arrangement. The levies will continue to attract matching Commonwealth contributions, as provided for under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989. The research funds are administered by the Grains Research and Development Corporation.

Currently levies are imposed under the Act on specified oilseeds at a flat rate, as recommended by the GCA. This can be increased by regulation up to a maximum rate also specified in the Act. The levy rate for all oilseeds is currently $1.55 per tonne. Maximum and operative rates of levy are specified in the Bill with provision for the operative rate to be changed by regulation on the recommendation of the GCA. The maximum rate may only be changed by parliament amending the Act.

Initially, the operative levy rate for all oilseeds will be one per cent of the net farm gate value of the oilseed, with provision for this to be increased up to a maximum of 3 per cent. The GCA's request for the introduction of an ad valorem levy for oilseeds reflects its policy of relating the amount of levy payable for all grains more directly to the return received by the producer.

The Bill provides for the method of ascertaining the value of oilseeds for levy purposes to be prescribed in the regulations. It is envisaged that the method will parallel that for wheat, that is, sale price net of handling, storage and transport costs. Regulations under the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 provide for the collection of the levies.

Because of the time of the House and because one would only be repeating what the previous speaker, the honourable member for Murray said, I will not go on any longer. But it is pleasing to see that on these two Bills, as in most cases in regard to research and development, the Opposition supports the Government. I am pleased to commend these two Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased also to join in supporting the Grain Legumes Levy Amendment Bill and the Oilseeds Levy Amendment Bill, which change the system for collecting levies for research into a wide range of oilseed and leguminous crops. The levy will in future be collected on an ad valorem basis, rather than a specific rate per tonne. Initially, that rate will be set at one per cent of the farm gate value, but there is potential within the legislation for that rate to be raised to 3 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Right at the outset, I should acknowledge a pecuniary interest in this particular matter, because I suspect that as an oilseed and legume producer I would pay more of these levies than anyone else in the House. Indeed, I have experienced the benefits personally in my own career as a farmer of the rural research and the various projects that have been undertaken through the research and development arrangements that are in place.

The rates that have applied for legumes in the past have varied from $1.25 a tonne for most of the leguminous crops. However, there has been a special rate of $2 a tonne for peanuts and $5 a tonne for navy beans. As one who grew more navy beans than anyone else in the country, I guess that I have been one of the largest payers of the navy bean levy. On the other hand, the oilseeds levy has been at a fixed rate of $1.55 per tonne.

The idea of moving to a percentage levy is obviously designed to ensure that each industry pays a fairer share of the costs of rural research. No-one can argue with that in principle. The establishment of a single grain research and development corporation has meant that there has been a co-mingling of the funds raised from the various rural industries and States, with basically a common pool being distributed to research projects which are assessed to be of particular value.

This has led to some degree of criticism that the producers of one crop are funding research in another industry. In particular, the wheat growers have had some justification for their complaint that they have been contributing at least double what they have actually received back by way of research funding. Some States have been concerned that the money raised in their State has been spent on projects in other parts of Australia. There are examples of how this disproportionate revenue raising and expenditure has

SPEECH.PARA: occurred. For instance, members of the mung bean industry have been contributing about $17,500 a year over recent years from their levies, but have had $108,000 spent in their industry in 1991-92 and $75,000 in 1992-93. So the mung bean industry has obviously done very well. Members of the peanut industry have contributed around $80,000 a year and have had about $150,000 spent in their industry. So, with the Government contribution, it could be argued that they have got reasonable value for money.

PARA.TAB: By contrast, the central Queensland sunflower growers have had just cause for complaint. They have made considerable contributions because it is one of the large volume oilseed crops, yet they have had very little research funded in their industry. The research and development corporations have taken the view that the future of the sunflower industry is somewhat clouded because of problems with markets in countries such as Portugal and Mexico and because of the threat to the sunflower industry in Australia from the importation of other oilseeds. So the researchers have been reluctant to spend money on oilseeds.

A great deal of oilseed research has gone towards funding new oilseed industries. In particular, there is the rape seed industry, which was developed in Victoria, South Australia and the southern Australian States. Central Queensland sunflower growers, with some justification, have felt concern that their levy moneys have been used to fund an alternative industry which has then moved around and taken away their market share. The central Queensland farmers argue that if there has been some assessment that there is no future in the sunflower industry in Australia—I might add that I contest that assumption—and that other crops have greater potential, at least the money they have put into research and development should be spent on other industries which can perhaps provide an alternative source of income for the farmers of their region.

Whilst there will be no specific ownership of funds by an industry or on a State basis, I am now pleased to note that the Grains Research and Development Corporation will be required to report on where its funds are coming from and where they are spent. In other words, there will be a greater degree of transparency and therefore an assurance that farmers are satisfied that the money they contribute to research is spent in an area that is likely to be beneficial to them and not just given to benefit others and have the effect of taking away their industry share from them. The Grains Research and Development Corporation will be providing information by way of its annual report on where funds have come from and where particular allocations have been made.

There has been general support within the rural industry for the changes proposed in this Bill. Everyone agrees that we need to spend more money on research. When times get tough in a rural industry and when the farmers can least afford to provide additional money, they become additionally conscious of the need to do better in the various practices associated with their industry. They want better varieties, they want to do things more efficiently and they want other aspects of their industry to be the best possible. They acknowledge the vital role of research in ensuring that we have the best possible practices.

Industries also accept that they will have to pay if they want research done in their particular industry. There is no free money around these days. When a company or commercial operation contributes money for research, naturally it wants to achieve some benefits or commercial advantage from that research. Industries also know that, if research is done in their particular industry, they will have to pay for that research. The levies in the primary industry sector, in particular, were established on the principle that those levies would be matched dollar for dollar by the Federal Government. That has been a principle associated with each of the new primary industry levies as they have come into existence and it has enjoyed bipartisan support. That has also been a fundamental factor in attracting industries into the research and development organisation that has existed. I suspect that if it had not been for the availability of that Federal Government money, many industries would not have so willingly embraced the idea of levying themselves for research.

Even though we talk about dollar for dollar funding, in practice the Government does not quite give a dollar for a dollar. There are certain limits on the amounts it will provide. Also it does not match everything that the growers supply but rather the funds that are actually spent on research. I note from the Grains Research and Development Corporation's annual report that growers contributed $12.5m in that financial year, but the Government's contributions—even though they are theoretically dollar for dollar—amounted to only $8.9m. Nonetheless, the Government's contributions are appreciated.

The Government also benefits from rural research. It benefits from the increased productivity. It benefits because many of the research establishments would otherwise be funded by other government programs. The universities and State departments also benefit because farmer funded research helps to provide them with experts; it helps to train the people who will be the future educators, the future researchers of our country.

Therefore, it was particularly disappointing to read and to hear in the lead-up to the current Federal Budget that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) actually proposed to slash Government funding for rural research. I was amazed that anyone in the Government would break ranks on this important issue and propose, in a Budget with a $13.5 billion deficit, that a few million dollars should be saved on rural research. I thought it was a rather petty-minded approach; certainly lacking in any kind of foresight for the future. I was very pleased that someone in the Government at least had enough commonsense to hit that proposal on the head and that the Government has proceeded in the current Budget with the normal funding arrangements for rural research. So my compliments to those on the Government side who had the foresight to see the wisdom of continuing these particular arrangements.

Under the new arrangements for collecting these levies on an ad valorem basis, some industries will pay considerably more for rural research than they pay currently. The fixed levy of $2 per tonne on peanuts, for instance, under a one per cent ad valorem levy is likely to rise to something of the order of $5 per tonne. That is a considerable additional commitment for peanut growers. Mung bean growers who currently pay only $1.25 will move to a levy of something of the order of $3 per tonne—obviously depending on the price that prevails at the time. Growers of several other leguminous crops and also oilseeds will pay additional money as a result of this legislation but, from what I can ascertain, those industries are prepared to accept those additional commitments because of their acknowledgment that rural research is so important for the future of their industries.

One difficulty that has not been adequately addressed in the legislation or in the Minister's second reading speech—and I hope the Minister will provide some enlightenment on this matter tonight—is the difficulty under this legislation of calculating what is the farm gate price to determine the one per cent ad valorem levy. There are various factors which will have to be taken into account. It is not just a simple matter as in the case of wheat, sorghum or some other crops where the farm gate price is readily calculated and in most instances is basically the same as the sale price. In many of these oilseed and legume crops there is a lot of processing and grading that must actually be done before the crop becomes marketable. For instance, peanuts with aflatoxin in them are absolutely worthless at the farm gate. It is only after they have been blanched, well and truly after they have left the farm gate, that they become valuable.

Someone will have to determine what the real farm gate value of these sorts of commodities is. Oilseeds and legumes have differing oil contents. There are multiple grades. The futures contracts involved may affect the actual end price of the crop and alter the relativity between its actual market price and its farm gate value. There are market price movements and those become particularly significant in crops where there is pooling or blending of particular farmers' produce. Of course, some of these products are produced in relatively small batches and they are not actually weighed at the farm gate. The actual return to the farmer comes many months later after it has been through an extensive processing phase.

The Bill provides no information on how the farm gate value is to be calculated. Even though the Grains Council of Australia supports this legislation, it has not been able to provide any technical information on the way in which these calculations will be made. As I said, it is easy for bulk commodities. It will not be so simple for these types of crops where frequently a lot of value adding is done before the farmer receives his return.

I point out as well that the volume of production of some of these crops is quite small. Only a few hundred or a few thousand tonnes are produced, and in some cases perhaps 10 or 20 tonnes. Therefore, to calculate the various rates involved will require quite a deal of mathematical assumptions. I hope this issue can be adequately addressed in the context of the passage of this legislation through the Parliament.

The cost of administering rural research and development in Australia is also a matter of some concern to the industry. We have a complex system of committees involving various State based committees as well as the central research and development corporation. We have committees to select committees and the bureaucracy associated with the administration of research in this country seems to grow year by year. The cost of selecting the Grains Research and Development Corporation was put in its annual report last year as $73,489. It cost us $73,000 just to choose the committee in the first place. Then, according to the Grains Research and Development Corporation report, Corporation members were paid $428,850 in fees and expenses during the year. The executive director is on a salary of over $110,000 per annum. Indeed, the total Corporation activity costs, according to the Budget, were $1.25m in that year. In addition to that, there were administrative costs of $1.07m.

So, to distribute just $16.7m worth of funds for research, over $2m was spent in administration costs. We have to look very seriously at whether we are in fact spending on administration more of the growers' money, which they want to spend on actual research, than can reasonably be justified. I appreciate that there were some initial setting up costs in this first year, but unless the Grains Research and Development Corporation can get its costs under control, increasingly there will be questions asked about whether or not this is an effective way to administer our research dollars.

Questions are often asked about the way in which the funds are spent. Again, turning to the annual report, it is interesting to note that the State departments of primary industries were the major beneficiaries of the farmers' financial levies. Over $9m of the research and development payments last year went to the State departments, a further $2.3m went to Commonwealth organisations, and tertiary institutions received $4.4m, leaving less than $1m to be spent by other independent institutions.

One cannot help but be concerned that the State departments of primary industries are winding back their efforts in research and their whole service to the primary industry sector and ask whether this is not yet another illustration of States balancing their budgets by using Commonwealth funds and farmer levies. I do want to denigrate in any way the quality of work done by State departments of primary industries, but the State departments should not be allowed to get away with reducing their own efforts by taking up the additional contributions provided by the Commonwealth and the farmers themselves.

As a Queenslander, I note with concern the winding down of the activities of the Queensland Department of Primary Industries since the election of the Goss Labor Government. There is stacks of money for thousands of additional public servants around the place, but the Queensland Department of Primary Industries has been denuded of staff, particularly in this research and development area. The State departments have done some excellent work. They have been responsible for much of the developmental work of the oilseed and leguminous crops about which we are talking today. If it was not for their pioneering work, most of these industries would not exist in Australia. So we need to be proud of what those departments have achieved.

As a navy bean grower, I think of people such as Eric Gallagher, who largely developed the upright varieties of navy beans that were responsible for the revitalisation of the industry in the 1960s and 1970s. I also think of others who have carried on that kind of research work: for example, the people who have been associated with the development of new peanut varieties over recent years—departmental staff, dedicated and talented people, who have been the catalyst for the growth and development of so many of the industries that are the subject of this legislation this evening. They have done some tremendous work with cooperating farmers. We need to acknowledge that and to express gratitude to the researchers who have put into effect the kinds of projects that farmers have actually needed and wanted.

It is important that this research be practical, that it be farmer oriented, that it be the kind of thing that is actually likely to develop improved returns to growers in the field and not be just academic mumbo jumbo which keeps a couple of university scientists in work. Farmers will need to be sure that their research and development money is wisely spent. They are unlikely to want to continue to contribute levies unless they are sure that they are getting value for money. This particular legislation helps to ensure that all farmers will contribute equally to the research and that it will continue for their own benefits. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr LLOYD
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Honey Legislation (Repeal and Amendment) Bill 1992 terminates the Australian Honey Board from 1 January of next year and transfers certain of its functions to the Australian Horticultural Corporation.

PARA.TAB: The Honey Board has operated for some 30 years, but the Government announced that it will terminate the board and transfer some of its functions to the Australian Horticultural Corporation until 30 June 1995, when the Horticultural Corporation and that arrangement will be further reviewed. To a certain extent, this was a result of the Davis Review Committee on Commonwealth Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities, which reported that the smaller marketing authorities, including the Honey Board, faced high costs relative to the income provided by levy on producers.

The Honey Board had been operating on a budget of $500,000, about half of which went in administration costs. The honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) made the point very tellingly in his comments on the previous legislation that it is very important that the administration of these organisations, corporations or whatever, is kept under control so that the value of the levies paid by producers is there for research, marketing, promotion or other purposes.

The gross value of production of the honey industry is about $40m, with 40 per cent going for export. I think that is a very good example of a small but very effective and efficient industry in relation to its contribution to our international trade and balance of payments. If we had more of those sorts of industries, particularly outside agriculture, which could say that they were as competitive as honey and were making their contribution to either exports or import competition to the same degree as the honey industry, we would not have this horrific balance of payments problem that we have at present.

One of the roles of the Honey Board was the setting of a minimum export price for bulk honey, but that was not effective because Australia had only about one per cent of the world trade, and the Board no longer appointed overseas selling agents.

The industry, represented by the Federal Council of Australian Apiarists Associations and the Honey Packers and Marketers Association of Australia, negotiated the changes with the Government. It is in agreement with the legislation and has requested that the Board be terminated at the end of this year. The Australian Honey Board Review Committee, established to consider future options, wanted the Board abolished, but recommended the continuation of domestic promotion, consumer education, quality assurance and information dissemination through the Australian Horticultural Corporation.

Research and development will continue through the Honeybee Research and Development Corporation. One raises here again whether or not there is a cost effective situation with a small industry like that, or whether it is better placed under the umbrella of the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation or, for that matter, some other organisation. That is up to the honey industry itself to determine.

The change is expected to save the industry about $100,000 a year in administration costs. As this industry is becoming more involved in commercial pollination, the closer association with horticulture could be beneficial. The marketing component of the honey export charge is being repealed and should save growers a further $70,000 a year. It was considered that this amount was too small for generic export promotion particularly, as I indicated earlier, as most exports are in bulk for branding overseas.

The honey industry will need to monitor the new arrangement to ensure that it is cost effective and that it is worth while for it to be part of the Horticultural Corporation. The Horticultural Corporation itself will need to be reviewed to see that it is performing a cost effective role for that range of horticultural industries which it has under its umbrella. The coalition supports the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on this adjournment to remind honourable members that six weeks ago two young Australian citizens, Iddin Gillespie, aged nine, and his sister, Shah, aged seven, were taken from their home by Raja Bahrin Shah, their biological father and prince of the Malaysian royal family, for an access period scheduled to last two nights.

PARA.TAB: Since that time, which was 5 p.m. on Thursday 9 July 1992, Mrs Jacqueline Gillespie, the children's mother, now married to Ian Gillespie, a resident of Melbourne, has not seen or had contact with her children. Despite a Family Court order that the children be allowed to phone home at least once a day, there have been no phone calls. On Saturday 11 July, Mrs Gillespie informed the Federal Police that it appeared the children and their natural father had not been at their hotel, the Victoria Hotel in Melbourne, for two days.

From that time, the kidnapping of the Gillespie children has been marked by three distinct characteristics: firstly, the incompetence of Australian authorities in preventing the kidnapped children from leaving the country; secondly, the obvious collaboration of Indonesian authorities in the kidnapping; and, finally, the failure of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, to take any strong line on this matter whatever.

We have all heard something of the story of how the children were spirited from Australia in an Indonesian fishing boat through the Torres Strait into Irian Jaya and thence on to Malaysia. However, few people know the inadequacies which were to follow in alerting Coastwatch. On Monday 13 July at 11.55 p.m., Mrs Gillespie was visited by two Federal Police officers assigned to the case, Sergeant Graham Downs and Constable Fiona Pedersen of the Federal Police Family Law Squad in Melbourne. The children's stepfather, Ian Gillespie, asked the officers whether authorities such as Coastwatch had in fact been alerted. He was assured that they had been.

During the meeting on that night of Monday 13 July, Mrs Gillespie was also asked whether the royal family had access to yachts or light planes. She told them that they probably had and again asked the officers whether Coastwatch had been notified of the search. The officers assured her that they had notified Coastwatch and added that they had already said that to her husband. Again, on the night of Thursday 23 July 1992, Mrs Gillespie asked whether Coastwatch had been alerted and was assured by Assistant Commissioner Walter Williams of the Federal Police that it had.

On Tuesday 28 July, an Australian helicopter pilot, Colin Ferguson, arrived back in Australia and told the media that the children had flown from Irian Jaya to Sulawesi in Indonesia. Some days later, Coastwatch announced that it had heard distress signals from an Indonesian fishing boat which had drifted out of control for four days in the Torres Strait. Coastwatch aircraft had circled the boat after hearing distress calls mentioning that two children were aboard, but the pilots were unaware of the alert mounted by Federal Police. The Federal Police are reported in the media as admitting they had not informed Coastwatch or other similar authorities.

The fishing boat was heard to radio in English for a specific Indonesian Army colonel, the Indonesian military forces Commander-In-Chief at Irian Jaya, to rescue them. On 20 July, the Indonesian military towed the disabled motor cruiser into Merauke in Irian Jaya. On the same day, two plane loads of Australian officials were inexplicably detained at Merauke, forbidden access to their aircraft and followed everywhere they went by armed guards.

Senator Evans's wimpish stand in this matter is well documented. He has continued to insist publicly that it was a private matter and not a Government matter. Mrs Gillespie has not been allowed to talk to her children and the Australian Government is refusing to help. Mrs Gillespie and thousands of other Australians believe she should not have been put in the position of having to submit her fate and her children's fate to Malaysian law. To the best of Mrs Gillespie's knowledge, a minimum of 10,000 petitions, each bearing between 10 and 20 signatures, have flooded into the office of Senator Evans and other Ministers. Literally hundreds of letters have also been sent to the Gillespies from people outraged by the Government's inaction regarding the rights of the Gillespie children.
In conclusion, I support the call by my colleague the shadow Minister for foreign affairs, Senator Hill, for a full Senate inquiry into this disgraceful matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —When Parliament sat last I named 47 occasions in south-west Queensland where contractors and graziers underpaid Australian shearers. Since that time I have been informed that in relation to those 47 cases $14,500 has been collected in underpayments to those Australian shearers. I have also been informed that since I last spoke Graeme Bruce has been convicted of 15 breaches of the award and B.J. Hammonds has been convicted of a further 10 breaches of the award.

PARA.TAB: The President of the UGA, Bill Bonthrone, and W.J. Turner, the industrial relations officer, have said that I claimed that Hammonds was a grazier and that he had underpaid workers. Nowhere have I ever said that, either in this House or outside it. I said that he was guilty of breaking the award, which is industrial law.

The UGA said that purposely to try to discredit what I have said and to take pressure off the fact that there is a conspiracy in this country to break our industrial relations system by bringing in New Zealand refugees, who are leaving New Zealand to come here, and coercing them into working in the shearing industry right across this country. They are taking away Australian jobs by breaking the award and working for less than award conditions. I acknowledge in the House tonight the Australian shearers who cannot get work for that very same reason.

The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has now joined the fray in supporting the UGA and criticising the industrial awards of Queensland. It is ironic that not allowing weekend shearing in Queensland should be criticised by both the honourable member and the UGA, because over the last 12 months the United Graziers Association has had the opportunity through the Industry Commission to apply to vary the award. But it never sought to do so. The UGA did not seek to do so because it knew that some of its members and contractors were flagrantly breaking the award themselves. Therefore the Association saw no reason why it should go to the industrial arbitrator and find out that it may have to pay a little bit more in the base rate to get what it is claimed should be the rate for weekend shearing.

Yesterday my committee met with graziers from Victoria who also shear. They said that they are totally opposed both to weekend shearing and to breaking the award system. It is quite obvious that there is a massive difference in the pastoral industry of this country between the squatters and the battling farmers who have a different perspective on this whole issue.

Further, this is part of the conspiracy to break down the award conditions that we have in this country, as we have seen in New Zealand. Australian shearers are paying the price. As I have said in this House before, we have seen a massive campaign to support the buying of Australian wool, and I support that, but I also support the employing of Australian labour at award rates of pay and not breaking down the conditions for which we fought for 100 years.

Following on from that, on Monday in Toowoomba the Cattlemens Union is going to meet. The Bauhinia branch, which is run by lackeys in the National Party, will be calling for me to resign from the chairmanship of my committee because I am exposing law-breakers in the pastoral industry—just like I exposed drought rorters over the last five years who ripped off $30m from the same property owners and graziers. But not a word was said at that time when their own industry lost $30m; not a word was said when local government lost $40m in transfer charges under the National Party Government in Queensland; and not a word was said when the NDRA was used as a slush fund by the National Party. It had the hide to side with law-breakers.

Along with an idiot like Bill Bonthrone, the President of the UGA, these clowns from the Bauhinia branch still think that the 1832 reform Bill was never brought in to allow people franchise and that the landed gentry run this country, as they did in England at that time. Well, they do not and we do have a democracy. Such calls from National Party organisations like the Bauhinia branch have no substance any more than do hillbillies like Bill Bonthrone, the head of the UGA, who support law-breakers like Hammonds, Blue Shearing Services and a parasite named Graeme Haycroft, who is the head of Troubleshooters, an organisation that intends to destroy the award conditions of this country.

It is important to recognise that rural Australia does not consist of just the squattocracy; it consists of battling farmers, Australian workers and shearers, pensioners and small business people. At the present time in the pastoral areas of this country a lot of our money is going back to New Zealand; it is not being spent in Australian towns. What the UGA and the hillbillies in the National Party are doing is a disgrace. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise an issue concerning small operators in the mining industry—people who, over the past 20 years or so, outlaid an average of $6,000 to set up eductor dredging operations. The idea was that the dredges provided access for the first time to gravels along the beds of streams. In many of the areas which were intensively prospected and mined for gold in the last century, the stream beds remain untouched and offer small scale operators the best chance of finding gold in worthwhile quantities. The development of the eductor dredging system triggered renewed interest in the search for gold, as well as tin and gemstones, in many areas of Australia.

PARA.TAB: To explain how the system works, the operator has a small compressor on the surface, while a diver uses a pipe or flexible hose to direct a high pressure jet of water into the stream bed. The water jet loosens gravel and other material and generates a suction force which picks up the loose material and discharges it into a sluice floating on the surface. After it has been screened for gold, the material is put back in the same area of the stream.

But towards 1980, this mining activity came under pressure from conservation groups. Licensing was introduced in 1980 for dredging operators in Victoria. The industry has been banned in Victoria since November 1989, and I understand it is not now permitted in most other areas of Australia, with the exception of parts of Queensland.

Many people who have operated eductor dredges are members of the Prospectors and Miners Association, which has endeavoured to represent their interests to governments and respond to the arguments of conservationists. To give honourable members an idea of the extent of this activity, the Gippsland branch of the Association in my electorate is aware of 100 people who have operated eductor dredges and indicates there may be several hundred more in that area alone.

Mining activity of this nature is a State jurisdictional matter, but the Association believes that, because there has been widespread interest in stream dredging across Australia, people generally should be more aware of the issues involved and there should be a more coordinated national approach to the industry.

In Victoria, eductor dredging was examined broadly by an interdepartmental committee in 1987 and a more detailed study was conducted in 1987-88 by a working group from ministries concerned with mining, conservation, water resources and environment protection. The working group reported that no long term environmental damage could be established as a result of stream dredging. It recommended dredging continue at its existing level at that time on a small number of streams. But then, around the time of the 1988 election, the Government amended the Mines Act to provide that no more licences would be issued. There has been no eductor dredging in Victoria since late 1989 and the Victorian Minister has told miners repeatedly that he sees no reason to review the position.

The concerns of the Prospectors and Miners Association are, firstly, that the ban was imposed, as it seems there were bans put into effect in other States, without scientific evidence to show that dredging causes environmental damage. The Association says the experience of its members and the information they have gathered indicate that eductor dredging does not mobilise loose materials within a stream. It argues that floods, the use of boats and vehicle access to areas adjacent to streams cause more environmental problems than dredging.

Secondly, all dredging activity was stopped without a proper hearing. People directly affected by the ban were simply not consulted, and the Association submits, quite forcefully and reasonably, that miners should have been entitled to a full public hearing before such a dramatic step was taken. The case of the miners has hardly been given fair consideration. This is a similar situation to that in which landowners in the timbered areas of Victoria, such as East Gippsland, found themselves under the Victorian Labor Government's punitive restrictions on the clearing of native vegetation.

The ultimate legislation on land clearing incorporated significant amendments moved by the State coalition parties to provide a more workable system which takes account of conditions in the various regions of the State. But in the first instance the restrictions came into force overnight under a blanket amendment to the State's planning regulations. Landowners have been working on long term plans to clear areas of their properties for commercial production and those who bought properties on the understanding they could be cleared found their operations frozen.

There were numerous stories of people who faced financial ruin because their lifetime's development and management strategies had been overturned at the stroke of a pen. The timber industry in Gippsland has faced a similar battle of wits to avoid the quicksands of shifting government policy over the past decade.

The last people to be given an equal say in the outcome of these policy shifts are those directly concerned—the people in the resource rich areas whose families and communities depend on reasonable access to natural resources. They have no desire to see the landscape laid to waste, but rightfully expect a proper balance in the management of public land and for their interests to be given equal weight.

The same is the case with the people who, until 1989, had been involved in dredging for gold. There is some suggestion that people with dredging equipment have continued to operate in some isolated areas since the ban came into force, but I am not aware of any having been detected and charged. The majority have been forced to abandon their mining activities and let their equipment gather dust. In quite a number of cases miners and prospectors have lost their livelihoods and are on the unemployment scrap heap.

From my information, it was possible, with equipment worth around the average amount of $6,000 and a reasonable knowledge of prospective gold-bearing areas and dredging techniques, to net gold worth tens of thousands of dollars in a season. There have been people who have earned a reasonable living, but they are unable to do so because they have been shut out of the industry without a fair hearing and without scientific evidence. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I need your indulgence. I intend to use the word `spiv'. If it is unparliamentary, I will use `frauds' instead. I refer, of course, to those arch frauds Irene Moss and Mr Burdekin.

PARA.TAB: Madam Deputy Speaker, I was intending to make the speech tonight but, looking at it, I see that I cannot possibly get it into five minutes. I will delay it until the grievance debate and get it on the air, because I think these things need to be publicised much more.

Instead, I want to support tonight the remarks of my colleague the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) who spoke on the shearing situation in Australia. I think that people ought to reflect on what is happening. The consequences of this very short term policy are devastating for a lot of small farmers. In many parts of the country, the small farmers are also shearers. They supplement their incomes and in fact acquire and finance their farms through the money they get from shearing. This is now a source of income denied to them and, with the present economic situation in the rural areas, the effect is quite devastating not only on them but on the economy of Australia as a whole. I think it is appalling that some of the agro-political organisations are so short-sighted that they are jumping at what they see as an opportunity to squeeze the cost of shearing in the short term.

I notice that Peter Lee—who was at one time the President of the WAFF, the Western Australian Farmers Federation, aptly known as the `wafflers'—is very much for the New Zealand shearers. Peter Lee is interesting because he is now a candidate for the Liberal Party on the upper house ticket for the State Parliament. Peter Lee was also a trustee of the Western Australian Farmers Federation. As a trustee, he was responsible for the money that was contributed by way of bonds by farmers. It is common knowledge now that the Western Australian Farmers Federation is broke and that bond holders are not going to get their money. In the normal course of events, he as trustee would be liable for that money. This would presumably send Mr Lee broke and he would not be able to hold a place in Parliament. But have no fear, he will get over that and I am sure that he will appear on the Liberal Party ticket. It just goes to the integrity of this matter. A person whose competence is demonstrated by the results that now flow from his folly is one of the people recognising the New Zealand shearing situation and urging farmers to employ this New Zealand labour.

Is it in the best interests of farmers? I would submit it is not. I was told recently by very successful farmers in the western districts of Victoria that last year, using Australian shearers, they had their very best shearing ever. They said in terms of real costs it was the cheapest shearing and they were very happy with the results. They said that they, like everyone else, had looked at using the New Zealand labour but they found out that there were a lot of hidden costs involved. While they would shear cheaper, they were demanding to work longer. This put an intolerable strain on their own staff. They either had to pay them a lot of overtime to start earlier and work later or the staff simply jacked up or broke down through the pressure. They said that shearing was traumatic enough at any time, they wanted a smooth shearing operation and they would not enter into these sorts of negotiations.

They also said that because of the reduced prices a lot of the shearers were what they described as very scruffy. The shearing was not of a good quality. It is interesting to note that one does not find these fly-by-night New Zealand shearers shearing the difficult sheep in the difficult country. They go for the easy shearing in the easy country where they get the big tallies.

This is not a denigration of all New Zealand shearers, because some of the greatest criticism I have had of the present situation is from New Zealand shearers who have made a commitment to Australia. They have come to Australia, they live here, they pay their taxes to Australia and they strongly resent the people who are ripping off Australia. It must be remembered that if New Zealanders were to return to New Zealand—I have many in my electorate; those who can vote I am sure will vote for me, but most do not vote—there would be about 25 per cent unemployment in that country. The reality is that New Zealand is exporting unemployment to Australia and we sit back and accept it like mugs.

We have to do something about this. It is quite clear that the Liberal Party would never act, and I am beginning to doubt the capacity of this Government to act on what is a long overdue reform. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I draw to your attention that I have finally hung in my office a patchwork that was designed and created by the Wonthaggi Patchers, as they are called. The Wonthaggi Patchers are people in my electorate who have a great talent in craft. They spread from Phillip Island all the way to the beautiful township of Wonthaggi and surrounds.

PARA.TAB: They have created a patchwork, at my request, to hang in my office in Canberra that reflects absolutely the electorate. It shows the fauna and flora of the electorate, the colours of the electorate, the sea and the sky. The Wonthaggi Patchers took the time to come up here to Canberra some six months ago to check the colour of the walls so that the background of the patchwork would be applicable to my office. Today has been a good day because the patchwork has been hung in my office. I am proud to say that I have in my office craft work from people of great talent in my electorate.

Every one of us has people of talent in our electorates, whether they be shearers, farmers, small business people or, in my case, manufacturers. In my electorate there are 50 or so people who have combined together to create artwork from their own hands, their own talent, their own design and their own energy. Hundreds of hours went into the making of this patchwork. They charged me for it, which was acceptable.

The best part was that I attended a community day in Wonthaggi where all the community services and volunteers were showing their wares—what they do for the community—to the township of Wonthaggi. There were people from Federal Government departments, State government departments, local initiative groups and local welfare groups. They asked me—a Liberal—to come and open the community day because there was a view that I actually cared about what was happening in my electorate, and I do. I also care about the fact that I now have some 13,000 people unemployed in my electorate. When I was elected I had 2,000. If honourable members do not think that causes some pain, it does.

The tragedy of my electorate is similar to many of the electorates around Australia. The Government, as addressed to me in Question Time by the Minister for Local Government (Mr Simmons) today, argues that it has thrown $15m at my electorate for infrastructure development. There is a view this evening that the Government has double counted on the figures—we will check that tomorrow morning—and included some of the funds for Isaacs, Corinella, Holt, Dunkley and even perhaps McMillan all in the same figures. If that is the case, what was going to be of great benefit to my community is now going to be a total debacle and the Minister should resign. Perhaps we are giving him forewarning that he may have an answer by tomorrow morning.

I return to the Wonthaggi Patchers who have put together a rather marvellous piece of artwork that includes all the animals that exist in my electorate, including the penguins. If I am accused of being the member for penguins or celery, I am very happy that anybody would remark of me in that way about the electorate of Corinella, because I have some pride in the work these ladies have done. Their talent is exceptional; they have shown real class in their craft. Not only have they extended themselves but they have extended themselves for the benefit of their community. I have made the promise, which will be fulfilled, that the piece of artwork will be returned to them in some 25 years time on my retirement from this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of the points that were raised earlier by the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Broadbent) with respect to double counting of figures are fairly significant and need to be followed through. Clearly, the figures that have been provided by the Minister for Local Government (Mr Simmons) with respect to allocation of funds to the electorate of Isaacs show a figure of $4,524,000 for the city of Springvale. I have some 300 houses of the city of Springvale in my electorate, and when one looks at the size of that city and an allocation of that amount of funds, one has to really wonder.

PARA.TAB: When one looks at the figures that were allocated for the electorate of Corinella and one goes through the municipalities that appear in that particular area, one comes to the municipality of Springvale and finds an allocation of $4,524,000. It is shown in each of those figures and it is also shown in the figures for the electorate of Dunkley.

Whilst the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) is carrying on about the figures, the fact is that in the allocation for individual electorates that has been put out by the Minister, he is quite happy to show that there is an allocation of $6,224,241 for the electorate of Isaacs. He has allocated the same sort of system for each of the abutting electorates. If he wants to put out those figures as a misrepresentation of the allocation of funds that are going into the electorates of Isaacs, Corinella, Dunkley and others, I suggest we have a very close look at them.

One has to look at the variation in figures between the city of Springvale and the Pakenham Shire. On one set of figures for the Pakenham Shire that have been presented by the Minister there is an allocation of $4,524,016. It is rather interesting that that is for the shire of Pakenham on one set of figures, and on the other side, the figure for Springvale is $238,924. These are two sets of figures that have been presented. On the other side we have an allocation in reverse where the city of Springvale has those figures.

I also find it very interesting when we look at the city of Moorabbin. The city of Moorabbin has a number of unemployed who would actually use the CES office in the city of Oakleigh, which is where the figures come from, and we find that there is no allocation whatsoever. The city of Sandringham in my electorate has no allocation whatsoever. When we start to get to rubbery numbers, I have some major concerns as to where all these figures lead and what the Minister is trying to do with these figures.

I have a genuine concern to try to provide some income for the constituents of the electorates that I represent. When these sorts of figures are presented as the means upon which constituents of mine in the various municipalities are going to receive some sort of incentive and some sort of opportunity to get jobs, I think that the representation has been somewhat of a sham.

The allocation of funds within my electorate is presented by the Minister as being around $6m. I will take only a part of Chelsea in my electorate. It has an allocation in excess of $1m. The percentage for the city of Chelsea will be somewhat less than half of that, so we are looking at half a million dollars. What is provided for the city of Mordialloc is $500,000. We really have about $1m which will be provided for the electorate of Isaacs and not some $6m that is provided by way of the municipalities. I think it would be fair for the Minister to explain that process. I am not arguing with the process of people getting funds to try to generate jobs in the area, but I think we need the whole process cleared up as soon as possible.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Sullivan)—Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I require that the debate be extended.
—The debate may continue until 11.10 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons The Hon D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to the comments made by my Opposition colleague the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson) in respect of the table that I provided to the House today concerning the allocation of the local capital works program. The important thing that perhaps the honourable member for Isaacs has not realised—and he is a reasonably new member of this House—is that these particular grants include capital works programs for councils where there is an overlap of electorates.

PARA.TAB: Local government areas do not necessarily coincide with Federal division boundaries. For example, tomorrow I will be announcing the financial assistance grants for Victoria. They have already been provided for a number of States and the Commonwealth. Honourable members on both sides of the House would be aware that where there is a council wholly within a Federal division the financial assistance grants and the local road council grants are provided for that council.

Going back to the point I made earlier, where there is an overlap within the electorate, clearly some councils are shared between neighbouring members. If one adds up all of the figures on the chart which I have indicated, one will see that there is more than the $345m that was announced by the Government. I am simply saying—and honourable members are not realising this—that there is an overlap of Federal divisional boundaries with local councils.

I cannot speak for Opposition members who have not bothered to check with my office about the specific details, but certainly included within the Federal division of Isaacs is the local government area of Chelsea, which has been allocated $1,145,781 on a notional basis. Partly included within that division is the Springvale Council area with a $4,524,016 notional allocation, and wholly within the division of Isaacs is the Council of Mordialloc, with $554,443.

If I had presented these figures and just included the Council of the City of Mordialloc, the honourable member for Isaacs would have had very good reason to get up in this House and accuse me of not providing the full information about council boundaries within his Federal division. As I have said on a number of occasions, the financial assistance grants which are provided to honourable members take into account the fact that there are overlaps within Federal divisional boundaries with local council boundaries. All I can say is that people have not bothered to check the full details as to the way in which these grants are allocated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you mislead the House today?

—I have not misled the House at all. People have suggested that in the case of the electorate of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) the allocation of $20m is wholly within the Federal division of Blaxland. The fact remains that the Federal division of Blaxland includes councils which overlap with other Federal divisions. Clearly, a number of councils are included within those areas.

PARA.TAB: All I can say, without wanting to detain the House for much longer, is that people should look very closely at their Federal divisional boundaries. My office is more than happy to provide the information if people want it. Many honourable members from the Opposition have actually contacted my office, with a great deal of enthusiasm, for these figures. The more experienced members of this House have realised that there is an overlap of divisional boundaries with local government boundaries.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Sullivan)—Order! The Minister's time has expired. He may speak for another five

SPEECH.PARA: minutes if no other Minister is seeking the call.

TALK.START.PARA: —If honourable members are in any way concerned to learn more about the specific allocations for entire local government councils within their Federal division or for part councils within their division, all they have to do is to contact my office and they will find that we will willingly provide the information. All I can say is that people are seeking to use this information simply to reinforce some of the comments that have been made by the Leader of the Opposition and other spokesmen from the Opposition who have sought to portray the fact that this program is solely aimed at Government marginal seats. The facts are quite the opposite. All members have to do is to check the facts for themselves.
