TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 9 May 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many persons, by sub-program and post, are expected to be admitted to Australia under the (a) refugee and special humanitarian and (b) new special assistance programs.
(2) Do the figures referred to in part (1) represent a variance from the 1990-91 programs; if so, (a) in which areas and (b) for what reasons.
(3) What criteria will be used to determine entry under the special assistance category.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The notional allocations under the overseas Refugee and Special Assistance stream were 5,600 places for Refugee and Special Humanitarian and 4,000 places for the Special Assistance Category, with a further 2,400 places allocated to resident status cases. Refugee and Special Humanitarian Program categories take precedence in allocations over the Special Assistance Category. Regional allocation figures for the 1991/92 Refugee and Special Humanitarian categories, together with outcomes for 1990/91 and 1991/1992, were:
*plus 1290 visas issued in Lebanese concession category which in 1991/92 were subsumed under the Special Assistance Category.

Under the new Special Assistance Category up to 4,000 places were made available to be distributed among: ethnic minorities of the former Soviet Union; displaced persons from the former Yugoslavia; East Timorese in Portugal and Lebanese. Notional allocations and outcomes were as follows: (see table opposite)
I would stress that allocations for 1991/92 were provisional planning figures only and subject to change according to needs that emerged through the year. This is reflected in the outcomes.
AllocationOutcome

(2) There were significant variations downwards between the 1990/91 visa issue and the allocations made and actual outcomes for 1991/92 in the Refugee and Special Humanitarian Program categories for both Indochina and Central America. In the case of Indochina the decrease reflected the effect of implementation of the Comprehensive Plan of Action covering Vietnamese and Lao asylum seekers. In Central America there have been a number of significant and positive developments which have been conducive to greater regional stability. There was an increased allocation for the Middle East in the aftermath of the Gulf War.

(3) General criteria for the new Special Assistance Category focus on two main elements: the degree of distress suffered by an individual as a result of severe civil disorder or violence or the fact that they are a member of a disadvantaged or repressed minority; and the extent of their link with Australia. There will also be individual sub-program criteria specific to each group to ensure that selection is centred on those in greatest need of assistance.

The introduction of the category reflects the decline in resettlement need in respect of our traditional refugee and special humanitarian programs, coupled with continuing high numbers of people in situations of humanitarian concern worldwide. Only a minority come within the terms of the United Nations Convention definition of a refugee. For the most part those of international humanitarian concern are the victims of generalised violence, civil disorder, collapse of state authority and other events affecting wide segments of a country's population.

In addition to the millions of people displaced across national borders, many more are displaced or otherwise suffering severe distress within their own countries. A significant number come from countries with a strong community connection with Australia. Many individuals involved have family in Australia.

In the light of strong community support for Australia's humanitarian intake and the continuing need for humanitarian assistance around the world, the Government has taken action to ensure that our ability to respond is not artificially constrained by problems of definition. The new Special Assistance Category is designed to allow us to reach groups who are in situations of real need, have a special need to settle in Australia but who do not fit the United Nations definition of a refugee or our traditional programs.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 2 January 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) To what extent do commercial and other forms of Australian shipping or boating currently make use of the US Department of Defense's Global Positioning System (GPS).
(2) How dependent are global ship or boat movements on access to the GPS.
(3) What are the technical advantages of access to the GPS over other conventionally available positioning systems.
(4) Do those who have purchased an appropriate receiver have free access to the satellite system or is there a commercial agreement, such as payment of royalties on purchase of a receiver.
(5) What is the stage of development of the GPS and when will it be fully operational.
(6) What interruptions to access to the GPS have been recorded or experienced since access has been made available by commercial means.

(7) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to any (a) interruptions to the availability of access to the GPS by Australian shipping or other boats between November and December 1991 and (b) other planned outages or down time in 1992.
(8) Is there any mechanism by which those using the GPS are made aware of interruptions to access; if not does this constitute a threat to safety at sea.
(9) Has a threat to safety at sea ever resulted from the unavailability of the GPS.
(10) If the unavailability of the GPS without prior notification constitutes a threat to safety at sea, what is the range of potential concerns or mishaps which could result.
(11) What alternative means are available to mariners to fix their positions accurately should the GPS be unavailable without prior notification.
(12) Is the Commonwealth taking any steps to ensure that there is adequate notification or advanced warning of the unavailability of the GPS.
(13) Can the warnings referred to in part (12) be broadcast through any existing radio network.
(14) Do the manufacturers or distributors of navigation equipment which enables access to the GPS undertake to advise purchasers of the likelihood of interruptions to the system.

(15) Are the manufacturers or distributors advised of interruptions to access to the GPS; if so (a) what steps do they take to disseminate the information to purchasers and (b) are there any voluntary or compulsory agreements which require manufacturers or distributors to disseminate the information; if not, are such agreements required.

(16) Is the US Embassy in Australia informed of planned downtimes or outages in respect of access to the GPS; if so, is the embassy willing to make the information available to the Commonwealth and other relevant bodies.

(17) Is the Commonwealth informed of planned downtimes or outages to the GPS; if so, (a) which Government bodies are made aware of or monitor the outages or downtimes and (b) what efforts do they make to disseminate the information.
(18) Does the Government use the GPS for its own purposes; if so, what are the details.

(19) Are there any reasons why the access to the GPS may be denied to mariners possessing the relevant receivers; if so, (a) what are the reasons and (b) are purchasers of receivers made aware that access may be denied.
(20) Was the availability of the GPS affected in any way by hostilities during the Gulf War.
(21) Are purchasers of receivers made aware as a condition of purchase that access to the GPS is prone to interruptions.
(22) Within what price range are appropriate receivers available commercially.
(23) What military or related function does the GPS serve.
(24) Does the accuracy of the information relayed through the GPS in respect of position differ in accuracy from that made available to commercial or recreational shipping or boating.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Although many ships and boats are apparently making use of GPS, I have no data on the extent of use. Fitting of GPS receivers is not a mandatory requirement for ships under Commonwealth legislation.

(2) I am unable to indicate how individual ships and boats rely on GPS. Despite its very considerable advantages, GPS provides but one of a number of means of navigating. Vessels should not rely absolutely on a single navigation system.
(3) The main advantages of GPS are high accuracy of position fixing and continuous availability throughout the world.
(4) All users have free access.

(5) The US Department of Defense has stated that the GPS constellation will be declared fully operational when the prescribed number of satellites are functioning in their assigned orbits. I understand this is expected to occur in 1994.

I am aware that there were interruptions to the availability of GPS during the period 22-24 November and 29 November-1 December 1991 due to testing activities. I do not have information on interruptions prior to November 1991 or on planned outages or downtime in 1992.

(8) The Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA), through its Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre, issues advice to shipping on GPS interruptions as Australian Navarea X warnings. The US Department of Defense has cautioned users to the effect that, until the system is declared operational, any use of the system is at the user's own risk.
(9) I am not aware of any such situation.
(10) The unavailability of GPS should not constitute a threat to the safety of life at sea.
(11) Other means have been available for many years. These include visual aids to navigation, various radio navigation systems, radar, dead reckoning and astronomical navigation.
(12) AMSA has requested the US Department of Defense to provide advice of planned outages. As appropriate, this information is promulgated as Navarea X warnings.
(13) Yes. Relevant navigation warnings are broadcast by the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre through the AOTC Maritime Communication Station Network and the Inmarsat Satellite SafetyNET system.
(14) I am not aware of what advice individual manufacturers, distributors and retailers of GPS equipment may give to purchasers.
(15) I am unaware of arrangements between the US Department of Defense and manufacturers and distributors of GPS equipment.
(16) I do not know whether the US Embassy receives this information. The information which AMSA receives on downtimes and outages is not received through the US Embassy.
(17) See answers to (12) and (13).

(18) GPS is used by a number of Commonwealth bodies for various purposes. Within my portfolio for example, GPS is used as a navigational aid by AMSA on its vessel Cape Moreton. The system is also used on board the research vessel Rig Seismic, operated by the Department of Transport and Communications on behalf of the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics.
(19) The US Government policy is that the Standard Positioning Service level of GPS will be available to all GPS users on a continuous, world-wide basis.
(20) GPS was available to all users throughout the duration of the Gulf War.
(21) See answer to (14).
(22) I understand that prices range from about $2 000 to $15 000 depending on the level of sophistication required.
(23) This is not a matter which falls within my portfolio.

(24) The US `1990 Federal Radionavigation Plan' published jointly by the US Departments of Transportation and Defense, identifies two levels of service provided by GPS. The Standard Positioning Service (SPS) is available to all GPS users, including commercial, recreational shipping or boating. The Precise Positioning Service (PPS), which provides a higher level of accuracy than SPS, is made available by the US Government only to users authorised by the US Department of Defense.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did Mr Robertson represent the Commonwealth's interests before the New South Wales Royal Commission inquiring into productivity in the building industry in late 1991; if so, what are Mr Robertson's legal qualifications.

(2) Is he able to say whether sworn testimony was given before the Royal Commission that (a) the Master Builders' Association (MBA), with the knowledge of the NSW Building Services Corporation, was party to misappropriating funding for an MBA apprentice scheme and (b) millions of dollars had been diverted directly to MBA accounts.
(3) Did Commissioner Holland grant the Commonwealth access to certain documents for perusal.
(4) Was the MBA group apprentice scheme initiated in 1977 to operate on a non-profit basis.
(5) Is he able to say whether evidence was given before the Royal Commission that the group apprentice scheme has been very profitable to the MBA.

(6) Has the Commonwealth provided funding to the MBA apprentice scheme; if so, (a) what sum has been provided in each State and Territory since 1982, (b) has the Commonwealth examined MBA annual reports and called for audit reports before contributing funds and (c) will action be taken to recover any Commonwealth funds which have been misappropriated.
(7) Will the Government examine Commonwealth funding of other apprentice schemes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am advised that Mr Robertson represented the Commonwealth's interests before the New South Wales Royal Commission and that Mr Robertson is a barrister in practice at the NSW, Queensland and Northern Territory Bars.
(2)(a) I am advised that there was no such sworn testimony.
(2)(b) I am advised that sworn testimony was given that the MBA scheme was generating large surpluses which were used for the general purposes of the MBA.
(3) I am advised that Commissioner Holland granted the Commonwealth access to certain documents for perusal.
(4) I am advised that the scheme was promoted by the MBA as a non-profit scheme.
(5) I am advised that evidence was given to the Royal Commission that surplus funds, generated by the MBA scheme, were treated as profit by the MBA.

(6) I am advised as follows. The only funds provided by the Commonwealth to the MBA in relation to apprentices were payments under the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training (CRAFT) scheme. Payments under that scheme are available to all employers of apprentices, such as the MBA. The payments are not required to be expended for any particular purpose.
(6)(a) I am advised that the information requested is not readily available and would take some time to obtain.
(6)(b) I am advised that the Commonwealth did not require applicants for funds under the CRAFT scheme, such as the MBA, to provide annual reports or audit reports.

(6)(c) I am advised that the Commonwealth is aware of no evidence to support any allegation that any funds paid to the MBA by the Commonwealth under the CRAFT scheme were improperly paid. As the CRAFT scheme did not require the funds to be used for any particular purpose, no question of misappropriation of Commonwealth funds arises.
(7) I am advised that the position is as follows.

All group training schemes funded for administrative purposes by the Commonwealth and State/Territory governments under joint policy arrangements, are required to submit Annual Reports and independently audited financial statements to governments each year. In addition, there are government representatives on the management committees of all schemes, who are able to undertake regular monitoring of financial and operational arrangements.
Governments will examine the funding arrangements of schemes where it is deemed appropriate and necessary to ensure sound financial management in accordance with the joint government policy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is he able to say whether sworn evidence was given before the New South Wales Royal Commission inquiring into productivity in the building industry that the Master Builders' Association (MBA) has received secret commissions involving (a) successful tendering for multimillion dollar projects and (b) compensation for unsuccessful tenderers.

(2) Is he able to say whether any of the secret commissions referred to in part (1) have involved Commonwealth tenders since 1982; if so, (a) is he able to say what sum the Commonwealth has been defrauded and (b) will he instigate criminal proceedings.
(3) Is he able to say whether the activities of the MBA as described before the Royal Commission are hampering the Government's efforts to promote the housing industry.
(4) Will the Commonwealth inquire into malpractice in the area of the building industry concerned with domestic dwellings.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) I am advised that sworn evidence was given before the Royal Commission that the MBA has received secret payments from successful tenderers on large construction projects.

(1)(b) I am advised that no evidence was given that the MBA has received compensation for unsuccessful tenderers. However, I am advised that evidence was given that MBA officers arranged and were present at meetings of tenderers during which agreements were made that the successful tenderer would make payments to unsuccessful tenderers. Also, I am advised that evidence was given that the MBA sought to collect unsuccessful tenderer fees from the successful tenderer on behalf of its members and that the MBA may have set-off in its accounts monies owed by a successful tenderer to an unsuccessful tenderer both of whom had MBA accounts.
(2) I am advised that some of the alleged payments referred to in part (1) are believed to have involved Commonwealth tenders since 1982.
(2)(a) I am advised that the Commonwealth does not have precise figures at this stage.
(2)(b) I am advised that matters arising from the Royal Commission are under investigation by the relevant Commonwealth agencies.

(3) I am advised by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services that, because the Royal Commission focused on the commercial building industry, specific effects of the MBA's activities on the housing sector are not identified. However, the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services has indicated that the Master Builders'—Constructors Housing Association Australia, representing the Master Builders movement throughout Australia, has been, and is expected to continue to be, an active and positive participant in housing policy issues.
(4) I am advised that any such inquiries would be a matter for State and Territory Governments.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Administrative Services: Employment Goals

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 28 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: Following the Prime Minister's pledge at the start of the One Nation strategy to fight the battle against unemployment and for economic recovery with all the energy he can muster, is the Minister's Department giving pre-eminence to the goal of growth of employment in Australia in its corporate planning and policy development; if so, (a) how is pre-eminence being given, (b) in what ways is the goal being implemented and (c) are there any departmental activities which are inconsistent with maximising employment growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: The corporate planning and policy development activities affecting employment growth in Australia are in two main areas—purchasing policy and in DAS' own staffing.

In relation to purchasing, the Australian and New Zealand supplies policy encourages Government buyers to actively seek out local suppliers and to channel business in their direction where goods and services offered represent value for money. An example of initiatives in this area is the "Offshore-What for" campaign, which successfully raised the awareness of senior Commonwealth executives and purchasing staff of the value of buying Australian goods.

To raise awareness in suppliers and manufacturers about this Government's policy to assist our Australian and New Zealand suppliers, the Department has mounted a "Make it in Australia" campaign. The Department is active in opening doorways of opportunity for local suppliers to access the $12 billion a year Commonwealth Government market.

These activities support import replacement strategies and aim to increase employment in Australia and New Zealand. The Department works closely with the Industrial Supplies Office to help achieve these objectives.

The Government's recently announced policy for quality assurance in Commonwealth purchasing will help give conforming Australian and New Zealand companies competitive advantage in domestic and overseas markets, because it is based on nationally and internationally recognised quality system standards.

In relation to DAS' own staffing, the focus is upon implementation of the Government's objective that the Department achieve full commercial levels of performance in the delivery of its services. This objective is consistent with the Government's broader economic objective of achieving sustainable long-term employment growth through strengthening the competitiveness of the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 28 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: Following the Prime Minister's pledge at the start of the One Nation strategy to fight the battle against unemployment and for economic recovery with all the energy he can muster, is the (a) Anti-Dumping Authority, (b) Australian Industry Development Corporation, (c) Australian Manufacturing Council, (d) Automotive Industry Authority, (e) Export Finance and Insurance Corporation, (f) Industry Research and Development Board and (g) Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority giving pre-eminence to the goal of growth of employment in Australia in its corporate planning and policy development; if so, in each case, (i) how is pre-eminence being given, (ii) in what ways is the goal being implemented and (iii) are there any organisational activities which are inconsistent with maximising employment growth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (a) to (g), (i) & (ii). The Government firmly believes that growth of employment will only occur through the development of a more efficient and competitive economy. Hence the Government's industry policy objective is to develop industries which are internationally competitive and can contribute to raising the standard of living for all Australians. The thrust of the policy has been to progressively reduce the emphasis on protection while adopting a range of measures to assist in the restructuring and modernisation of existing industry and the development of new areas of activity.

ANSWER.PARA: My Department and agencies within my portfolio are actively working to implement the Government's industry policy.

PARA.TAB: (a) to (g), (iii). There are no organisational activities which are inconsistent with the Government's goal of maximising growth.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 28 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: Following the Prime Minister's pledge at the start of the One Nation strategy to fight the battle against unemployment and for economic recovery with all the energy he can muster, is the Trade Practices Commission giving pre-eminence to the goal of growth of employment in Australia in its corporate planning and policy development; if so, (a) how is pre-eminence being given, (b) in what ways is the goal being implemented and (c) are there any organisational activities which are inconsistent with maximising employment growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a)-(c) The role of the Commission is to discharge its statutory functions under the Trade Practices Act. In so doing, the Commission seeks to achieve a competitive and efficient environment in which opportunities for economic growth and benefits to consumers are maximised.

The Government has recently announced proposed changes to the Trade Practices Act which will enhance competition in Australia: in particular it has decided to change the merger threshold from one of dominance to that of a substantial lessening of competition. Healthy competition and prevention of anti-competitive conduct are necessary factors in an efficient economy, which will, of course, lead to increased job opportunities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 28 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: Following the Prime Minister's pledge at the start of the One Nation strategy to fight the battle against unemployment and for economic recovery with all the energy he can muster, is the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation giving pre-eminence to the goal of growth of employment in Australia in its corporate planning and policy development; if so, (a) how is pre-eminence being given, (b) in what ways is the goal being implemented, and (c) are there any organisational activities which are inconsistent with maximising employment growth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) The most effective means of addressing the problem of unemployment and pursuing economic recovery in Australia in the longer term will be to make Australian industries and enterprises internationally competitive and innovative. The resulting economic growth based on increased exports and import replacement will provide a substantive means for employment creation.
In the process of making Australian industry more competitive and more innovative, CSIRO is playing a pre-eminent role.

CSIRO's main task, as set out in the Ministerial Guidelines provided to CSIRO under section 13 of the Science and Industry Research Act 1949 on 2 June 1988, is the conduct of research in support of national economic, social and environmental objectives.

By directing its resources to those areas which will generate the maximum returns to Australia, CSIRO will make a substantial contribution to the government's strategy for reducing unemployment and achieving economic recovery.

(b) The recently released CSIRO Strategic Plan which covers the period 1991-92 to 1995-96 maps out the way ahead for the Organisation over the next five years, and indicates substantial benefits from research conducted during that period for the benefit of all Australians.

This CSIRO Strategic Plan reflects the Organisation's first attempt to establish research priorities. The process of setting priorities involved assessment of the benefits flowing from adoption of the products of research and CSIRO's capacity to deliver research outputs, in 17 research areas corresponding to the principal sectors of the Australian economy as well as major areas of community concern.
In assessing the return to Australia from its research effort CSIRO accounts for two major factors:

attractiveness, which combines the potential economic, social and environmental benefits for Australia and Australia's ability to capture the benefits by converting technological progress into commercial or other gains; and
feasibility, which combines technological progress that could be potentially accomplished and the nation's and CSIRO's ability to achieve that progress in a timely way.

ANSWER.PARA: Therefore, CSIRO's resource allocation decisions over the long term give much consideration to the benefits likely to flow to Australia from the research, as well as the feasibility of the research. Present and projected economic situations in Australian and world markets are factored into the research priority decisions.

PARA.TAB: CSIRO will continue to be a significant contributor to economic growth, through growth of new products and industries and hence the creation of new jobs. For example, assessments of the benefits flowing from recent CSIRO research include:
$500 million from aluminium research;
$2 billion from research on ten projects for the rural plant industries
$420 million from five research projects for the rural animal industries.

In addition, estimates of the expected benefits from planned outcomes of CSIRO's R&D in the minerals and energy area amount to $2500 million a year. This includes the establishment of a coal-bed methane industry in Australia and the spread of the SIROSMELT technology at the rate of at least two new installations a year.

As an increasing number of Australian firms recognise that they can only become world competitive by investing in technology and skills, the benefits of CSIRO research will become more widespread. With commitment and determination to the upgrading of technology and skills, Australia will ensure a future characterised by employment growth and prosperity.

(c) CSIRO is committed to research in support of national economic, social and environmental objectives. As a result of its rigorous identification of research priorities and their implementation through the CSIRO Strategic Plan, the Organisation is well placed to deliver innovations to Australian Industry over the next five years. These will aid in the generation of increased production of goods and services for the domestic and international markets and the commensurate growth in employment. Among the high priority areas identified was research on the `environmental aspects of economic development'. Major new international opportunities in this area will provide considerable growth in employment. Australia is well placed to capture a significant share of this growth.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 28 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: Following the Prime Minister's pledge at the start of the One Nation Strategy to fight the battle against unemployment and for economic recovery with all the energy he can muster, is the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission giving pre-eminence to the goal of growth of employment in Australia in its corporate planning and policy development; if so, (a) how is pre-eminence being given, (b) in what ways is the goal being implemented and (c) are there any organisational activities which are inconsistent with maximising employment growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the following answer in response to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, through an array of programs, is making a significant contribution to reducing Aboriginal unemployment throughout Australia.
The current Corporate Plan of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in its Statement of Purpose includes the following words:

"ATSIC will work towards the achievement, in the longer term of a situation of justice and equity where Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders have sufficient economic and social status to enjoy fundamental civil, social and economic rights."
The Corporate Plan also summarises the program structure which includes amongst its program objectives and strategies the following words:

"In terms of employment and economic status the Government has introduced the Aboriginal Employment Development Policy (AEDP). This policy includes a number of measures which take account of the different aspirations and employment needs of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders arising from markedly different social circumstances and cultural values and the concentration of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in rural and remote areas where there are few or no mainstream employment opportunities".
The Commission is currently revising its Corporate Plan and it is intended that similar emphasis will be given to employment matters.

The Community Development Employment Projects Scheme (CDEP), which enables communities to convert the aggregate Jobsearch and Newstart entitlements of community members into grants for projects which provide meaningful employment, is the Commission's largest single program.

Grants are currently made to 185 CDEP projects which provide employment for over 20,000 participants. Project activities are determined on the basis of community priorities and include, inter alia, the production and marketing of art and craft, environmental and horticultural projects, and construction activities relating to housing and community development.

In response to recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, the Commission is developing proposals for a program to provide employment for up to two years in Aboriginal organisations for unemployed young people with the objective of improving their work-skills and thereby their employment prospects.

Following a review of the Aboriginal arts and crafts industry, the Commission has commenced implementation of a strategy to improve industry performance for the benefit of Aboriginal artists. The art industry provides employment and income to several thousand Aboriginal people. Through improved resourcing of community infrastructure, co-ordination and promotion, the strategy is designed to maintain and, if possible, expand employment opportunities.

The Government decided in December 1992 to transfer from the Department of Employment, Education and Training to the Commission, responsibility for the community based elements of the Training for Aboriginal Program. The Commission commenced administering community training and employment programs on 1 July. These programs will involve an expenditure of about $50 million in 1992/93.

Where the Commission delivers programs which are not directly aimed at Aboriginal employment (eg. infrastructure in remote communities, health services), there are invariably significant positive spinoffs for Aboriginal employment.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Fraser Island and Great Sandy Region

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 7 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the federal Government agreed to the use of Commonwealth funds provided under the Fraser Island and the Great Sandy Region World Heritage listing compensation package for the purchase of the Orchid Beach Resort on Fraser Island.
(2) Has the Queensland Government purchased the resort for $5 million.
(3) What are the World Heritage values of the small Orchid Beach Resort site.
(4) Has the Government decided against demolishing the resort; if so, how will the resort be used.

(5) Were between 20 and 30 jobs lost as a result of the decision to close the resort; if so, were the jobs included in the list of jobs lost as a result of World Heritage listing of Fraser Island; if not, why not.

(6) Will the Hervey Bay and Rainbow Beach communities be compensated for the loss of (a) the jobs referred to in part (5) and (b) income to local businesses previously supplying the resort; if so, by what sum.

(7) Did the Government state that World Heritage listing would lead to a tourism boom for the Fraser Island area; if so, is the closure of one of Fraser Island's leading resorts consistent with that statement.
(8) Will the Government close any other tourist resort facilities on Fraser Island.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No Commonwealth funds were used for the acquisition of the Orchid Beach Resort.
(2) I understand that the Queensland Government has purchased the resort for $5 million.

(3) The site of Orchid Beach is part of the Fraser Island-Cooloola sand mass. The natural values of that sand mass have been nominated against all four natural criteria of the World Heritage Committee Operational Guidelines as follows:
(i) be outstanding examples representing the major stages of the earth's evolutionary history; or
(ii) be outstanding examples representing significant ongoing geological processes, biological evolution and man's interaction with his natural environment; or
(iii) contain superlative natural phenomena, formations or features or

(iv) contain the most important and significant natural habitats where threatened species of animals or plants of outstanding universal value, from the point of view of science or conservation, still survive.
(4) The Commonwealth Government has made no decision on the future of the resort.
(5) This is a matter for the Queensland Government.
(6) This is a matter for the Queensland Government.
(7) The Commonwealth Government has no record of making such a statement regarding this nomination.
(8) The Commonwealth Government has no plans to close any tourist resorts.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 26 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) On what date was the National Food Authority Act 1991 proclaimed.

(2) What matters relating to the drafting or promulgation of food standards, whether arising from proposals or applications, were the subject of recommendations by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) to the National Food Standards Council (NFSC) but on which the NFSC had not made a final and unanimous decision by (a) 19 August 1991, (b) 7 November 1991 and (c) the date of commencement of the National Food Authority Act 1991.

(3) In respect of each matter referred to in part (2), on what date was the recommendation finally made to the Ministerial Council by the National Food Authority in accordance with the procedures laid down in the National Food Authority Act 1991, as amended by section 31 of the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Act 1991.

(4) Which of the matters referred to in part (2) were referred to the Ministerial Council and had been queried or rejected by at least one State Minister and in each case, what were the (a) details of the matter, (b) concerns of the State Minister and (c) outcome.
(5) On what date and by what means were State and Territory governments informed of the federal Government's intentions to amend section 71 of the National Food Authority Act 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (2)(a) All the matters covered by Amendment 12 to the Australian Food Standards Code.

(b) With the exception of certain amendments relating to the use of diffusion extracted material from oranges, all the matters covered by Amendment 12 were supported by eight of the nine members of the National Food Standards Council. The ninth member did not respond on any of the matters. On the issue of the use of diffusion extracted material from oranges, of the eight members who replied, one reserved his position. No further response was received.
(c) Same as for (a) above.
(3) No recommendations were made by the National Food Authority to the National Food Standards Council in respect of Amendment 12.
(4) See answer to (2)(b) above.
(a) One State Minister reserved his position in respect of the amendments relating to the use of diffusion extracted material from oranges in fruit drinks, soft drinks and cordials.
(b) The Minister did not indicate what his concern, if any, was.

(c) The outcome was that Amendment 12, including the amendment relating to the use of diffusion extracted material from oranges, was adopted into the Australian Food Standards Code by majority decision.

(5) The State and Territory Governments' nominees on the National Food Authority Advisory Committee were informed of the intention to amend the National Food Authority Act at the National Food Authority Advisory Committee meeting on 19 December 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 26 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did he state in response to a question without notice (Hansard, 4 May 1992, page 2250) that a tax rebate or deduction was of no value to a family if it could not find a child-care place and that the Government's national child-care strategy is focused on the two aims of affordability and supply.

(2) Did he reject an application by the Sigma Pharmaceutical Company in Perth for a grant of $40 000 to assist the provision of 19 child care places for their staff and other nearby businesses, including Telecom; if so, why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) Yes. The Commonwealth does not provide capital grants to employers who provide child care for their employees. The Commonwealth does however provide Fringe Benefits Tax exemptions to employers who provide child care on their business premises and tax concessions for operating costs and depreciation.
Under the National Child Care Growth Strategy, capital grants are available only to approved non-profit sponsors.
The Commonwealth also provides fee subsidies (based on family income) to families using employer sponsored child care services.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 26 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the future of the Army's ammunition park adjacent to the residential development of Roxburgh Park in outer urban Melbourne been decided.
(2) Will the depot be located to a more suitable location; if so, (a) where will it be relocated and (b) when; if not, why not.
(3) If the depot is to remain in its current position, will the Government assure the local residents in writing that they will be in no danger from the depot.

(4) Is there any where else in Australia where an active ammunition depot is situated adjacent to a residential development; if so, have there ever been any accidents or danger caused to residents because of the depot's proximity.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Defence facility adjacent to the Roxburgh Park development is a Navy ammunition depot. The future of the depot has not yet been determined although current planning is that it will be relocated at some time in the future, but not in the immediate future.

(2) The Government has not yet made a decision on an appropriate alternative site, on the eastern seaboard, and provision of an alternative facility could take five to ten years. The establishment of a Defence ammunition depot is a complex issue. Any decision on the location of a new facility requires careful development particularly in regard to environmental, safety and security issues, as well as logistics and budgetary aspects. In addition, negotiations with State and local authorities where required, will involve wide ranging consultation.

(3) The Somerton depot has been used to store explosives since 1942. The explosives are stored in compliance with stringent safety standards that are internationally recognised. These standards have been reviewed by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, and examined by the Australian National Audit Office, and their use has been approved by the Government. Independent audits are conducted to ensure compliance with these standards. The safety of existing and proposed residential developments is not compromised by the explosives that are stored at the Somerton depot.

(4) In Australia there are six active ammunition depots owned by the Department of Defence situated adjacent to residential development. These depots were sited and constructed long before residential development occurred. Specialist staff applying current safety standards keep abreast of local developments. Residential activity is kept under review to ensure that standards and safety are not compromised. The management of these depots is subject to monitoring by independent technical authorities and is also subject to separate safety audit to ensure that safety policy is not compromised.

The Department has no record of any accidents resulting from the proximity of the six depots to residential areas. Danger to residents is kept at an absolute minimum by the application of stringent safety standards which are internationally recognised.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 1 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did a delegation representing the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) and the Wool Council recently attend a world textile manufacturers' conference in South America.
(2) Did a large delegation from the Australian wool and textile industries also attend the conference.
(3) Did the industry delegation travel business class.
(4) Did the AWC and Wool Council delegation travel first class; if so, (a) why, (b) was the cost borne by wool growers and (c) what was the cost.
(5) How many delegates from the AWC and the Wool Council attended the conference and who were they.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Representatives of the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) and the Australian Wool Realisation Commission (AWRC) attended the International Wool Textile Organisation Conference at Punte del Este, Uruguay in April 1992. The AWC Chairman attended as a representative of the International Wool Secretariat (IWS). Representatives of the Wool Council of Australia, which is a producer organisation, also attended this Conference.
(2) I am informed that over 30 delegates from the Australian wool, textile and exporting industries attended the conference.
(3) It is not appropriate for me to comment on the travel arrangements of delegates from industry organisations.
(4) It is not appropriate for me to comment on the travel arrangements of delegates from the Wool Council.

(a) In regard to the AWC and the AWRC the situation is: the AWRC Chairman, the AWC Chairman and the AWC Managing Director travelled first class. The terms of appointment for persons holding these positions accord them this standard of travel. The second AWRC representative travelled business class.

(b) The cost for the AWRC Chairman was met by the AWRC operating budget which is partly met from wool tax. The costs incurred by the Chairman of the AWC were paid by the IWS, given that an IWS Board meeting coincided with the IWTO conference. The IWS is indirectly funded by wool growers. The cost for the AWC Managing Director was met by the AWC, which is largely funded by wool growers.

(c) The cost of first class air travel for the AWRC Chairman was $12,481, for the AWC Chairman $9,266 and for the AWC Managing Director $7,297. The discrepancy in airfares was caused by the different routes which had to be taken as a result of the different commitments of the persons concerned.

(5) Two representatives of the AWRC attended the Conference—the Chairman, Mr David Clarke and the Director—Europe, Mr Jacques Vanderhaeghen. Two delegates from the AWC attended—the Chairman, Mr Mac Drysdale and the Managing Director, Mr Barry Jackson. I am informed that two delegates from the Wool Council of Australia also attended the conference, Mr Alan Bowman, the President and Mr James Hoadley, the Executive Director.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 3 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: Further to his answer to a question without notice on 28 May 1992 (Hansard, page 3093), has the Government re-examined its decision on cost recovery in respect of safety regulatory services provided by the Civil Aviation Authority; if so, will the Government proceed with cost recovery for air safety.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins announced on 7 May 1992 that the Government was to re-examine its decision on cost recovery for safety regulation due to the efficiency gains achieved and foreshadowed by the Civil Aviation Authority. The issue is still under consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 3 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to (a) a submission from the Japanese Tour Wholesalers Committee of Australia seeking a labour agreement to facilitate entry into Australia of 2000 Japanese tour guides, (b) the high levels of unemployment in Australia at present, particularly amongst young people and (c) the many secondary and tertiary institutions offering training in Japanese language and culture for Australian students.

(2) If so, will he ensure that no Japanese nationals are granted temporary entry visas to work in Australia as tour guides, unless it can be clearly demonstrated that there are no Australians reasonably capable of taking these jobs.

(3) Will a detailed labour market assessment of the present and future demand for tour guides in the tourist industry be carried out; if so, will the labour market be extensively tested to ensure there are no unemployed Australians who could not reasonably be expected to be employed as tour guides following an intensive training program.

(4) If there is a need to import tour guides, is he able to state what training plan the Japanese Tour Wholesalers Committee will implement to ensure that in future there will be an adequate number of Australians with qualifications to act as tour guides.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) My department has received a proposal from the Japanese Tour Wholesalers Committee of Australia to fill a large number of tour guide positions in Australia with Japanese temporary residents. There has been no decision reached about the number of Japanese temporary residents who may be permitted entry; to date, the focus of discussions has been the total number of Japanese speaking tour guides, both Australian residents and Japanese nationals, required by employers in Australia over the next few years. Employers' overseas recruitment needs have not yet been quantified.

The proposal has been the subject of discussions with, amongst others, the Departments of Employment, Education and Training and Industrial Relations, the Australian Tourism Industry Association, the Inbound Tourism Organisation of Australia and the trade union movement. Discussions with the appropriate parties are not yet complete.

Training, labour market and industrial issues must be satisfactorily addressed before the Labour Agreement can be concluded; there will only be an Agreement if there is endorsement from all the major parties involved, that is, government, employers and trade unions.
(1)(b) and (c) Yes.

(2) It remains government policy that Australian employers may have access to overseas recruitment to meet their skilled labour needs only where appropriately skilled Australian citizens and permanent residents are not readily available from the local labour market or through employers' own training efforts.

(3) My department is awaiting advice on the labour market aspects of the proposal, in particular, from the Department of Employment, Education and Training. The availability of appropriately skilled Australian citizens and permanent residents who are capable of being retrained for tour guide employment will also be the subject of assessment.

(4) If a labour agreement is concluded with the Japanese Tour Wholesalers Committee it will facilitate the development of a tour guide workforce strategy for a significant sector of the tourism industry and involving government, employers and trade unions. Employer commitments under consideration for inclusion in the Labour Agreement to achieve this include:
an interchange program for Australians involving all companies party to the Labour Agreement
a program to promote accredited Japanese language courses throughout the tourism industry within Australia, together with an analysis of future employment opportunities

a scholarship program for Australians to study in Japan, funded by individual sponsorships by companies involved in the Agreement and/or from fees payable towards the management, monitoring and training by participating companies
enhancement of professional recognition of tour guides through relating this program to the Tour Guides Accreditation Scheme
development of a work experience program for Australians within Japanese companies operating in Australia
a monitoring program which reviews the effectiveness and success of the above programs on a continuing basis.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 24 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What sum did the Australian Manufacturing Council (AMC) spend on advertising (a) in total and (b) in (i) print, (ii) television, (iii) radio and (iv) other forms of advertising in (A) May and (B) June 1992,
(2) What forms of advertising other than in print, television or radio were used.

(3) What portions of the sums referred to in part (1) were contributed by (a) the Minister's Department, (b) private industry, (c) government business enterprises or statutory corporations and (d) unions.
(4) Who contributed towards the expenditure referred to in part (1) and how much did each contribute.
(5) What sum will the AMC spend on advertising in 1992-3 and what forms of media will be used.

(6) Did the AMC undertake a fund raising program in 1991-2 among businesses, government authorities and unions to contribute towards its advertising expenditure; if so, (a) what form did the approach for contributions take and (b) which organisations were asked to contribute.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Manufacturing Council (AMC) spent $558,531 on advertising for the first phase of its Community Education Program. Of this amount, nil was spent in May and $119,994 in June 1992. Of the remaining $438,570, $191,616 will be spent during July and $246,954 during August 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: asked all portfolio Ministers, upon notice, on 24 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) For which (a) government business enterprises, (b) statutory authorities, (c) agencies, (d) authorities and (e) fee-charging or income-producing organisations does the Minister have portfolio responsibility.
(2) With respect to each organisation referred to in part (1), (a) how many staff are employed, (b) which principal Acts relate to its operation and (c) what are its major assets.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 25 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: Has an incident been reported to the Department of Transport and Communications regarding the flight of a Cargolux 747 freighter which departed Brisbane International Airport at approximately 10.20 a.m. on Tuesday, 9 June 1992, using the Lara Vale 5 route and bound for Perth; if so, what (a) were the circumstances of the incident and (b) action has been taken against the carrier.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

However, no report of any incident concerning the flight has been received by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, which is required to be notified of any such events within 48 hours of the occurrence.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 25 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: Is the Department of Transport and Communications re-examining departure procedures at Brisbane Airport to ensure that minimum noise is inflicted on nearby suburbs; if so, (a) does the review include maximum use of departures over Moreton Bay and (b) when will new procedures be introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: This is a matter for the Civil Aviation Authority which regularly reviews departure procedures at Brisbane Airport to ensure that minimum noise is inflicted on nearby suburbs. As recommended by the Brisbane Airport Task Force the practice of directing as many aircraft operations as practicable over Moreton Bay in preference to residential areas is continuing. The proportion of operations that can be achieved over Moreton Bay is subject to weather and other operational constraints. But for the month of June 1992 only about 1% of night-time jet movements were take-offs or landings to or from the south over Brisbane. The procedure of jet aircraft taking off over the Bay and reaching an altitude of 5000ft before flying over residential areas is now in practice and has been incorporated into the CAA's Noise Abatement Procedures.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 25 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Laravale 5 standard instrument departure route from Brisbane Airport to be re-examined and relocated.
(2) Will the departure path be relocated over vacant land between Hemmant, Queensport and Murrarie to ensure that Hemmant is avoided.
(3) When will the review of the departure route be undertaken and new routing introduced.

The Task Force recommendations pertaining to preferred flight paths have been implemented and there is currently no proposal to re-examine the Laravale 5 departure route.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 25 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: Did Army Reserve (ARes) Brigadier G.B. Standish prepare a report for Army headquarters following an examination of the problems of preserving the employment, social and financial status of ARes members in the event of being called out; if so, (a) what were the major findings in the report, (b) what attention has the report received and (c) which recommendations will (i) be accepted and when and (ii) not be accepted and why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Brigadier Standish's report has been received by the Assistant Chief of the General Staff—Personnel.
(a) The major recommendations of the report are in the following table.
(b) The report has been disseminated for comment to Headquarters Australian Defence Force (HQ ADF), Navy and Air Force Offices, and within the Army. The majority of comments have now been received.

(c) A Reserve Structure Review is required to report to the Chief of the Defence Force (CDF) by February 1993 on measures required to update and rationalise the various forms of the Reserve and make recommendations to amend supporting legislation. It is expected that a number of the report's recommendations will be examined during this review. The majority of the issues raised will also be put to the Assistant Chief of the Defence Force (Reserves) for consideration by the Joint Reserves Policy Coordination Committee. The draft Terms of Reference of this Committee enable it to consider and make recommendations on all matters affecting Reserves across the ADF. Until the report is examined in further detail under these mechanisms, it is not possible to state which recommendations will be accepted. A copy of the report has been provided to Mr Downer MP.
1. The implications of an escalation must be taken into account when considering the recommendations in the Report.
2. Recommendations should be the subject of appropriate cost/benefit assessment.
3. Tri-Service consideration should be given to the Report.
4. Existing call out legislation needs to be reviewed to ensure continuity of call out and that an individual Reservist can be called out for up to 12 months.

5. Army should either better administer the Inactive Australian Army Reserve and communicate to its members their call out obligations or amend the current call out obligations in the Defence Act to remove their liability.

6. The regional nature of the Army Reserve should be taken into account in considering the implications of call out and that policy and organisational solutions, as well as legislative solutions, should be pursued. However, 'protected industries, or 'reserved occupations' are not recommended.
7. It is necessary to have more binding legislation powers to enforce the call out of the Reserves in situations short of defence emergency or war.

8. As a general principle, the basic conditions of service of all who are on full-time duty in the ADF during a period of call out should be the same. Individual exceptions to this principle should be clearly justified.

9. In consideration of the protection of the civilian interests of Reservists, a minimum of 28 days 'preliminary notice' should be provided in general, with provision for individuals to volunteer for lesser periods.
10. An integrated system of structure and employment policies is needed to permit individual exemptions.
11. Reservists should be required to declare their personal circumstances annually and re-affirm their availability for call out in case of defence emergency or war.
12. Before the Army Reserve call out process starts, a system is required which removes the current rights of all members of all parts of the Army to take discharge.

ANSWER.PARA: STRUCTURING AND TASKING OF THE ARMY RESERVE

PARA.TAB: 13. The Army Reserve should be structured and tasked to facilitate exemptions.

14. Before exemption mechanisms are introduced, further research is required into how many Reservists might seek exemption, and estimates need to be made of the administrative load of processing individual requests for exemption.
15. An exemption appeal process is required through either the member's chain of command, or recourse to a Tribunal, or perhaps both.

16. The guiding principle in developing employment protection measures for Reservists should be that neither Reservists nor their employers should be disadvantaged, relative to other employees or employers not affected, once the Reservists have been released after having been called out.
17. The following employment-related principles for the basis of employment protection should be adopted:

ANSWER.PARA: a.employers are not to hinder or prevent employees from serving in the Reserve or Emergency Forces;
b.employers are not to discriminate against employees, or penalise them, by reason of or on account of their service in the Reserve or Emergency Forces;
c.employers are not to permanently fill an employee's position during any period of absence, either on non-voluntary training or when called out, as a member of the Reserve or Emergency Forces;

d.at the employee's request, employers are to fully reinstate an employee, who is a member of the Reserve or Emergency Forces, following any period of absence either on non-voluntary training or having been called out, as if the employee had not been absent;

e.no employee, who is a member of the Reserve or Emergency Forces, is to be prevented or hindered from resuming his employment within a reasonable time following any period of absence either on non-voluntary training or having been called out;
f.employers are not required to pay an employee, who is a member of the Reserve or Emergency Forces, during any period of absence related to that service;

g.employers are not required to make any superannuation or like payments on behalf of an employee, who is a member of the Reserve or Emergency Forces, during any period of absence related to that service;
h.all employers, including the State and Federal Governments, are bound by these principles;
i.enforcement orders may be made or penalties imposed by the Courts for breach of these principles;

j.employees who are members of the Reserve or Emergency Forces and believe they have been disadvantaged by breach of any of these principles by their employer, may seek enforceable redress, relief and/or compensation; and

k.employers who employ members of the Reserve or Emergency Forces and believe that they are disadvantaged by application of these principles, may, even if they are receiving some other directly-related advantage, seek enforceable redress, relief and/or compensation.

PARA.TAB: 18. Principles for the general rehabilitation and re-establishment for all ex-Service personnel should be developed in advance of a major defence emergency or war, to be a guide during the national reconstruction effort.
19. The following options could be developed to provide employment protection for self-employed Reservists and Reservists involved in small business:

ANSWER.PARA: a.assuming one can be found, obtain a replacement with or without the provision of financial assistance;
b.pay compensation and/or provide other relief for loss of earnings in their business (whether or not a replacement has been obtained);

c.allow flexibility in the application of the call out provisions so that call out for continuous full-time service can be limited to times and periods when the impact will be minimised and acceptable to the Reservist and/or the employer;

d.limit call out to a part-time basis, and do not deploy those affected from the vicinity of their normal business address, so that they can continue in their civilian employment or continue to run their business, as well as render Reserve service;
e.exempt the self-employed or those in small business from call out; or
f.offer the self-employed or those in small business the opportunity to resign/take discharge.

PARA.TAB: 20. Effective enforcement of the principles of employment protection is necessary. The existing penalties in the Defence (Re-establishment) Act are ineffective. A revised legislation approach to the enforcement of the proposed principles relevant to both peacetime and call out is needed.

21. The establishment of a Tribunal is needed to provide for conciliation and arbitration, when possible, but ultimately for the resolution of disputes by binding orders which would be enforceable at law.
22. The Defence Act should be amended to constitute a Reserve Protection Tribunal to provide employment protection.
23. The Tribunal's authority could be widened to deal with other matters such as the protection of education opportunities and the determination of financial assistance/relief.
24. The Tribunal, if constitutionally possible, should have enforcement power.

25. The Defence (Re-establishment) Act should be repealed and the current projections be written into new legislation which includes both Reserve service and call out. Perhaps the legislation could be framed as a code of behaviour based on the principles recommended in paragraph 17.

26. Mechanisms should be put in place to ensure that Reservist pay is commenced within a maximum of say three weeks after they report for duty and also that a call out gratuity, similar in concept to the Emergency Force Gratuity, be paid at the time of reporting for duty.
27. Protection, which should be provided in relation to debts, needs to be more comprehensive than that given to national Servicemen under the Defence (Re-establishment) Act.

28. The cost of a comprehensive debt moratorium system should be borne by the Federal Government. An insurance system or scheme could be devised similar to the current schemes available to insure lenders and borrowers against death, disability or retrenchment of the borrower with the premium being met by the Government.
29. The Reserve Forces Protection Tribunal should be given jurisdiction in relation to debts as well as employment protection.
30. In principle members of the ARes, when called out, should receive ARA pay and conditions so that all those serving on full-time duty are on equal footing.

31. The pay and conditions package for low level operations in Australia needs to be established as soon as practicable and not left until hostilities are imminent or have commenced, and a universal system of pay and conditions applicable anywhere in Australia and not just in operational areas is favoured.

32. A policy on financial compensation, at least in principle, needs to be decided and promulgated well in advance of any call out. Payment of compensation for agreed income loss is generally warranted unless exemptions or favourable employment options are available. Reliance on civilian employers voluntarily making up pay is not recommended.
33. The MSBS legislation, and other legislation if required, should be framed to require contributions by all Reservists who have been called out, irrespective of the period involved.
34. All Reservists called out contribute to the DFRDB Scheme/MSBS to have access to the disability and death provisions available.

35. Provision should be made for Reservists to be able to make higher contributions to maintain their pre-existing superannuation level and any hardship cases should be referred to the Tribunal for resolution.
36. Legislation should be provided to ensure superannuation payouts are not forfeited if a member dies, or is incapacitated, as a result of call out.
Life Insurance

37. Legislative provisions are required to maintain continuity of cover if life insurance premiums lapse during call out, and to ensure that payouts are not forfeited if a member dies while called out for situations short of defence emergency or war.

38. While the existence of and need for clauses in insurance policies is not generally disputed for the situation where there is widespread destruction and loss of life, legislative provisions are needed to prevent insurance companies from selectively or arbitrarily avoiding their policy obligations in time of call out short of defence emergency or war.

39. While the likelihood of call out is low, insurance premiums should not be affected in any way but when insurance companies can justify higher premiums (times of heightened tension), the Federal Government should meet any additional costs.

40. The Tribunal should have the jurisdiction in cases of dispute, and legislative provision should be provided to make it an offence to discriminate against Reservists in relation to the issue and conditions of insurance policies.
Disability Insurance

41. Disability insurance cover should be available to all Service personnel both before and during a call out situation. If following a call out, insurance companies can justify higher premiums, the Federal Government should meet the cost.

42. Appropriate amendments to the Veterans Entitlements Act and the Defence Force Retirements and Death Benefits Act to ensure that in time of war, defence emergency or otherwise, when the Reserve and Emergency Forces (in whole or part) are called out, all members then serving on continuous full-time service for the defence of Australia receive the same compensation and related projections and benefits should be earned irrespective of where, within or outside Australia, the members are serving at the time.
43. MSBS legislation should be reviewed to ensure that all Reservists who are called out have access to the compensation provision therein.

44. All students should be able to defer their call out liability for call out for a defence emergency or war until the termination of their studies. However, it should remain open for students to elect not to defer their call out and in such circumstances they should be given legislative protection to guarantee them the right to defer their studies and retain their place when they are released following call out.

45. Welfare issues include general welfare and security of the families left behind, single parent families, and families with both parents in the ARes. Exemptions or deferment from call out may be warranted along the lines applied to Regular Servicemen for compassionate leave and posting provisions and related management options.
Children
46. The welfare of children of Reservists should be maintained by applying the Regular 'model' to the Army Reserve if possible.

47. In general, as a principle, conditions of service available to Regulars and their dependants should be available to Reservists who have been called out and to their dependants. If, because of particular circumstances, Reservists or Regulars require special conditions circumstances need to be justified on a case-by-case basis.
48. Consideration should be given to applying all conditions of service on a case-by-case basis to the Reserves.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 25 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) During what are described as national news broadcasts, do ABC announcers operating in Sydney refer to the NSW Premier and NSW Ministers without identifying the State while doing so for Premiers and Ministers of other States; if so, (a) why and (b) will the ABC be instructed to recognise that the broadcasts are being transmitted in States other than New South Wales.
(2) Are NSW local news broadcasts used in other States through national network stations as a substitute for scheduled national news services; if so, why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question, based on information provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation:

PARA.TAB: (1) Generally, ABC announcers and journalists when referring to State politicians on national news broadcasts, identify the State where the politician holds a portfolio.

(a) In a letter dated 22 June 1992 to the ABC Managing Director, Mr Scholes drew attention to an error made by the Melbourne newsroom in a News item broadcast on ABC Radio Metropolitan station 3LO in Melbourne at 9.00 am on 22 June 1992.
The story which was broadcast from Melbourne about events occurring in NSW State politics, should have identified Mr Yabsley and Mr Greiner as (at that time) holding portfolios in the NSW Government.
(b) The Head of Radio News has asked the Victorian Radio News Editor to remind Melbourne journalists to ensure it is clear which States political leaders come from.

(2) As a matter of ABC Radio policy, NSW State or Sydney local news bulletins are not used in other States. They are not on the national networks as a substitute for scheduled national news bulletins.
This could occur only in the event of an error in computer switching of program sources around the network. Such errors with news bulletins are rare.
National bulletins are generally relayed from Sydney for Radio National and Triple J networks and from Adelaide for ABC-FM Stereo.

On Metropolitan and Regional stations, the majority of weekday news bulletins are produced and read from State capitals. At present, for operational and resource reasons, national bulletins are normally read out of Sydney on these networks between 10pm and 7.45am Monday to Friday.

News copy and audio material for inclusion in the State-produced "composite bulletins" is circulated between all ABC newsrooms via the ABC's Basys news computer links, landlines and satellite circuits.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Road Funding: Eastern Corridor in Melbourne

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 25 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: Has the Federal Government allocated funds to the eastern corridor in Melbourne; if so, what sum; if not, will funds be made available.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Yes. In the Federal land transport strategy I recently announced, Victoria is to receive $8 million in 1992/93 and $12 million in 1993/94, a total of $20 million in Federal funding, for urban public transport improvements and upgrading of road intersections in the eastern corridor of Melbourne.
